reviewText:
allright so i just finished the main game in 14 hours.
what i think about it?

let me first tell you that i have played and finished both Lords of Shadow 1 and Mirror of Fate, so this would be a great and useful review as i can compare this installment to the others.

first the negative part:

1 - the game is a tad shorter than Lords of Shadow 1 but it is longer that Mirror of Fate.
2 - this game is easier than LoS 1 and MoF, but the last boss is such a pain..
3 - not many puzzles, if any it will be a kid's puzzle.
4 - story is weaker than LoS 1 but somewhat alot better than MoF.
5 - the modern city is not very interesting.

now the positive part:

1 - graphics are very very good.
2 - combat system is simplified and it is more useful than LoS 1, no longer you have combos that are useless in combat.
3 - great story, still not as good as LoS 1. meaningful and relevant to the previous installments (LoS1 and MoF)
4 - no crashings, no freezings and no technical issues what so ever.
5 - amazing design of the Dracula's castle.
6 - Great soundtrack and voice acting, still i think LoS 1 was a bit better.
7 - rotateable camera angle in-game, which was somewhat painful in LoS 1.
8 - so many secrets and playablitiy, just like LoS 1 and even better than that.
9 - great boss fights and boss designs.
10 - state of the art character design, level design, theme, atmosphere and off course bosses.

frankly i dont get why on earth metacritic gave this game a 58 out of 100.
if i would to give LoS 1 98/100, then i would give this game at least 85/100.

i strongly recommend this game to you, defo worth the price and time.
do not look at the metacritic score, it is an amazing game.

i hope my review was useful to you guys, all the best and enjoy this astonshing game.

reviewText:
Don't bother suffering the reviews by critics and gamers alike who have written this title off because of their views of the first game.

Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 is easily in the running for my 2014 game of the year. You've undoubtedly seen the low reviews from people who claimed poor graphics. These claims are groundless, and trampled by some of the screenshots you can uncover in the community hub for this game. The graphics are staggeringly good, and some areas have such incredible photorealism that you have to look twice just to make sure you're looking at a texture.

The free-form camera works great. No longer can whiners throw a fit that they can't see elements of the battle, as you can now rotate 360 degrees in virtually every setting. It not only grants you a breathtaking view of the scenery; it allows you to tactically view your surroundings and analyze your best moves mid-combat.

Platforming and quick-time events have been significantly altered to combat the same list of complainers who hated them in the first game. Platforming now directly shows you where to go, and no longer forces you into long-winded movements where every step is a new jump. You now streamline climb like spider-man over most surfaces, and the ones too far grant you a swift, and simple jump to the new object. Quick-time events have been cut in quarters. No more cinematic sequences where defending yourself during a movie becomes normal. They're limited to combat, and the rare gameplay-to-cinema segue.

Controls are as easy as they were in the first game, with a few minor improvements. Button rotations have made combat noticeably smoother, and grant the player less hectic moments of desperate survival. Moves now have instant-cancellations, (another complaint from the first game) which allow the player the freedom to be as quick and reflexive as they want to be. If you die in combat-- you're just not up to snuff that round. No more blaming the devs.

The music. What can I say? I've never been so excited to tear into a new game just to hear the musical composition behind it. Oscar Araujo does it again with a score so moving and epic that it pulls players back into its immersive world of magic and demons with a slew of trumpet blasts and harmony-driven pieces that are sure to win over even the most jaded action-gamers.

There's never been a better time to jump into the world of Castlevania. I loved this game's predecessor, and I can still hold firmly to my nostalgic love of a classic Castlevania devoid of all the work MercurySteam has pumped into it in recent years.

However, the Lords of Shadow" series has brought life into a franchise that has desperately needed fresh-blood (forgive the pun).

I strongly urge anyone to pick up this title
date: even if you're only looking for a new action-game. The battles are challenging; you'll be forced to reconsider how you take on countless enemies that you think you know well enough from the first game.\n\nThe story is moving. Piecing together questions and answers from both the first game as well as Mirror of Fate
recommended: LoS 2 brings about a conclusion that is sure to yield an uproar from the masses for more of this tale.\n\nYou are no longer a pure-hearted man. Gabriel has become a ruthless
hoursPlayed: violence-embracing monster who is indifferent to suffering and who will stop at nothing to obtain the freedom he desires. Many of his choices in the game will makes fans of the holy-hero cringe as he shows how his transformation into the Prince of Darkness has affected his moral judgment.\n\nThis game is worth your money
voteText: and it's worth your time. If this game stretches even HALF the length of the first game
helpfulPercent: then it's going to be a ride you'll never forget."

reviewText:
Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 continues the story of Gabriel Belmont and his transformation into the dark lord; Dracula.

Upon starting the game you'll immediately be plunged into an epic battle as Dracula's castle is besieged by the Brotherhood of Light. During this time you'll be trained in the art of combat, mastering Dracula's three weapons as well as evasive maneuvers. The weapons vary and each of them fill a specialized role.

After the initial opening, you'll be unleashed into an open world with two dimensions to travel between, Dracula's Castle and a modern Gothic city built upon its ruins. The art direction and audio is phenomenal, featuring an amazing cast of voice actors; Robert Carlyle, Sir Patrick Stewart, and Jason Isaacs to name a few. The soundtrack is also really well done, fitting the mood of the game flawlessly. The environments are absolutely beautiful, allowing plenty of room for exploration while searching for the various upgrades, lore and abilities.

The story, when combined with the previous two entries is engaging and helps propel you through the 15 hour game, although the ending is a bit abrupt as well as disappointing. Veterans of the Hack n' Slash genre will want to begin on the harder difficulty as it's a bit simple when compared to games like Devil May Cry and Bayonetta. Between, fighting, exploring, puzzle solving, and platforming there's a lot of fun to be had.

While the stealth segments seem to be a major complaint for a lot of reviewers, they don’t detract from the overall game. I’ll admit that I was skeptical at first since stealth really has no business being in a Castlevania title, but they play out similarly to puzzles opposed to traditional stealth missions. They’re also few and far between.

The menu system is highly polished and will document every type of creature you fight against. It also acts to manage your upgrades and abilities as you level. Plenty of Lore and backstory is provided along the way from diaries as well.

While it'd be nice to have a triple A classic Symphony of the Night experience, LoS2 is great in its own way and playing as “The Dragon” with this new take on the legend is a blast. Don’t believe some of the critics, Lords of Shadow 2 is a must-play.

For a longer and more detailed review, here’s a video my friend and I put together:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iUW5McQYaCE

Pros:
+ Excellent Art Direction
+ Great Soundtrack
+ All-star Voice Acting
+ Balanced Gameplay
+ Large open world to explore

Cons:
- Dracula doesn’t feel evil enough
- Disappointing Finale

reviewText:
It usually happens I find myself torn between a diamond in the rough and problematic technical or some other aspect of the game, but with Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 it's somewhat different. Time to see if I can put into somewhat coherent paragraph or two as to why that's the case.

Let's start off by saying I was one of the people who enjoyed the original Lords of Shadow for what it was – not necessarily a creatively original masterpiece, but a game of astounding production values, competent writing and tight narrative punctuated by stellar voice work and lastly, and perhaps most importantly, it was a very meaty game which lead to some even saying it was too long for its own good. Fast forward to sequel and you can see it basically falters in each of these categories.

Interestingly enough game seems to swing between two polar opposites with its visuals because on one hand you have this classic Castlevania look comprised of foreboding yet mystical gothic castle to romp through, as well as its assorted menagerie of beasties to but heads with and solve painfully few puzzles compared to the first game, but on the other you have to contend with extremely bland modern-day warehouses and science laboratories ad nauseam alongside some fairly uninspired enemies ranging from more classical demons and Satanists to, what really should've been more interesting that ended up, futuristic soldiers and cybernetic abominations roaming the streets. But honestly, it's this weird disjointed narrative that undoes the game the most in my mind because you can clearly tell there was meant to be more there instead of just going from A to B and meandering in-between retreading locations with nothing but brief radio contacts from time to time. And lastly – game is simply short compared to the first one and that probably ties into my previous point. Rumors abound regarding game's troubled development were apparently well founded.

That's not to say game is bad because, as you will have most likely noticed despite my continued rambling on regarding its negatives, this is marked as a positive review overall. It's still Lords of Shadow and if you liked the original you'll probably like this considering you can overlook its weak story. Gameplay feels familiar and skippable QTEs are god-sent, both of which are points in game's favor for me, not to mention combat and item system was expanded and enemy variety despite their designs actually means you'll end up facing quite a bit of different behaviors. Story establishes the mood very early on as one of Dracula's somber and more resigned journey, one profoundly personal despite all other events that unfold over the course of the game. Had it been properly fleshed out and Robert Carlyle's more subdued performance given time to develop, occasional hamfisted melodrama notwithstanding, it would've been a much, much better final product. I also heard some nay saying about mandatory stealth sections in the game to which I say it's about time to drop hand-holding. Barring for one section involving leaves and crazed Satyr these were a welcome diversion for me and fitting considering MC's condition story-wise.

One last caveat I feel should be posted is that playing the original game and Mirror of Fate is recommended before tackling the sequel.

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iUW5McQYaCE&list=UURLmXiAxqgzAGPO64W78sSg

Mercury Steam's hack and slash take on Konami's long running vampire slaying franchise proved to be a bit divisive by rebooting the franchise's lore and staying away from the loot gathering of the massively successful side scrolling titles starting with Symphony of the Night. With Lords of Shadow 2, Mecury Steam is drawing their controversial take on the franchise to a close, putting players in the worn out boots of Dracula himself as he faces off against Satan and his army of minions. Attempting to inject a bit of metroidvania design and hopping back and forth between Dracula's castle and modern times, is this the compromise between the side scrolling titles and the foundation laid by Lords of Shadow?

After a recap of the events of Lords of Shadow and Mirror of Fate, players are treated to an epic prologue that has Dracula defending his less than humble abode from a tremendous siege which culminates in an encounter with his son, Alucard.  The game then flashes forward a thousand years to find a very weak Dracula awakening in a cathedral in modern times greeted by Zobek. Zobek offers Dracula the chance to end his cursed existence in exchange for the death's of Satan's acolytes. In typical video game fashion, Dracula must regain his lost powers and battle a few inner demons in addition to Satan's minions. While the sections that have Dracula revisiting his castle provide some appreciative depth and introspection, the plot unfolding in modern times is rather underwhelming and even a bit silly. The game is at it's narrative peak when it recaptures the spirit of Gabirel's sober journey in the first game, reflecting on Dracula's numerous sins and the decimation of the Belmont family.

Perhaps the largest change to Lords of Shadow 2 comes in it's structure. Dracula moves between present day and his castle and, eventually, players can revisit areas previously explored. It makes the game more metroidvania-like thank it's predecessor but hoping back and forth between the two areas leaves the geography feeling fragmented and backtracking only becomes available much later in the game making this still feel somewhat like a linear level based affair. Combat remains largely intact from the previous games with light and dark magic now complimented by two additional weapons: the chaos claws and the void sword. These along with Dracula's shadow whip can be upgraded by purchasing various moves and utilizing them. It's a system that rewards using your entire move set and is an excellent addition to a genre where many rely on a couple effective all purpose combos. Relics have been added as consumable items that give Dracula the ability to restore his health, transform into a dragon for massive damage and gain extra experience.

Tragically, the gameplay does take a major step back when it comes to the puzzles. Standing in for the first game's brain teasers are a gauntlet of stealth bits that have Dracula posessing enemies, cowering in the shadows and transforming into a rat in order to navigate small cracks and crevices. Most of these are easy and don't feel rewarding in addition to being at odds with playing as a powerful and feared vampire. A couple of the stealth sections can prove to be frustrating and one visit to a forum exposes one pre-boss fight stealth section as a stopping point for many. Boss fights are also completely unchallenging which is a shame since Lords of Shadow provided an excellent difficulty balance.  Fortunately, those who invest in the DLC will be treated to gameplay and puzzles that are more in line with the original Lords of Shadow making it an excellent piece of content for fans even though it's narrative additions are minimal.

On the PC, Lords of Shadow 2's beautiful art direction is showcased by higher resolution textures and runs silky smooth at 60fps. Despite the fact that it doesn't offer the lastest graphical bells and whistles, this Direct X 9 title is more than pleasing to look and all of it's details can be appreciated since the fixed camera of the first game has been ditched. The Castle in particular is a stunning place to be and it becomes almost frustrating that the entire game doesn't take place there since the modern city seems a bit bland in comparison. Enemies can also be a bit bland and repetative but the bosses generally make up for this minor short fall. The soundtrack to Lords of Shadow 2 is also magnificent with beautiful somber orchestral compositions and delicate piano pieces. It adds a huge amount of ambiance to the game and is perhaps this year's best soundtrack.

Lords of Shadow 2 is unequivocally not as good on the whole as it's predecessor though it shows a few major improvements that are easy to appreciate. It's a lengthy experience that offers superb combat, excellent visuals and a top notch soundtrack. For a Castlevania fan, it generally outweighs the lame stealth segments, repetitive enemies and underwhelming open world design. Even for it's biggest detractors, the Lords of Shadows games are proof that Castlevania can exist in three dimensions.

reviewText:
So, I actually liked it a lot more than I expected. The overall impression of it everywhere seemed to be very negative (regardless of what you think about metacritic, 58/100 doesn't exactly inspire confidence), but I ended up liking it quite a bit.

The combat is fun, even though it sometimes feel like the enemies have too many unblockacle moves, so instead of sync blocking you are dodging maybe more than I would prefer. Still, Dracula is nimble and there are enough new moves doled out every now and then to keep things interesting all the way through. Void and Chaos powers replace the light and dark magic from the first game, but more in name than function. You still get orbs from keeping your combat focus going, in order to fill out those magic meters, and one of them is more powerful and the other one is less, but heals with every hit landed. It's essentially the same system as the first LoS, but some very minor differences. Probably the biggest difference with combat is not even directly related to combat, but it's the free camera. And they handle it well, the combat camera is smart most of the time (unlike say, the camera in MGRR), and doesn't get in the way. All the finishers take too long though, I get it, you are Dracula, but suck that blood a little faster, thanks. But overall, good stuff.

Presentation is probably the most uneven thing in the entire package. Environments and locations can be gorgeous, but they can also be ♥♥♥♥ing boring. Boring sewers and industrial plants, but also gorgeous gothic (or something) architecture and fantastic vistas. Dracula seems incredibly tiny in this world too. The grand scale of everything works well in the non-industrial setting, big majectic doors and windows etc, but in the industrial setting it just looks comical. Music is the same, Araujo does some good work with some tracks, but others are just a big meeh. I remember reading an interview from him where he says that he didn't really have a lot of freedom in the end, that he had tried to approach the music from other angles but was told that it needed to be more cinematic. Some of it works, some of it doesn't. The story is really really dumb, somewhat poorly written, but it does its job of pushing you towards your next objective.

The worst part are the sections where they probably thought that they should add some variety in the gameplay design or something. Obviously the much talked stealth stuff is one part of that. They have absolutely no place in this game, they are just poor. But they are also really easy and short, so I'm not sure how the press was so badly hung up on them. Yes, they suck ♥♥♥, but it takes like 2 minutes to go through. The elevator action section is dumb as well, again, not because it's hard or anything, but a timed switch to restore power in order to use an elevator is not fun. And I imagine the director had played Uncharted and told that we need something like that, heart pounding set pieces. The results are absolute ♥♥♥♥. There's one section where the floor falls under you, push forward and push A for awesome. The entire train section is hot garbage, but especially the part where you dodge the roof lights or whatever. And then there's the QTE's, which you can turn off from the settings. If you played LoS, you'll probably remember that most boss fights had some easy quicktime event sequences in them, sometimes in the middle or in the end, and usually if you failed the boss would gain a little health back, rinse and repeat until you were quick and timely enough. That's still here, but if you turn them off, it will just play that whole section as if you were successful. And I very much recommend it. What does it tell you about this hot feature that they added an option to just disable them?

The game is very linear, but it has a hint of that non-linearity with all the secrets you can find. That speaks to me in some primal level and I can just get lost in the world, just running around and looking behind every corner and such to find everything. It just speaks to me man. Of course I would recommend you do this only after you get all your powers back, can't get them all without all your powers. There's also some combat challenges, and I played through couple tiers of them... but didn't bother with the rest. It gets into a little more complicated stuff than I have patience for (you can only hit this dude while he is frozen, while simultaneously killing smaller dudes every 20 seconds etc etc). For me it takes the fun out of it.

So overall, I'd say my experience with the game is positive. I paid ~20$ for it and I'd say it's worth at least that if not more.

reviewText:
(DISCLAIMER: Objectively, as a game, Castlevania LoS 2 is a good, overall,  game that has some flaws. However, as a follow up to Castlevania LoS, it is terribly disappointing. My recommendation is based on the game itself, not my disappointment as  a sequel to the original.)


Let's start with the GOOD. The combat has been refined in a very nice way and thusly feels a bit more responsive. As in the last game, with the points/experience that you receive from defeating enemies, you can use that to buy additional moves for your weapons, but this time, you have the addition of the chaos claws and void sword AND they have their own moveset on top of the same function as shadow and light magic respectively. Thusly, giving you many combo possibilities. Dodging is smooth, although I would have preferred a roll like the original, or the turning into smoke like Laura in the original game as well. I'm glad for the addition of the free rotating camera that was lacking in the first game.

Platforming has also been improved and is much smoother than before.

The graphics, very,very nice. However, it seems a bit of a waste since the most of the environments are dank, dark and very similar; unlike the original game where there was a lush forests, autumn ruins, icy castles, dark dungeons, crazy grand canyonesque platforming. Just wasted potential overall, but a great graphics engine nonetheless.

Now for the BAD: STEALTH, man oh man, this game never needed stealth to begin with so I don't know why it's even here. Not that I mind stealth, it's just done very, very poorly in this game. The stealth sections were very tedious and boring. It was repetitive and not necessary to the game.
Speaking of not necessary, the section where you have to hide from Pan's brother so you don't get one-shotted....ridiculous! You're freaking Dracula, the prince of freaking darkness. Satan is even scared of you in the game, yet, you have to hide from this guy? Again, since this was a stealth portion, it was terrible and necessary.

The modern setting, I'll admit that I was excited to check out a modern setting in LoS, but honestly, it felt so out of place, especially the robots and commandos in exo suits. The sections you get to go back to the castle felt much more appropriate and epic.

The story, the story this time around, lacked a sense of urgency and purpose. This is probably partly due to that you're now Dracula and you don't care weather thousands of people live or die. I through most of the game, it felt as if I was just trudging along just getting through the game, instead of feeling like I'm making real progress. The story lacked any real revelations, twists or turns, like the original had. It was very one track and lacked anything with real substance. There is no internal struggle like in the first game, any real tragedy with character investment, the story felt like it had a beginning and an end but missing pieces in the middle, not necessarily plot holes, but more so they needed to add elements to make it really interesting.

Overall, the game is ok with some flaws. I did have fun with the combat, especially in the intro of the game, but after that, it felt like it was all downhill from there; lack luster story, repetitive environments, terribly implemented stealth. Sadly,  Castlevania LoS 2 just couldn’t meet the standards set by the first. As a huge fan of this series, I'm hugely disappointed. As a gamer, it's a “not bad” game.

7/10

reviewText:
I'm a diehard Castlevania fan. I was also one of the few who defended Lords of Shadow 1 when it really alienated the Castlevania name. I enjoyed the first game a lot, and I was really excited with the idea of a second game.

Unfortunately, I can't recommend this title. It does have great ideas, and I love NWO references (like a reptillian creature, and that a pharmaceutical company is in leagues with Satan). In any case, I'd like to think that this is the Simon's Quest for the Lords of Shadow series. The gameplay is okay, but it has no idea what it wants to be. It wants to be a hack/slash adventure, yet it wants to be a platformer, and yet there are stealth sections which ultimately hurt the game. As a customer, I wanted the Castlevania that built on Lords of Shadow 1, not whatever this is currently.

The game falls VERY flat in the end. I was not satisfied with the story, despite the massively epic build up from E3. With that said, I don't recommend the game at full retail value. Maybe if it drops down to 30 or 20, I would say go ahead. As it stands, it truly is one of the weakest.

Pros:

Robert Carlyle as Dracula, other voices were great too.
Decent story

Cons:

Doesn't know what it wants to be, multi-vision project
Too few enemies
Doesn't offer the excitement that LoS1 provided
Flat ending
Felt rushed

reviewText:
8.5/10
Overview: Third Person Action Adventure

The Good

+ The setting is a mixture of a modern city in ruins and Draculas old castle. Both settings provide a nice contrast with each other and are fun to explore

+ The first major difference from the original is the ability to control the camera as opposed to having a fixed camera in the first game.

+ The second major change is all the levels are interconnected with each other. This provides for a much more immersive and seamless experience with gameplay.

+ Combat is more refined than the original and just as fun. You have light magic that does less damage but heals you whenever you damage an enemy and chaos magic that does significantly more damage but is slower and has less range. Effectively dodging and switching between your magic meters is fun and engaging. If you played the first game, the combat should offer little surprise to you. One key difference is by using attacks over and over again you can increase your mastery of a certain weapons making them stronger.

+ Boss battles have always been a highlight for this series and this game is no exception. Bosses are unique, well designed and will require you to use all your techniques in battle to defeat them.

+ the game has plenty of collectables scattered throughout the world

+ The game features 16 optional challenges to further extend your game time. Each challenge has a series of objectives that has to be completed in order to complete the challenge.

+ option to disable quicktime events


The Average

The story is not awful but it didn't really do much either. It doesn't help that most of the dialogue spoken by the villains is bad.

This game has some REALLY annoying enemies that will test your patience


The Bad

For some odd reason the developers decided to include stealth sections in the game. I like stealth games and I like it when developers try to mix up the gameplay but this was just a bad effort. The stealth sections feel very out of place and are not always clear in what you have to do making for some really frustrating trial and error. It also feels very odd that you play a badass destroying most enemies in your path only to reach a section in the level where you have to avoid enemies.


Conclusion

This game fixed two of my biggest gripes from the first game. The fact that the levels are interconnected and the ability to actually control the camera make for a much better gameplay experience despite the awful stealth sections. I was a bit baffled that reviewers panned this game pretty badly as I think this game improves the first game in many ways. If you enjoyed the first game then there is no reason why you shouldn't love this game as well, unless of course the modern day setting doesn't appeal to you.

reviewText:
Some spoilers ahead:

Finishing Lords of Shadow 2 left me with a bitter aftertaste.

From the very beginning of the game, you will be forced into stealth missions, evading generic vat-grown monstrosities in high-tech labs. The game's combat system, one of it's greatest strengths, is mercilessly defenestrated here, and as you find yourself sneaking behind an invulnerable guard for the fifth time, you start to wonder at what point it was that you stopped having fun.

But then you cross over into a castle area, and the familiar atmosphere coupled with the excellent swordplay (whipplay?) makes the game seem like a worthy sequel once again. The combat is fast and fluid, with the accelerated orb gain (compared to the first game) playing a great part in that. The platforming is much more forgiving, although the inclusion of (even more) platform highlighting was really not needed.

As soon as the game manages to realize you're having fun, however, you encounter the acolytes of Satan. These unfortunate excuses for characters that seem to have been created by pulling edgy tropes from a hat will casually wipe the floor with you - that is, until you use a clever trick to defeat them. Unfortunately, this is a sign of things to come, as well as one of my biggest issues with the game. You are Dracula, the Prince of Darkness. You've ruled this Earth from the shadows for centures, while Satan cowered from you ever since his last defeat. Well, it sure doesn't feel like it, since you'll spend most of your time in LoS2 running away from large fights and powerful enemies. Gabriel Belmont feels no more powerful than he was in the first game - weaker, in fact, due to the fact that you start the game with no skills or abilities.

Still, I went on with the game, hoping that the story would make it worthwhile. I cleaved my way through research facilities and desolated city streets, castle ramparts and dungeons. The narration was served to me in droplets, as if the whole story was an afterthought - an idea that I haven't quite managed to fully dismiss. Eventually, after maybe 12 hours of gameplay, the story started going somewhere. A major revelation was shown, and it had me genuinely interested.

Then it abruptly ended. There was a boss dull boss fight, set on an epic stage only to serve as a distraction from its lazy design (I'll use this opportunity to coin the term forced epic"). It was over
date: Dracula said a cheesy one-liner and the credits rolled. That was it. The cluttered mess that the story had become turned into a Gordian knot not even Dracula's Void sword could sever

reviewText:
As a Castlevania fan (and I mean all of them), I recommend this game sincerely to fans of the series, gothic atmospheres, vampire and other mythical lore and fast-paced action games.
I've played this game before on a different system, but I needed it again for the PC. That's how much I love it.

The negatives about this game often are about the stealth parts and the modern day sequences. I also find those less appealing, but it makes me appreciate the castle sequences even better. The environments are beautiful and open for exploration. Once you've got the majority of your abilities the exploration becomes the best part of the game, for me at least.

Some people say the story is so so, but I love the amount of effort they put in the lore. A lot of the story is hidden in the pages of the bestiary and abilities. Accompanied by amazing artwork and good music (though, earlier Castlevania's had better music), it makes it a atmospheric experience of storytelling.

My opinion might be influenced by my love for the series, but I can still recommend this game just for the amazing leveldesign, atmosphere, awesome bossbattles and rich mythological lore.

After I was highly disapointed by the console port of Lords of Shadows 1 I must say I really like this game. It got a 58 Metacritics score, but since I'm a sucker for Metroidvania and God of War-like games I gave it a try.

reviewText:
Recommended? Maybe.....

After giving Castlevania Lords of Shadow 1 a glowing review, it really pains me to give this a thumbs down.  I was really hopeful that this sequel would follow in its footsteps as a worthy successor. Unfortunately this game is marred by a clunky camera system, weird game mechanics that don't always work right and an irritating save/checkpoint system that punishes you heavily for failure by making you repeat the same sequences and boss fights over and over again until you get them exactly right.

By contrast, the first game's checkpoint system was much better in saving your progress (even during boss fight stages) and all the artifacts and items you picked up you kept after you got them. If you died at a particular place, you would just restart at that place with all of your previous progress saved. Not here, you're forced to proceed a great deal further in most instances in order for everything to be saved. Make a mistake and you're going all the way back to the beginning of the sequence or fight. It's just frustrating and not fun.

The story is just OK. Nothing that really draws you in and connects you to its ficitional world like the first one. The levels take place in a bizarre alternating transition between the past and present which makes the game feel like a cross between its gothic horror roots and the futuristic setting of Doom 3. In the modern levels Dracula will be operating elevators, powering modern machinery and battling mechanized bad guys that are equipped machine guns, grenade launchers and electronic counter measures, it just feels out of place. The main characters aren't as memorable nor do they stir up the same level of emotion as Lords of Shadow 1.

It's also much harder to go back to previous levels and pick up many of the artifacts you'll need to make your character strong enough to face the tougher enemies in the late game after you unlock the special powers required to get to them. There isn't an individual level selection system like the first game. Instead you have to select a previous location and then find a special room which allows you to teleport to an area of the that location where you think you might have left something behind. It takes way more time to do and just means more repetition of the same convoluted areas over and over.

I'd say it's worth picking up only on sale and only if you're a fan of the first one (having completed it) and Mirror of Fate and have an interest in the story. That's alot of ands. At the time of this writing, I haven't finished it and I intend to see it through but after 15 or so hours I'm getting ready for it to be done.

Overall 5/10

Please do think for yourself, watch some videos and some gameplay and play for yourself Heres my review on why this was a fun game to play.  I enjoyed all 15 hours of it and thats not finding Everything.

The Story was not suspenseful as LOS this time around, It started off flaring and action packed and for some reason just ended in a sorta fizz. You'll start as Gabriel in his castle fighting against the army of brotherhood, After so you'll be treated with some story telling from the Ds version of the game and past forward into the future. You are Gabriel Belmont thousands of years laters in the future you'll be fighting Satans army while experiencing the past and the future in the game at the time. Play the game to find out more. The music of course was amazing as usual and really brings out the game, alot of the symphony and the epic music world music makes you feel really pumped playing it, Even if you're walking through an empty hallway. Gameplay  The fighting and combat is fast and action packed, fighting enemies is sort of like a puzzle and requires strategy and thinking You cannot go in mashing, I tried and ended up looking like a fool and getting ripped by the mobs. You'll have to think the game revolves around your shadow whip, Vorpal blade which heals when you hit enemy and your Chaos gaunlet  which breaks defense when you use it against certain enemies along with dodging and guarding mechanic.
The game itself has alot more jumping puzzles and Puzzles itself. This time along with some stealth which is medicore. There is alot more platforming. The real treat is that also the world is a bit more explorable this time around, with many sections of the future + past at the same time.

Used an xbox controller for this game, tried the keyboard and didn't work too well for me, also note the port had Xbox showing buttons popped up which needs to be fixed for players. This time the camera is also no longer in a fixed position, it is  now controlled by the player though could be better if you could actually hit a button to face your enemy.

The graphic itself has HD textures given to you, which is great but doesn't change the fact that it was  A PORT. though still a great game and looks quite decent. The level design looks phenominal, the detail put into it if you look carefully and how the buttons and switches in the game works the way they do, The future might look a little bleak and grim maybe a  bit different than what many expects but did look ok.

+Fast action paced combat that requires players to think before mashing

+ Not a linear game this time around, has explorable areas that can be revisted with warp points.

reviewText:
Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 is lying to you, there are not Lords of Shadow in this game. But luckily there is a castle, so I guess it's not all bad.
Okay, half a castle.

You play as Dracula...What, really? Yeah, you play as that guy you've been beating up since the 80's. Now, when I played Lords of Shadow I explained that I am not familiar with Castlevania outside of a little bit of Symphony of the Night. Now that I've played more than an hour of the original games I have a better understanding of the series. And now I come to you saying that Castlevania: Lords of Shadow as a series feels more like a fairly competent fan fiction than it's own universe.

After an annoying tutorial sequence, you wake up in the DISTANT FUTURE OF 1999, at least I think it's 1999. Dracula awakens form his long slumber looking much like I do after a Saturday night, minus the incredibly handsome. After getting beaten up by a large T-rex looking monster, you are saved by a man in armor  who's wielding a suspiciously Japanese looking sword, lets just call him Scrungus Humungous for now.

So Scrungus takes you back to his master Zobek, who is Patrick Stewart but also a jerk. He tells you that Satan is using his Acolytes to revive him so he can dominate the world. Zobek tells you that if you can pull Satan out of hiding and defeat him, he will give Dracula the eternal rest he longed for.

So yes, this game is about Dracula fist fighting Satan.

I should probably explain the game now.

Much like the first game, LOS is a action beat-em-up much like God of War. You have three weapons, a whip, a sword, and your dukes, but your dukes are on fire, how rad is that? Both the sword and your fire fists are on a meter of sorts while your whip is good to go at any moment, not unlike a whip in that weird teachers basement.

Your enemies come in different shapes and sizes, with a nice touch that they all have lore and back story to them. But other than a few special moves they all attack the same outside of the very few bosses you run into. Standard attacks can be both blocked and countered, leaving the enemy open for a critical attack. But every now and then, or more than often, all the time, the enemy will use a heavy attack which you will have to dodge. Outside of a few items and changing weapons on the fly, that's about as complicated as combat gets.

So I'm going to say some bad stuff now.

Like I said before, I finally got familiar with Castlevania as a whole, and now a lot of elements just leave a bad taste in my mouth. Outside of Dracula originally being Gabriel Belmont (Spoilers by the way, if you've never watched any of the trailers), the Belmont lineage kind of gets turned into that soup the weird lady hands out down town. Dracula and Alucard (That's Dracula backwards) are both Belmonts and the rest of the lineage kind of takes a back seat.  Actual spoilers by the way.
You actually DO meet another Belmont named Victor, but he dies roughly 10 minutes after you meet him, so whatever.

This is honestly kind of stupid, in the original series, Dracula was a man named Mathias Cronqvist, so not only did they change who Dracula actually IS but they also flat out replaced him with their own new character for the series: Gabriel.

What was the point of this? I'm not in the fanbase but did anyone actually ask for Dracula as a playable character? It doesn't add anything because your best healing is the same healing you used in the last game because Dracula biting fools doesn't really cut it. If they really wanted you to play as a Vampire why didn't they just have you play as Alucard as you did in Symphony or that other part of Mirror of Fate? Alucard already plays better than his father does in the DLC and has a more interesting set of skills.

Did they think that people really liked Gabriel so much as a character that they wouldn't want to move on to another Belmont? Perhaps continue the narrative in another way that doesn't include reusing an original character you made specifically for your reboot? It doesn't really even feel all that Castlevania like, really, outside of a few name drops and shout outs from previous games.

And for a game with as much padding as Lords of Shadow 2, it sure as hell is rushed at the end. And by that I mean it just kind of ends, it's all over and then Dracula goes to take a nap. I'm not kidding, that's how it ends. Roll credits. I've watched bum fights with better closure than that.

Should you play Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2: The Reckoning: Fury Road?

This is actually hard. Because the game has a really strong start but then kind of fades away at the half way point. A lot of plot points are just kind of shoved aside or hand waved before the game comes to an end and it drags on just long enough for the combat to become frustrating and boring. Just like my sex life.

But on the other hand, it's nowhere near as offensive as other reboots like, lets say, DmC, or my sex life. I just feel like it could have maybe cut out a lot of the fat and busy work and focused on it's strongest point.

Just like my sex life.


LOS2 is getting pass, but just barely, I would get it while it's on sale at five bucks or less. It's not great, but it's nowhere near as offensive as a lot of other reviewers made it out ot be. If you absolutely NEED a vampire game right at this moment, though? You can get the Legacy of Kain series for much cheaper.

Fortressmania 2: Kings of Shade gets 3 badly voiced sections from Symphony of the night out of 6.

Dracula backwards is Alucard.

reviewText:
This game is a mixed bag, and by no means outright terrible. There are however many flaws which strike me.

Gameplay in and of itself, with the exception of the glaring annoyance of nonsensical stealth sections is decent enough, and all of the provided mechanics are put to work equally in the combat and in exploring the world itself. This works well enough though it doesn't appear to me to be anything revolutionary or exciting.

Stealth sections very much break the established flow, despite being short and ridiculously easy to get past they are at odds with the rest of the game, disabling your ability to perform any attacks short of stunning opponents and trying to escape. It doesn't make sense when the game plays up the fact you're a character with ridiculous combat ability, and you're regularly destroying enemies twice the size or so of the guards in the stealth section which utterly wreck you in seconds if you get caught. The mechanics the stealth sections use, possesion and transforming into a swarm of rats don't seem to be used to their utmost. Particularly possession, why not allow the player to actually do something with the apparently invincible guard they're controlling aside from use an eye scanner to open a door?

As for turning into a group of rats, when the rat you're controlling dies - you possess the next rat in your entourage.  If all the rats die, you die.  This is used to -some- effect in the first stealth section where you have to navigate tunnels and avoid hazards, keeping your other rats alive. As well as again later on very briefly.  I don't particularly like this kind of gameplay, but the idea was good and for the effort spent in making it functional it seems very underused.

The game world itself is nice looking and well designed in most respects but it's fairly linear, it does allow backtracking throughout though mainly for the purposes of revisiting past areas with new abilities to grab missed collectables, which is more in tow with the series prior, although likely not quite as interesting. If you like collecting lots of crap (increases to various gauges, unlockable challenges, item limit upgrades, artwork) and trying to 100% games, that's a pro and you might enjoy it. The upgrade system for the main set of combat abilities is good, and offers some interesting options.

Enemies are fairly varied, interesting and the bosses are pretty fun. Though the hardest difficulty is locked until you've beaten the game. One flaw is that enemies and bosses (and anyone in combat with you) will quote the same 3-6 lines of dialogue over and over as you fight them to the point of it becoming annoying.  I like about as many of the character and enemy designs as I find unappealing, even then knowing that the ones I do like aren't very memorable and don't actually get that much focus.

Story is a big no sale for me, which is a shame because signifigant portions of it could be considered competent and plenty of time has clearly been spent on it. The main setting is uninteresting and feels generic as a plot point (despite the actual work which went into designing it.) Most of the characters motivations seem either generic, pointless, obvious or some combination of all three. The best segments are generally spent in the castle sequences, but the whole premise behind that is fundamentally pretty simple and renders itself unnecessary on the whole. There's a lot of background information in the journal which updates with entries on your abilities when you get them, and each enemy type/character when you kill/meet them respectively. This is nice if you like these kind of details.

PC controls work well enough, although onscreen prompts still use controller buttons which is lazy. There is a contextual control reference dropdown bound to F1 which shows what action, what button it's mapped too and what key represents that button, which is at least something. Being provided with a HD texture pack and features like being able to disable QTE's is great. Even if I found this game average I feel at least somewhat vindicated in supporting it for providing things like this.

If you're sensible, You'll wait to get this until it's on sale or gets a price drop. It's entertaining, stable and more or less what it presents itself as, but no grand masterpiece unless you're a person who'd particularly enjoy the areas where the game excels and be capable of enjoying it despite its problems.

reviewText:
The only other Castlevania game I played to completion prior to this one was C:SotN, widely regarded as the best Castlevania in the series. Without knowing until after I finished this Lords of Shadow series follows an alternate timeline from the others in that series, and without playing Lords of Shadow 1, I enjoyed it a lot. The game catches you up to the story of Lords of Shadow well, and I enjoyed the plot and flow of the game.

Gameplay (fighting) is pretty hack-slash with comboing using the whip, or sword/chaos claws but is quite simple. I've read people compare it to God of War, but having not played that series I wouldn't know. I wasn't expecting anything amazing in combat but I did find it fun to play despite not a huge variation in enemies. At least most of the enemies weren't annoying, but I did dread getting into fights. There was a fair bit of platforming, some stealth missions which I hated, and some nice simple puzzle-solving. There as good flow and variation during the story to keep it fresh.

Exploration in this game is pretty lacking. Missions/the story is pretty linear/guided, and unless you wanted to upgrade your weapons/skills (not necessary if you played on an easier difficulty like me, I just wanted to play this game casually) there was no point in re-visiting areas. You can access 'new areas' in levels with upgraded abilities later in the game, but there's really no point unlike in Castlevania:SotN because you won't be getting new weapons/skills/etc. doing so. Don't expect some Skyrim/TES bonuses from going off the beaten path

Visually, this game is pretty good. Nice background scenery, the castle looks beautiful. The modern city is kind of 'meh', but I did appreciate how the game looked. Some of the audio tracks are great too, but you will run into a lot of the same music.

Overall, I had fun with the game and enjoyed it for what it was. I admitedly got frustrated with some parts of the game and would just quit playing 10 minutes in if I couldn't advance through the story fast enough to do other stuff but my yearning for knowing what happened in this game kept me coming back. I won't be playing it beyond the story mode and doing a NG+ mode or anything like that. Buy it on sale for 10-15 dollars but I wouldn't pay full price for it.

reviewText:
Continuing from the first Lords of Shadow, which had a strong sense of adventure, always moving on, traveling from one end to the other and, apart from the dlc(which I'd advice you to simply ignore entirely), never forces you to backtrack. A feeling of being on an grandious, epic, adventure through ancient lands and fairy creatures as well as monsters. It's was not the most ideal re-imagining of the Castlevania brand, there were the low's but also the high's, and the high's outweighed the low's IMO... that is until they actually continued from the epilogue and explained it.

Lords of Shadow 2 is an oddly excellent example of a game who's budget coupled with one man's over-confidence(from the success of the first game) turned arrogance, effectively ruined any ounce of a future this particular franchise ever had. There is quality here, don't doubt it, it's just found sparsely between thick stretches of game-design that will utterly boggle the mind, how Enric Álvarez, the series director who, literaly, stood for every gameplay design and story sequence in LoS2, how he ever convinced himself this was good.

The combat is more of less the exact same, apart from a few weapons, with an added options to turn off quicktime-events.

The game is split up between modern-times, where you travel through a city which was built around Dracula's grand castle, and past times, before humanity apparently conquered the dark prince, a mystery you will only solve a half-hour before the credits roll. Execution is everything. The story telling, the characters, the level design, the various game mechanics, the leveling system to the weapons... all of it is just horribly miss-matched and all over the place. There are stealth sections equiped with enemies in god-mode. You simply aren't able to fight them and they take you out with projectiles in two hits. These sections are numerous and extremely tedious. You're supposed to be Dracula, taking on Satan himself... but you are apparently a small ant compared to this simple mob. Laughable. PR said that they were going to fuse the first LoS with SotN(one of my favorite games ever) and the thought had me riveting with saliva. I could even see it in front of me.

I loathed the story almost completely. Resented every aspect of the modern levels. Not a fan of this Alucard either apart from purely visual perspective. He even retconned the story from the first game in a pretty stupid way. I bought this at full price day one. I did not listen to reviews. If you think you want this game, re-evaluate, come back after a week or so and if you still want this game... wait for a steamsale, no sense of wasting more money than you have to.

reviewText:
It's a big improvement of the first game. No doubt about that. Also I would love to like this game but it's decent at best. I'm pretty sure they made it as irritating as they could. I'm going to list the MAJOR grievances I have with this game.

EXAMPLE: At one point in the game, you have to ride an elevator. So you kill a bunch of enemies and go to the elevator to find out it has no power. Then you go back to the entrance and start the generator. All enemies respawn and you kill them again. When you're finally at the elevator there's still no power since the generator has a timer >: ( So back to the entrance again and start the generator AGAIN! Then back to the elavator a final third time. Frustrates me to no end.

reviewText:
Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 is an action-adventure game, the sequel to the 2010 game Castlevania: Lords of Shadow, and the 34th installment in the Castlevania franchise (37th if one includes the 3 Pachislot games). The game was developed by MercurySteam and published by Konami. It was released late February 2014 in both North America and Europe and on March 2014 in Australia. A Japanese release was released on September 4, 2014. A downloadable chapter has also been released in March from the same year.

Gameplay
As in the previous game, the player controls Gabriel Belmont, now known as Dracula, as he fights through an open world. During the game's opening sequence the player is able to control Dracula while he still possesses all his powers as well as all of his weapons. Dracula's main weapon is his Shadow Whip, a weapon that is comparable to the Combat Cross from the original Lords of Shadow. Replacing the magic system from the previous game are the Void Sword and the Chaos Claws. The Void Sword can replenish Dracula's health when used while the Chaos Claws can be used to break through enemy defenses and deliver powerful attacks. The story mode in Lords of Shadow 2 has been stated to be far longer than the previous one. The game is mainly an open world allowing the player to choose what route to take. Lords of Shadow 2 features a movable camera, something that was not available in its predecessor.

My opinion
The game is fun, but it's optimized poorely. The controls with keyboard are pain in the ♥♥♥♥ and FPS drops make it even more worse and PLUS horrible stealth mechanic ruins most of the fun. I fixed of the problems by using Razer Onza controller. This game has a good plot which I don't want to spoil, but if you're unfamiliar with the previous game- don't worry, there's a short re-cap in the start of the game.  The slasher elements make the gameplay live and interesting and the level up system doesn't award those who use only one combo, which makes you use different variations of attacks. The game is great for the money that are asked for it.

Would recommend to:
*Fans of Slashers
*Fans of Vampires
*Fans of games with great story
*Fans of lags/horrible controlls/bad stealth

Would not recommend to:
*Old fans of Castlevania (Way before the first Lords of Shadow was released)

reviewText:
Highly recommended.  Extremely underrated by gaming websites who have taken a myopic view of the game. Just check the user metacritic/steam reviews which you'll find overwhelmingly positive.

Pros:-
* Gorgeous art style with large and stunning vistas - IMO the biggest draw of the LOS series.
* Combat is fluid and satisfying with great variety in combos/powers/special moves
* Presentation is top-notch. Right from voice acting to cutscenes the game is very polished
* High quality orchestral music. A bit understated, but sets an epic ambience nonetheless.
* Misc-  Great boss battles /decent in-game lore/some very creative sections (eg: toymaker)

Cons:-
* Flow of the game is often interrupted with excessive camera cues/ superflous cutscenes/etc. To be fair this happens less as the game progresses though.
* Stealth sections albeit few, are insipid. Particularly annoying are the Golgoth guard sections where the mighty Dracula is rendered powerless and has to solve uninspired puzzles to progress further in the game. IMO the other stealth sections (incudling the widely derided Carmilla/Agreus ones) were actually pretty decent.
* The story is inconsistent, some parts are evocative and well done, while others just don't add up. There's often a sense of confusion and dissonance in the plot.

reviewText:
Interesting game with many Pros and Cons.
BLUF: Recomended IF you wait for a Steam Sale/game patching.

Heres what I found to be the best and worst of the game, in order of presedence.


Positives

Good story line
Very good visuals, particularily the scenery (it seemed this is where they put their most effort into.)
Fluid, responcive, satisfying combat. Completley reminicent to the God Of War series.
Good characters/voice acting. I personally enjoyed watching all of the cut scenes.
Partialy destructable enviornment. Cans clutter and such.
Challenging boss fights.


Negitives

It wants you to play with a game pad. The game does not seem to be designed for a mouse and keyboard. Every Single Time there is a quick time event the UI will come up telling you to spam things like the left trigger to an Xbox controller. Made me have to consult the key mapping way way too often.
Claims to be partly open world when it really is not. You get to revisit previously traveled to destinations. Mainly rooms and hallways in a completley linear path.
Dracula does not act like Dracula. You find yourself with menial tasks, and small obsticals that make little sence. You're supposed to be the Prince of Darkness.. Satan is concerned with how powerful you are.. but hold on I have to run down stairs to turn on a power switch to activate an elevator to go to the next floor. Tell me that's somthing a Vampire Lord would do.
Silly stealth sections. Again, knowing forwell that Satan fears you, you decide to morph into a rat and sneak around a guard or two, here and there. Must be one hell of a guard.  Insta kill if they find you btw. On that note, you never face them in open combat.
Invisible walls. If a spot is not game essential, you're not going there. Don't expect an Assassins Creed style of play here.
The game holds your hand the whole way through. The camera will usualy show you exactly where you need to go, how to get there, and have either a glowy thing waiting for you or a char shouting to you with explanations. Yet, some parts you just havent the foggiest bit of a hint of where to go.
Low replay value. There are elements present to keep you busy after the main story is over, however I can't see entertainment value lasting with that; or starting a new save; albite there are always diffrent difficulty levels if you're into that.
The only way to die in this game is in a giant explosion of blood. The enemies almost always blow up, or burst into blood. I think that greatly takes away from the feel of it.
Another game that likes to kill off just about everyone. You catch onto the trend of: Oh a new guy. Guess he's the next boss..  but this ones my opinion, maybe you just like all that murder.



One list seems to be bigger than the other. Hrm.

So to wrap up, The game has a solid foundation, and is fun; 15 ish+ hours gameplay. However there are some problems that sound like somebody put money over quality. I may have been nitpicking but this is a $60.00 game, and theres another $10.00 or so worth of DLC.
Nothing is perfect, but if you're going to put somthing out at full price don't do it half ♥♥♥♥♥. Regrettably, that seems to be what this is. They came so close but just didn't go all the way.

As I said up top; Sure I'll recomend this title.. but not right now. This is somthing that you will enjoy playing, but not with the current pricetag/greavences.


P.S.
Is it just me or do the DLC costumes just look like a recolored version of what he's already wearing??

reviewText:
Don't listen to the bad reviews. I was looking forward to this game ever since the first trailer came out on the E3 2012, so I can say that I pretty much had high standards for it.

I was a bit afraid that MercurySteam won't be able to exceed my expectations, but I am happy to say that they did. The graphics look great, much better, than, for example, the new Thief's graphics imo, and don't forget that this game wasn't even made for the so called next-gen consoles. Sure, lot's of critics say that the modern day-chapters don't look as good, and the lot of grey metal becomes boring over time, but I think that that's exactly the point. And the reason is that Dracula is a very complex character, the best one created in a long time, he lost everything, his love, faith, son, etc, and that's what even the modern setting implies: if you compare Dracula's castle in the past with the city that is built upon it in the present, you can also see that he even lost the home he had had for centuries. His castle became barren, empty, just like he himself. Maybe I overinterpret things, but I still think it's a great metaphor.
The music is awesome, seriously, while I was playing, there were times when I just stopped moving around because I wanted to listen to the music till the end.
Gameplay's also great. Sure, Castlevania includes elements from the God of War and Devil May Cry series, but it combines the best elements of these games, so players really have nothing to complain about.

So all in all, I can recommend this game for everyone who looks for an intensive hack 'n' slash with a great and complex story with unexpected twists. Oh, and btw: Dracula is a badass! :D

reviewText:
Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 has polarized its' audience upon release: while the game is mostly well received by the gamers, it's has been a subject to negative criticism by the game media.
So is Lords of Shadow 2 a worthy sequel?
There has been some changes since the prequel, some for the worse and some for the better.
Lords of Shadow 2's core element is the combat which is very smooth and features a free movement camera. Gameplay wise the arcadish mission selection approach has been replaced by an open world with transitions from the present, modern age  to the medieval ages.
There's also a stealth mechanics introduced in the sequel, which is largely criticized by many people.
But is this new feature really THAT bad? I think not, while it certainly breaks the pace of the game, the number and difficulty of these segments are LOW, that it shouldn't bother many people. And certainly not a reason not to play the game because of these parts.

That being said, this game is a very solid and entertaining entry in the franchise, which also concludes the Lords of Shadow trilogy!

PROS:
- Graphics are gorgeous, and performance wise the game is very well optimized!
- Soundtrack is excellent, and so is the voice acting!
- The game design also well done in Lords of Shadow 2. This includes the architecture, level, creature and boss designs.
- Combat is easier, than Lords of Shadow 1, but still very satisfying.
- Boss fights are easier than Lords of Shadow 1, but at the same time very entertainining.
- Platforming segments are more fluent this time.
- Lot's of content and collectibles providing huge replay value.

NOT PRO, BUT NOT CON EITHER:
- Due to the newly introduced open world approach, the arcadish level selection feature is gone in Lords of Shadow 2. This means boss fights cannot be replayed, unless you start a new game!

CONS:
- While the story is good, the story-telling is not so coherent as it was in the last game.
- Some characters weren't introduced properly (lack of screentime)
- Xbox button prompts, and console HUD. This wasn't an issue in the prequel, so there's no excuse here!
- The difficulty decreased signifantly in all aspects. This includes platforming, combat and boss fights as well.
- Puzzle elements were mostly removed from Lords of Shadow 2. It's a pity, the prequel had some nice puzzles.

reviewText:
Castelvania: Lords of Shadow 2 is a wonderful ride from start to finish, with very few road bumps along the way. If you're a fan of action games, exploration games, or loved the first Lords of Shadow, there is plenty here to be happy about. However, if you were NOT a fan of the first game, there is little reinventing of the wheel here to pull you into the franchise.

Gameplay: 8/10

The exploration from the modern areas to the realm of Dracula's Castle is fluid. Dracula moves very intuitively, response time is great, and once the game really starts to open up its areas you really get this sense of a large scale fluid world. The negative here would be the platforming, or lack there of. Platforming in LOS2 is mostly just wall climbing from grapple to grapple. It can feel a little dull at times.

Combat: 9/10

The combat system from the first Lords of Shadow returns, but with a HUGE overhaul. It has been streamlined to perfection in almost every area. The pace at unlocking skills feels perfect, the variety of Dracula's weapons is interesting enough to keep combat feeling fresh, and the combinations of moves Dracula can perform make combat easily the most enjoyable experience of LOS2.

Story: 8/10

Continuing where LOS1's ending left off, the story of LOS2 is a great epic. There are moments in the story that had me jaw drop, the highs are fantastically done. However, there are low points. There are a few twists that you can see happening a mile away that occur, and there are two specific points in the story that really bring down the overall score. Without spoiling for those who haven't played, the two negatives I attribute to story are in the case of a character being VASTLY underused, and the game's ending.

Music: 9/10

It's awesome. Orchestral awesomeness. The somber tones, the high symphonies, everything. It's not classic Castlevania, but it deserves praise all its own.

Graphics (PC): 8/10

Even if there is occasional tearing and the odd lightning hear and there, LOS2 is very pleasing to look at. The game looks great.

Other notes: As many have read, there are *stealth* sections in this game. I am not even going to dignify them to allow a drop in score, because they are NOT broken, NOR are they impossible. They slightly disrupt the flow of the game in some parts, but if you utilize ALL of your abilities (Shadow Daggers, Bats, Mist form, Possession) and use your brain, these sections are laughably easy. The most infamous response to these sections have been from Kotaku, who's reviewer got stuck on one particular section for FOUR hours. I completed the same section in less than two minutes. Use your abilities, and these sections are trivial.

Overall: 8.75/10

LOS2 is a great game that is sadly being underplayed by major media sources. It is NOT game of the year, sure, but this is a solid title that can stand on its own and a wonderful edition to the Castlevania franchise. Mercury Steam should be proud of LOS2, because they made a good game. I enjoyed my 14 hour playthrough, and will continue to play it for 100% and achievements.

reviewText:
If you're reading this review, you've probably played the original Castlevania: Lords of Shadow. If not, go check out that game first before you buy LoS 2, since this game relies VERY heavily on the backstory from the original LoS.

For those of you who have played the original LoS and finished the game, your next question is probably going to be: how does LoS 2 compare to the original?

I was a very big fan of the original LoS, and my review of that game gave it a 9 on 10, with high praise for its beautiful landscapes and art direction, for its incredible musical soundtrack, its professional voice acting, and for its ambition in telling the origin story of Castlevania. I felt its weak points were the holes in the story that sometimes just didn't make any sense, and the odd puzzles that forced you into a puzzle menu to play the associated minigame.

LoS 2 retains all of the things that I felt made LoS a wonderful work of art, and also retains the higher resolution graphic textures that are unique to the PC version. It still runs easily at 120 fps for those who are using 120hz monitors and want to lock the VSync to the refresh. No screen tearing, no artifacts, just beauty. But be sure to disable the motion blur in the graphic settings (setting it to LOW is 100% disabled).

The game looks stunning, the backdrops and scenery are jaw-dropping, the animation is superb and flows like water. New weapons in the game have their own detailed animations and combos, and open up a whole new God of War-like variation to weapon variety that wasn't present in the first LoS. The music is modernized but retains the original LoS theme throughout many of the compositions, keeping true to the original soundtrack (the composer is the same as the original LoS, so he knows exactly how to bring back variations on the old tunes).

If you were a fan of the original, then I strongly recommend buying this game. In my opinion, this game is as good as the original, if not better in a number of ways. It isn't just a brand new story slapped on top of the old one, but rather it builds entirely on the story from the first LoS and gives it a full tribute in everything that it does. It is a very worthy sequel to the original game.

As a final score, I give Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 a rating of 9 on 10.  The only reason it did not score a 10 on 10 was due to the introduction of a new stealth mechanic that wasn't entirely fleshed out enough. Thankfully it isn't used that frequently, but it can get frustrating when you're in the mood to kick ♥♥♥ and you're forced into a medicore stealth mode.

I'd also like to thank Mercurysteam and Konami for releasing this game on PC, and for releasing it at the same time as their Console launches! They have shown us PC gamers a great deal of respect. Thank you!

reviewText:
In my opinion, most of the video reviews I came across don't give this game the credit it deserves. In a sentence, this is an excellent third person action game, with very nice and enjoyable combat mechanics, which is what matters to me most in this kind of games.

Once you get a good feeling of the combat system (might take a while though), defeating hordes of enemies becomes very satisfying. Comparing it to the benchmark -in my opinion- of the category Batman Arkham City/Origins, you don't get to feel as invincible as Batman (although you're supposed to be even more badass), but the combinations and the options you have in the battle are more engaging.

Most of the critics seem to point out how it is unfit for Dracula to be in a modern era context. Some others seem to dislike the story ending. Let me say that, although this is my first Castlevania game (since the original one on SNES :P ) and I didn't follow the earlier episodes, the story seemed to me to be brilliantly scripted, especially due to its clever ending (no spoilers), where everything is explained.

If you are like me and are searching for a third person action game in the style of Batman Arkham series, where nice combat mechanics is your priority, then I think this is a game you will enjoy.

reviewText:
I'm going to start by saying that my overall experience with this game is more positive than negative. While there are a few issues that detract from the overall experience, they are not serious enough for me to not recommend the game. Some key points follow.

The combat system is an evolution of the one in the first game, with significant refinements that make for a very smooth experience. For example, you can dodge and parry attacks even in the air. While the skill trees for each of the weapons may seem labyrinthine at first, if you put some thought into how they're structured and how each of the moves are executed, you'll start to realize how elegantly designed Dracula's moveset is. Gone are the difficult-to-execute combos in the first Lords of Shadow; you now have a broad range of attacks that are easily performed with plenty of versatility for nearly any combat situation.
Setting and environmental design is generally excellent. Both in the castle and in the city, there's a great sense of scale, and the level of detail put into the environment is absolutely incredible. Overall, it's designed in the open-world Metroidvania" tradition

Lords of Shadow and Mirrors of Fate are amazing games and couldn't be different with Lords of Shadow 2.
Even with some skills very likely when we played as Gabriel Belmont (in Lords of Shadow); play as Dracula is a totally new and excited world. Using his Void Sword, Shadow Whip and Chaos Claws to create powerful combos you'll become invencible, and in this point I have a negative opinion to say: I'm not sure if is because I played the first game and know how the combat system works, but I felt the game much easier, even when I was playing in Prince of Darkness difficult (except fora some Kleidos Challenges - they made a great work in those challenges).
They made a open world game this time and they made great in my opinion. Was amazing when I started to play and everything was...normal and as long I kept playing I could see the world changing around me.
The fights, and in this point I have to say, they improved A LOT from the first game. Each weapon (Sword, Whip and Claws) has a different movement's tree and I just loved to use all: freezing smallers enemies and throwing them in the air with my Sword, breaking some shields and armors with my Chaos Storm and finishing them with my Whip was simply awesome, after all he's now Dracul and not just a simple human.
Whitout no doubt a great game, not as much as the first one, but a great game. BUT like any game, this one has negative points too. Let's talk about bosses and enemies first.
We play as Dracula, but there isn't much fights to enjoy all our powers, and should have more since is an open world game AND (yes, I know we play in present days), but I felt a bit out of context when I needed to fight against Mech (like robots) and enemies with guns (WTF face that moment), like Dracul just dropped of in another world. And I didn't see those epics bosses fights as I saw when I played the first game. The bosses in my opinion were just normal enemies a bit bigger (except for four: SPOILER WARNING the fights against the two first acolytes, Zobek and Satan). You won't see an epic Titan or a dangerous Lord or some powerful Necromancer.
Well, even with some negatives points and some troubles (I'm not sure if was 'cause my computer or the game só I decided do note talk about them), I still recommend to everyone to play this awesome and beautiful game.

reviewText:
I have been a fan of this series since the first game was released on NES.
Although I liked the lore/story of the first Lord of Shadows a lot, I felt the first game was a little bloated with filler and lacked a strong third act.
Lords of Shadow 2 is a better game and sequel. I would highly recommend this to fans of the series. Unfortuantely, if you have not played the first Lords of Shadow the story is a continuation and will not make sense.

CONS: Too many skills and weapon upgrades that are not necessary. I used about four out of each set.
The transport system to teleport from each part of the city is far and inbetween.
Final boss was a little underwhelming.

reviewText:
8/10

Not the best action game you're ever going to play but definitely worth considering if you're a fan of the genre. Stealth parts nearly ruins it, but the sound/visual quality is very good compared to other games. Story makes virtually no sense compared to the first LOS but the combat system is well worth the purchase, a lot deeper than other games, and along with a lot of collectibles make it worth a second playthrough.  Plays similar to GOW for puzzles/platforming to compliment the fighting which isn't a bad thing since there isn't that many games like this on PC.

Like the first game though, took a lot of ideas from other games, but didn't really interograte them quite as well e.g. the pharmaceutical industry and the monsters; the failored light/shadow combat system (DMC), the stealth system (Dishonored), and the open exploration (Metroid-ish).

Ending was slightly disappointing. Just seemed that the whole story wasn't well thought out enough plot wise. The DLC is worth a look too if you liked the main game.

Doesnt deserve all the bad press it got, and definitely look forward to going through a second time with a better laptop to really indulge on the visuals. Difficulty has been nerved compared to the LOS.

reviewText:
As the sequel to Castlevania: Lords of Shadow, one of the most memorable games of 2010 I played. This game holds up very well and takes advantage of the modern setting it takes place in pretty well.

That said, it does have flaws, but the main thing is you are not getting a buggy game. I found no bugs, glitches, or problems while playing.

The stealth elements could have been handled better, considering Konami funded this you would think they have *someone* who knows a thing or two about that.

But for what it is worth, the few instances of stealth were handled better than I thought they could have been. I did not find myself confused too easily by some of the stealth sections. But they were, at first, problematic due to the fact that they seemed forced rather than a natural progression of things.

That aside the artwork for the game is awesome, yes, the modern city sections of Castlevania seem out of place. But that is not a flaw to me. Dracula's castle is not Castlevania. The city which is named as such, was built on and around Dracula's castle. So the design changes from running around a beautiful old castle and its environments. To an open city that looks nice, but is not as nice as the castle, is not such a bad thing.

I am not going to obsess over art direction when I want a game's story to make sense. And the story only makes complete sense once you are near the end of the game. At first I thought it was poor writing. But I suspect it was a bit of Play Mirror of Fate to get the full story/purchase our DLC.

Yes, I honestly feel that with the announcement of DLC. I think they *may* have cut story content just for the DLC. But everything comes together towards the end of the main game anyway.

The bosses are fun, the exploration is fun, generally speaking if you are on the fence about this and you played the original. You will LIKE the sequel. I personally love it, and love the way the game came together in the end in my opinion.
