reviewText:
I'm only 3 hours into the game, but so far I have enjoyed it.  Feels very God-of-War like, which isn't necessarily a bad thing.  Combat is fun although there's not much here that hasn't been done before.  Combat skill trees are present.

Exploration is fun as well despite not being truly open world, it's still fun to find hidden secrets.

They bring back staple items like the hourglass that can slow enemies' movements, etc.  That along with destructible things like candlesticks that hide experience points or other goodies keeps it feeling like Castlevania.

Not sure about the modern setting, but most of the environments don't reflect a modern look anyway, it still looks like dilapidated castles, etc. for the most part.

The graphics are not fantastic, particularly in the distance some of the meshes have very jagged outlines, even with settings maxed.  The lighting/shadows in cut scenes can also be pretty distracting.

Much has been made about the stealth aspect of the game, but I didn't find it overwhelmingly unpleasant, although it did make me itch to get back into the combat and exploration where the game shines.

Ultimately I'm glad I bought the game

reviewText:
This game improves upon everything they did in first game.  No more fixed camera, and there's a decent arsenal of subweapon to experiment with.  They way you level up weapons and techniques encourages variety in combat.  Unlike the first game the Light and Dark magic forms have their own weapons.  Void Sword and Chaos Claws once leveled up can be used long enough so you can experiment with them instead of just using them when you know you the extra health or damage.  Also since the game is open world it's much easier to backtrack and find secrets you may have missed on your first time through.  That was the biggest pain about LoS1 since you have replay an entire stage.  Though at least the chapters were divided up into multiple areas.

Hard to understand all the hate for this game, but I can understand some of it.  The story is a bit whacky, and the events that bridge the two games have their own 3DS game (which was ported to console and PC), but that game is really lackluster.  Kind of depressing since the summary they give in the beginning of this game is really interesting.  Almost wish that game would've been Lords of Shadow 2, then make this game Lords of Shadow 3.  My biggest complaint about the story is how they treated Victor Belmont.  I assume he's suppose to be Richter, but given that you meet him and 20 minutes later he sacrifices himself, I'm glad he's not Richter.  Really wish there was more of him in the game.

Environments in the present day segments are pretty dull.  No real variations in it, just greyed out industrial areas.  The other parts of the set Castlevania's past feel alive.  Definitely feels like the devs had fun making those areas.

Enemy designs also don't feel very varied either.  Boss design is on point though aside from the final boss.  *SPOILER WARNING* Final boss is Satan inside Alucard's body.  I was hoping for something a little more unique.  And since you only see Alucard for the last little section of the game (though technically he is there for the entire game disguised as the Zobek's second in command) it's disappointing that he's only there for that last little bit.

Speaking of Alucard.  his DLC is solid too.  It has actual cinemas unlike how the DLC for LoS1 was handled.  He doesn't have new weapons for the magic modes, but the DLC is just long enough you don't notice it.  The only disappointing thing about the DLC is Alucard doesn't have any attacks for his Bat Swarm or Spectral Wolf abilities in combat or with magic.  Would've been a nice touch.  Oh yeah, the actor that plays Rob Stark from Game of Thrones does his voice if you're wondering why he sounds familiar.

reviewText:
I completed the game and basically the game doesn't have a very good story (totally ignored other people complaints about this games story, thinking it couldn't be that bad)

Who could of pictured Dracula as a anti-hero, can i call him that? He comes off as bad but develops into a semi heroic character. I don't think developers will ever grasp the concept of being evil as a main character. If someone plays as a bad guy, he has to remain that way, i mean he/she has to be totally deprived of emotions and feelings. Dracula here has these and it basically takes away from the evil that the character is known for in the castlevania series. I'm content with saying he is basically a sissy compared to the Dracula in other Castlevania games. If i play as a evil bad guy, i want to bad all the way to the end.

The art direction i notice is down right horrible. The art direction on satan in particular is down right terrible. I think i could of design a better version of him thats not too similar to the bible depiction of him. The armor on a couple of particular characters, dracula included are pretty much weird to me. They have the same similar design and shape, which consist of sharp wave like rig.

The combat is decent, but i just don't understand why the devs didn't add more skills to draculas default whip, they had room to. They could have even recycled some of gabriels whip skills from lord of shadows. While playing i kept thinking i could do one of my favorite skills from the first Lord Of Shadows but then reality hit..

Final battle could of been done better, instead they went for a semi-cliche kind of approach, which is expected in other games. If you're a castlevania fan, you'll expect a really cliche climatic Castlevania final battle, which isn't a bad thing. I guess these guys didn't play the castlevania games, when putting this one together.

If it was me i would of added a bit of fanservice to the game. I can say artwise, though the graphics are pretty good, the devs dropped the ball hard on this game. It's a ok game if you just want combat, decent boss battles, but dont expect a great blow your mind game experience.

reviewText:
I wanted to love this game. I really did. Don't buy it unless you have a morbid curiousity to see what happened after the very entertaining first game. If you haven't played the first, go buy that instead.

The first Lords of Shadow was an unexpected surprise for me, with gorgeous art and a fairly well told story backed up by solid action. Combined with a ridiculous twist and cliffhanger at the end, I was pretty excited to see where MercurySteam took the series next. On paper, it sounds pretty good. Expand the combat systems from the original game, continue the story, and place it in an open, Symphony of the Night style world that favors exploration.

Then they went and cocked it all up. The action is barely distinguishable from the first, despite the huge change in character. You now have subweapons, but they are essentially palette swaps of the default whip with the properties of either the light or dark magic from the first game.

The story is hilariously badly written, and at times borders on nonsensical. Character motivations frequently are completely impenetrable and illogical, and the ending of the game provides very little closure. The first thing that you see when the credits roll is that one man 'wrote and directed' the game. If I were him, I certainly wouldn't take credit for this wet fart of a story for fear of the death of my career.

Classic metroidvania backtracking and openness is a great idea, but the biggest problem is that the map system is absolutely not up to the task. Modern metroidvanias like Shadow Complex frequently combine the classic 'grid' style map with indicators of an item that you have seen but were not able to access. LoS2 has a woefully inadequate 'world map' that is simply the names of different areas with the number of secrets you have yet to access. With all the shortcuts, twists and exits in each area, neither the world map or the local map (that basically confines its view to the loaded in level chunk with no indication of where exits go) is sufficient to make hunting for upgrades anything but a chore.

And then there are the infamous stealth sections. God, the stealth sections. I'm typically against the death penalty, but whoever added those to the design doc needs to be publically executed. I want to watch. There are apologists for them, saying that they're 'more of a puzzle' than a stealth section. That may be true, but they're still a really ♥♥♥♥♥♥, inconsistant puzzle, using mechanics that do not smoothly integrate into the game. If you thought the 'boat stealth' sections from ACIV were the worst in recent memory, boy do I have a surprise for you.

Alright, I've got that out of my system. Don't buy this for 60 bucks. Please don't.

reviewText:
This review is written after having played almost three hours of gameplay with intent to play more. It's also important to note that this is written from the point of view of someone who has not played any of the Castlevania's before Lord of Shadow (The first one.)

Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 thrusts you into the role of Gabriel Belmont (otherwise known as Dracula) who is disturbed from his centuries of rest to once again battle Satan. The game stands well on it's own and I feel like someone who hasn't played the first game can still pick up this one and not be confused as to what is going on. However, I also feel like if someone were to have played the first one they will enjoy the story a lot more than if they didn't. (This is easily remedied by reading a wikipedia summary or watching the cutscenes of the first game on youtube.)

The gameplay is reminiscent of Devil May Cry, Ninja Gaiden and other stylish action fighters. You do combos against multiple enemies and emphasis is placed on avoiding attacks to survive. Even the normal mode feels difficult because there is just so much going on and it's easy to lose track of enemies that end up behind you. However, the combos you can upgrade into feel almost pointless when you can just mash your single target attack, dodge and come out victorious. However, it also does some things good by giving your weapons meaning. The Void Blade restores health through attacks and the Chaos claws deal extra damage to enemies. Dodging attacks is essential because in order to use these weapons you need to build up a combo meter which allows blood orbs" to appear which gives power to the weapons.

Where Castlevania: LoS2 sets itself apart from Devil May Cry and Ninja Gaiden is in the platforming sections. With Devil May cry you time a bunch of jumps and with Ninja Gaiden you run across rooftops. With Castlevania it manages to execute a good platforming experience reminiscent of games like Prince of Persia. You'll scale up walls while under siege by enemies
date: time perfect jumps and use your abilities to reach hidden spots to power up Dracula.\n\nI also think it's worthwhile to note that if you dislike Quick Time Events(QTE)
recommended: there is an option to disable QTE's in the game menu. This is a huge step forward as a lot of gamers moan and gripe about having to "Press X to not die" and I hope to see this option more in the future in other games.\n\nOverall
hoursPlayed: if you liked Ninja Gaiden or Devil May Cry you'll find a similarly enjoyable experience in Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2."

reviewText:
Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 is the latest in the Castlevania franchise. This title is a hack and slash action oriented game that is not for the faint of heart. Those who dislike blood and gore are likely to turn away from this game, however those who like blood guts and gore can go nuts. Fans of Castlevania will appreciate this game to a point, however those new to the series may find things a little confusing.

For starters, the control system in the game is very fluid for the most part. Abilities can be used at will depending on the situation at hand. Swapping between the 3 weapons you get in the game is very smooth, switching from one to the other and back again at the touch of a button while keeping a combo going. The combat in general is smooth, however there are minor things that can be very disheartening for newer players. Unblockable attacks can be overlooked given the amount of things going on in a heated battle at times. For example, fights with a lot of dirt, rubble, blood and enemies flying everywhere can sometimes (not always) block your view from unblockable attacks meaning you are going to get hit. And in a life or death situation this is very annoying.

The difficulty of the game varies between 4 difficulties, 3 of which are available from the outset. The 4th difficulty is unlocked by beating the game once. A veteran of games from series like Devil May Cry will not find the initial hard mode" all that difficult. While it can be a challenge at times managing the players health and resources on hard
date: it isn't deathly hard. For newer players the easy and normal difficulties can provide their own challenge

reviewText:
The reviews online are correct, and wrong.

If you are a fan of Castlevania, or just enjoyed Lords of Shadow then you'll enjoy Lords of Shadow 2, but by god it will try to make you hate it.

The combat is excellent, carrying on from LoS, only complaint can be the spamming nature of small enemies with unblockable attacks, but as you progress you'll find ways of adapting to it.

Environments are goregeous, hands down the castle beats the modern settings, if DLC is planned, more more much more castle please!

The story is good, not great but good, but it really really needs the player to have played mirror of fate, please get it released on PC and added to this game as a free download for purchases.

Now onto the bad, stealth, the concept made sense at the start but every stealth section is a nightmare, whoever wanted this in the game had a good idea, abysmal execution. Fortunately the sections are short and not clustered but they are excrutiating. As an aside to the reviewers who are baffled by the rat concept, Dracula turns into rats in Bram Stoker's novel as a means of escape. Nice nod I thought.

If you're a fan of Castlevania, or enjoyed LoS, buy it. If not I'd say when it's on at least a 50% sale.

reviewText:
Somehow this game is even LESS like Castlevania than Lords of Shadow 1.

It's like Mercury Stream's objective was to cram in as many aspects from OTHER successful games as possible, hoping that by emulating them that they'd make a blockbuster. This game took a lot of chances by drastically distancing themselves from the traditional Castlevania formula and judging by the abysmal metacritic score, things didn't pan out for this game as the devs had hoped.

Dracula endures stealth segments like metal gear solid and at times transforms into a rat to covertly delve into enemy ground, very much like the morph ball from Metroid Prime. Also instead of a level select book like in the prequel we now have a psuedo open world to explore, like SotN. Beating up enemies is a 1:1 conversion from the previous game and the rockclimbing simulation aspect was reigned in just slightly.

I have a few gripes about this game. Though the overhead map in the corner ensured I'd not be lost for very long, I still managed to get stuck in several rooms scratching my head hoplessly trying to figure out what to do or pick up to continue. Eventually I'd stumble upon whichever asanine detail of the room I had missed in my multiple examinations.

This game's biggest shortcoming is the plot. The writers had an outline of what they wanted to have the main character do and feel, and while they try to explain his motivation the game just feels full of holes.

This game is like a delicious recipie with some fresh ingredients, but the chef forgot to stir the pot as it was cooking so now the meal separated. Rather than blend together into one satisfying experience we have competing facets of gameplay (flavors) that seem to detract from one another.

I heard mercury stream had a lot of problems. Maybe if the people running the company paid their employees and stopped enforcing their asanine and uninspired ideas over the people who had experience making games then this game would have been better recieved.

As it is only TWO people on my ~200 friend list have bought your game and BOTH dropped it more than halfway through.

Despite all this game's shortcomings it has plenty to offer and overall I enjoyed playing it.

reviewText:
Lords of Shadow 2 continues where Lords of Shadow left off, almost literally, with an aged Dracula awakening during modern times, weakened and missing his memories from the past thousand years or so. Soon, Zobek comes to Dracula and informs him that Satan is preparing to return. Zobek offers Dracula eternal rest in return for destroying Satan’s acolytes, thus preventing Satan return. With the two coming to an agreement, Dracula sets out to recover his full power and prevent the return of Satan.

As one of its strongest aspects, Lords of Shadow 2 expands on the excellent combat system from the original Lords of Shadow. Many of Dracula’s combat moves are very similar to those used in LoS, this time with a vampiric twist. Instead of the Combat Cross Dracula wields whips made from his own demonic blood. Instead of the light and chaos magic from the first game, Dracula has the Void Sword and Chaos Claws. The Void Sword can restore Dracula’s health with each successive hit, while the Chaos Claws increase the Dracula’s combat strength. Similar to the magic system from LoS, both the Void Sword and the Chaos Cross have their own pool of magic which can be restored by chaining combos, which drops magic orbs.
Chaining combos is not as easy as it sounds however, as even the weakest enemies have ranged attacks, as well as strong unblockable attacks. Thankfully, Dracula’s dodge and parry will mostly keep the player safe as long as they are mindful of enemy patterns. Lords of Shadow 2, like Lords of Shadow before it, shows the player no mercy when they fail to dodge or parry an attack. In fact, even with some of the weakest enemies, a failed dodge can mean getting hit by a string of unblockable attacks until the enemies combos are over. This can lead to a somewhat abrupt death if the player does not manage to restore Dracula’s health immediately.

Combat does feel more forgiving in Lords of Shadow 2 this time around, however. For one, checkpoints are more frequent and areas before large fights generally have an artifacts which allow Dracula to recharge his health and magic before heading into the fray. Helping to make things easier this time, secondary combat items such as daggers no longer require collection and instead recharge after a few seconds. There are also a host of consumable items in LoS2 that do everything from restore health and make attacks stronger to slow down time and give unlimited magic. These items make the difficulty curve in Lords of Shadow 2 feel more manageable, despite its sometimes unforgiving combat.

Unfortunately, the game is not always about its fantastic combat system. Sometimes, the game slows to a crawl as Dracula is forced to use stealth to proceed. These segments see Dracula using some of his abilities such as possession, rat transformation, and bat swarm to progress. At first, the stealth segments make sense as Dracula is weak and needs to possess either scientists or cyborgs to progress. As Dracula recovers his powers however, it becomes unclear why he is forced to sneak about. Dracula can destroy one of Satan’s acolytes but is unfit to face a simple cyborg? It makes little sense.
One particular stealth segment towards the middle of the game is particularly frustrating. Dracula is forced to sneak about a maze full of dry leaves as a boss actively hunts for him. If the boss hears Dracula step on the leaves, the boss finds Dracula and forces him back to the start of the maze, taking a portion of the player’s health. This is made worse by the boss actively pursuing Dracula regardless of the noise made, sending Dracula back to the start if he simply comes into line of sight. The segment is made all the more insulting since Dracula and the said boss fight almost immediately following the maze. What was the point of the maze at all? Why did Dracula run if he could simply stand and fight?

Some of the frustrations involved with Lords of Shadows 2 also stem from what should have been its greatest strength: the open world. Without spoiling too much, the game basically revolved around two semi-open worlds: the city and Dracula’s castle. The game looks beautiful and the levels are mostly well designed, but the navigation map struggles to keep up. Sometimes the player is left with nothing more than a vague arrow pointing somewhere off-screen. I found myself several times wandering in circles only to discover a small ledge I strained to see or a far off switch I was supposed to hit with a dagger. These moments can be frustrating, and may be played off as exploration/puzzles but mostly just feel like poor design.

In regards to puzzles, LoS2 is a little bit disappointing. While the volume of puzzles seems to have increased significantly from the previous entries, the quality seems to have gone down. Most of the puzzles boil down to pull this switch/use that power. Rarely do the puzzles reach the height of those in the original Lords of Shadow, if at all.

That’s not to say the game doesn’t have its inspired moments though. Part way into the game, Dracula unlocks optional arena style challenges where the player can put Dracula’s powers to the test. These can be a lot of fun and test the player’s skill by doing such things as banning the use of a specific power or setting a time limit to kill enemies.

There are also moments where the game shines creatively such as a first person feeding segment, some clever sliding puzzles, and an interactive play. Equally enjoyable are several segments in the game where Dracula fights with a companion at his side. Dracula may be required to work with his companion to platform past obstacles or to solve puzzles, which really feels great. These moments are too few and far between, unfortunately.

On the more positive end of things, the boss fights in Lords of Shadow 2 are actually an improvement on Lords of Shadow and seems to take a page from Mirror of Fate. The fights feel more epic, with larger bosses, and fewer quick time events.  The QTE are mostly limited to escape animations but are sometimes used for boss finishers. Wisely, Mercury Stream has provided checkpoints before boss finishers which makes the QTE less frustrating. Wiser still, you can turn off QTE entirely if you so choose. With boss fights less reliant on QTE, the game flows a lot better, and it gives the player more of a sense of involvement during boss fights.

As someone who actually enjoys the Lords of Shadow universe, I felt slightly let down by its supposed conclusion. While the ending was satisfying enough, it felt a bit abrupt and unexpected. The story also pays almost no attention to the events of Lords of Shadow, only vaguely referring to the game’s events. Instead, the game focuses more on events from Mirror of Fate. This combined with the sudden demise of some key characters and a lack of explanation regarding how the player comes to arrive at Dracula’s castle, make the story feel unrealized at times. This is further compounded by an ending that doesn’t necessarily feel appropriate for the series, especially given the general direction of the entire game’s story and portrayal of Dracula throughout.

As the player progresses through Lords of Shadow 2, they see Dracula coming to terms with the monster that he has become - how becoming Dracula has affected him, his family, and the world around him. Unfortunately, that character progression just doesn’t live up to the ultimate ending, leaving loose ends right at the moment that it seemed everything was going to be tied up.

Overall, Lords of Shadow 2 was an enjoyable experience despite some questionable gameplay additions and a lackluster ending. There’s a lot of content to Lords of Shadow 2 and a lot of fun to be had, including a New Game+ mode. Hopefully the upcoming Alucard DLC just ties up some of the loose ends that LoS2 left unraveled.

reviewText:
Lords of Shadow 2 continues where Lords of Shadow left off, almost literally, with an aged Dracula awakening during modern times, weakened and missing his memories from the past thousand years or so. Soon, Zobek comes to Dracula and informs him that Satan is preparing to return. Zobek offers Dracula eternal rest in return for destroying Satan’s acolytes, thus preventing Satan return. With the two coming to an agreement, Dracula sets out to recover his full power and prevent the return of Satan.

As one of its strongest aspects, Lords of Shadow 2 expands on the excellent combat system from the original Lords of Shadow. Many of Dracula’s combat moves are very similar to those used in LoS, this time with a vampiric twist. Instead of the Combat Cross Dracula wields whips made from his own demonic blood. Instead of the light and chaos magic from the first game, Dracula has the Void Sword and Chaos Claws. The Void Sword can restore Dracula’s health with each successive hit, while the Chaos Claws increase the Dracula’s combat strength. Similar to the magic system from LoS, both the Void Sword and the Chaos Cross have their own pool of magic which can be restored by chaining combos, which drops magic orbs.
Chaining combos is not as easy as it sounds however, as even the weakest enemies have ranged attacks, as well as strong unblockable attacks. Thankfully, Dracula’s dodge and parry will mostly keep the player safe as long as they are mindful of enemy patterns. Lords of Shadow 2, like Lords of Shadow before it, shows the player no mercy when they fail to dodge or parry an attack. In fact, even with some of the weakest enemies, a failed dodge can mean getting hit by a string of unblockable attacks until the enemies combos are over. This can lead to a somewhat abrupt death if the player does not manage to restore Dracula’s health immediately.

Combat does feel more forgiving in Lords of Shadow 2 this time around, however. For one, checkpoints are more frequent and areas before large fights generally have an artifacts which allow Dracula to recharge his health and magic before heading into the fray. Helping to make things easier this time, secondary combat items such as daggers no longer require collection and instead recharge after a few seconds. There are also a host of consumable items in LoS2 that do everything from restore health and make attacks stronger to slow down time and give unlimited magic. These items make the difficulty curve in Lords of Shadow 2 feel more manageable, despite its sometimes unforgiving combat.

Unfortunately, the game is not always about its fantastic combat system. Sometimes, the game slows to a crawl as Dracula is forced to use stealth to proceed. These segments see Dracula using some of his abilities such as possession, rat transformation, and bat swarm to progress. At first, the stealth segments make sense as Dracula is weak and needs to possess either scientists or cyborgs to progress. As Dracula recovers his powers however, it becomes unclear why he is forced to sneak about. Dracula can destroy one of Satan’s acolytes but is unfit to face a simple cyborg? It makes little sense.
One particular stealth segment towards the middle of the game is particularly frustrating. Dracula is forced to sneak about a maze full of dry leaves as a boss actively hunts for him. If the boss hears Dracula step on the leaves, the boss finds Dracula and forces him back to the start of the maze, taking a portion of the player’s health. This is made worse by the boss actively pursuing Dracula regardless of the noise made, sending Dracula back to the start if he simply comes into line of sight. The segment is made all the more insulting since Dracula and the said boss fight almost immediately following the maze. What was the point of the maze at all? Why did Dracula run if he could simply stand and fight?

Some of the frustrations involved with Lords of Shadows 2 also stem from what should have been its greatest strength: the open world. Without spoiling too much, the game basically revolved around two semi-open worlds: the city and Dracula’s castle. The game looks beautiful and the levels are mostly well designed, but the navigation map struggles to keep up. Sometimes the player is left with nothing more than a vague arrow pointing somewhere off-screen. I found myself several times wandering in circles only to discover a small ledge I strained to see or a far off switch I was supposed to hit with a dagger. These moments can be frustrating, and may be played off as exploration/puzzles but mostly just feel like poor design.

In regards to puzzles, LoS2 is a little bit disappointing. While the volume of puzzles seems to have increased significantly from the previous entries, the quality seems to have gone down. Most of the puzzles boil down to pull this switch/use that power. Rarely do the puzzles reach the height of those in the original Lords of Shadow, if at all.

That’s not to say the game doesn’t have its inspired moments though. Part way into the game, Dracula unlocks optional arena style challenges where the player can put Dracula’s powers to the test. These can be a lot of fun and test the player’s skill by doing such things as banning the use of a specific power or setting a time limit to kill enemies.

There are also moments where the game shines creatively such as a first person feeding segment, some clever sliding puzzles, and an interactive play. Equally enjoyable are several segments in the game where Dracula fights with a companion at his side. Dracula may be required to work with his companion to platform past obstacles or to solve puzzles, which really feels great. These moments are too few and far between, unfortunately.

On the more positive end of things, the boss fights in Lords of Shadow 2 are actually an improvement on Lords of Shadow and seems to take a page from Mirror of Fate. The fights feel more epic, with larger bosses, and fewer quick time events.  The QTE are mostly limited to escape animations but are sometimes used for boss finishers. Wisely, Mercury Stream has provided checkpoints before boss finishers which makes the QTE less frustrating. Wiser still, you can turn off QTE entirely if you so choose. With boss fights less reliant on QTE, the game flows a lot better, and it gives the player more of a sense of involvement during boss fights.

As someone who actually enjoys the Lords of Shadow universe, I felt slightly let down by its supposed conclusion. While the ending was satisfying enough, it felt a bit abrupt and unexpected. The story also pays almost no attention to the events of Lords of Shadow, only vaguely referring to the game’s events. Instead, the game focuses more on events from Mirror of Fate. This combined with the sudden demise of some key characters and a lack of explanation regarding how the player comes to arrive at Dracula’s castle, make the story feel unrealized at times. This is further compounded by an ending that doesn’t necessarily feel appropriate for the series, especially given the general direction of the entire game’s story and portrayal of Dracula throughout.

As the player progresses through Lords of Shadow 2, they see Dracula coming to terms with the monster that he has become - how becoming Dracula has affected him, his family, and the world around him. Unfortunately, that character progression just doesn’t live up to the ultimate ending, leaving loose ends right at the moment that it seemed everything was going to be tied up.

Overall, Lords of Shadow 2 was an enjoyable experience despite some questionable gameplay additions and a lackluster ending. There’s a lot of content to Lords of Shadow 2 and a lot of fun to be had, including a New Game+ mode. Hopefully the upcoming Alucard DLC just ties up some of the loose ends that LoS2 left unraveled.

reviewText:
LoS2 is a game that I found myself pretty hyped for. The downfall of this sequel, however, is that it doesn't even favorably stack up to its predecessor.

LoS2 has improved primary combat from the first game. The Void Sword and Chaos Claw mechanics feel distinctly unique from the main whip weapon, but unfortunately they do not really feel different from each other, except for the range of attacks and the focus on healing and damage. The Claws and the Sword have the same base combos as the whip, and while they offer more options once you learn the available skills, it still feels like the game is played largely the same regardless of which weapon you have equipped. The ability to dodge into enemies to interrupt some attacks, as well as dodging vertically or block from an aerial position, are welcome. It would still be nice for the dodge to have some window of invulnerability, for the cases where the camera is not being nice and you are unable to exactly avoid a tracking charge move or the like. Speaking of, the camera assist does seem to be helpful, but at the same time there are a few instances where I find myself needing to find the center of the room just so that I could get situated again with the camera and enemy placement.

Overall, the combat is the only real improvement that the sequel provides, and everything else changes for the worse. The story starts off really interesting, but nose dives quickly. Zobek is the game's instant chaperon, declaring to Dracula what needs to be done and why. This is kind of an instant turn off. The idea that Dracula has become an errand boy" for a man who has deceived him in the past is a bit silly. Story threads seems half-baked

reviewText:
It's games like this that really make me wish Steam has 3 recommendation buttons: thumbs up / thumbs down / apathetic shrug. Because LOS 2 is far from the great game the first one was, but also isn't totally crap - I'd say it's about 60/40 on the quality divide.

If you played LOS 1 you'll recall it finished with a gob smacking reveal - that had me extremely curious as to how the developers would follow up on this audacious twist. As it turns out - not particularly well. It's a beat em up platformer just like the first, but in this case the camera is moveable - which makes a big, and unwelcome, difference as it is slightly too far out to see the action, and also gets obscured by the ridiculous amount of special effects that happen with EVERY attack.

The game begins back in ye olde days with Dracula's castle being attacked by a giant robot that looks like a building. At first I was like WTF  is that?? because it looks utterly stupid - until I remembered the Titans from LOS 1: those majestic towering elemental creatures that were so impressive. Well, this is one of those - except it's been put through the moronometer, and come out with totally dumb design. Technically impressive for sure, but so NOT Castlevania!

If you hated the liberties the first game took with the series design - you'll be frothing at the mouth over this one....and I'd probably best not mention it gets even worse when the game jumps back to the present day, because those bits will  likely cause your brain to explode in disgust. They annoyed me, and I wasn't bothered by LOS 1's changes.

In the modern day bits you begin by traipsing through a pharmaceutical warehouse, beating up crates and plastic barrels - but not the enemies because you are too weedy after starving yourself of blood for hundreds of years. Yet there's a cutscene where Dracula gleefully murders a family of three - kid included - to regain some of his strength, and to show you how EVIL he has become...err, okay ...not really selling it so far (mainly due to Robert Carlylse's utterly ♥♥♥♥ performance), but whatevs!

Anyway, because you've become a total wimp  the first enemies you face have an enforced stealth aspect, which is pretty basic - and by the way, said enemies are big dudes in demonic armour with a gun bigger than you are.......Wot tha fudge?

Eventually you get through these dull encounters, and get sucked back into ye olde times - which thankfully are (a) much more enjoyable, and (b) less crap stylistically, though the first boss you face in this world isn't the greatest to look at. Duff them up, explore a bit more, and then...it's back to the crappy warehouse, traipse thru that some more, and it's back to ye olde world. The games a YOYO!!! Ye olde world =good, modern day=big bag'o'shito

Back in yon days of lore there's a bit with these creepy snake headed girls that's very....creepy, as they skitter about, and contort themselves in a fashion that really won't be doing their spine any favours. They're genuinely disturbing, yet at the same time it's such a pity the whole game seems incapable of maintaining the menace they exude.

The boss battle that precedes this bit has an awfully written cutscene, that's very japanese (even though the devs are spanish...) With an overtly sexual demonic villainess who laughs like a demented walrus, and then says you make her wet....yeeeessss, ok then. The bizarrest thing about all this - the first game had Hideo Kojima involved and wasn't this bad, this time around he was nowhere near this game and it's even more Hideo Kojimaesque than Hideo Kojima.

And, well, that's as far as I've got so far : that's an awful lot of crappy aspects for the first 3 or 4 hours of a game. There's still some enjoyment to be had with it, but it's a shadow of LOS's greatness and a horrendous treatment of Castlevania.
On the plus side - Patrick Stewart is much less awful this time around, so there's that. So, here goes - time to push the 'meh' recommend button, oh wait - there isn't one.

reviewText:
A game i waited over 3 years for, expecting a final epic battle against satan and his army in hell but what we got was a bunch of running around a city with crappy stealth sections and just a lack of varied enemies, with almost nothing related to the castlevania universe. Should mention that the tutorials are horrific in this game and leaves a bad first impression right there but other than those things, its a pretty decent game with good combat and somewhat fun exploring(when you go back in time ofc, to avoid those horrible city sections.) and the boss fights are quiet nice, most of them are really well designed and badass but also not too difficult. At its current price i find it hard to recommend this game, at least if you are a fan of the first Lords of Shadow game but when it drops down to 20-15€ then it would be worth the price and worth giving a shot. Quick round up the good thing and bad things of the game.

Pros:
+Really good looking graphics and runs really smooth with not a single framedrop
+Medieval era is awesome and looks fantastic
+Combat is great and fun
+The Orchestral music in the medieval areas and most boss fights are fantastic
Cons:
-The Orchestral music during the city sections are really bad
-Very few different kinds of enemies
-Story is mediocre
-Stealth is boring
-So is the whole city
-Characters this time around are not as interesting or memorable as the first game.

EDIT: Now that the DLC is out but cant be reviewed seperatley, i will just combine it with this.

The revelations DLC is a fantastic piece of content but still feels like it was cut from the main game just too make some extra cash.

So you play as Alucard this time to retrieve Draculas weapons for whats coming next for him when he  wakes up. Sounds simple and a bit boring but it was much better than i expected.

The big thing about this is NO STEALTH or CITIES, it only takes place in the castle and it looks amazing and has some nice puzzles and exploring the castle is fun.

Now how is it controlling Alucard? I find it awesome, he has a good variation of combat skills and his abillities are cool but they have no purpose in combat. Instead of having a different weapon like Dracula for his light and dark magic, he has a sword with light and dark magic which might sound a bit lame but its not, works really well and its not too hard to learn the combat skills.

Overall this is one of the best DLC's i have ever finished and definetly worth the money and makes the games story feel much more complete, its just a shame that this wasnt a part of the main game from the beginning.

Would easily recommend the main game and dlc if found for 30-50% off, unless you own the main game, then you should throw ur money in steam right now and buy the dlc.

reviewText:
After a little more than 15 hours of a rather painful experience, I've finally managed to plough through the boredom, frustration and dismay, feeling a great and lasting sadness when the credits finally rolled over, putting an end the whole agony.

A calamitous art direction:  Bland and repetitive backdrops (sewers, laboratory, castle, then more sewers), poor choice of a de-saturated almost monochromatic color palette (everything seems to be just another variation of grey), botched facial 3D renders (the characters' faces look like plastic with absolutely no emotional range, Dracula's face is particularly bad and almost laughable), uninspired character design (Nergal is just some random bald dude and Satan looks like a gym bro on steroids).

Incoherent game design:  Ridiculous mandatory and aggravating stealth (the 'Agreus' sequence is already famous all across internet, and that's not even talking about Dracula being forced to transform into a rat to avoid security guards that are stronger than Satan), exploration ruined by a archaic game structure and sub-par plat-forming (the wolf game mechanic breaks the rhythm and the climbing is either unclear or too easy with the pointers).

Mediocre sound design:  The only thing worth listening to is Dracula's theme at the title screen and a couple of action themes during the prologue, the rest being forgettable (compared to the first Lords of Shadow, this is a major let down), and the voice actors seem to be reading their lines more than they are giving it any kind of emotional depth (Robert Carlyle, Patrick Stewart and Richard Madden, shame on you ! You guys were so much better in previous games !).

A decent plot, completely destroyed by the worst appalling ending I've ever witnessed in a triple A game.  The story is actually interesting if you've completed both the first Lords of Shadow and Mirror of Fate (otherwise, don't even bother), but the grand finale and the game's ending is so embarrassingly insulting, it's actually a league of its own.

Combat mechanics are half-way decent, since it's basically a dumbed-down version of the first game (the game is much easier, thanks to a larger Synchronized Block window and an overpowered evade move, which knocks down and interrupts enemies), but let's not delude ourselves any longer and call this game what it is: shameful.

Objectively, it's not the worst piece of gaming ♥♥♥♥ this century, but unfortunately the first Lords of Shadow which was published 3 years before this sequel, is just way better in every possible way (yes, even the fixed camera which actually provided some cinematic flair).  As a fan of the first Lords of Shadow and having always argued about Mirror of Fate's qualities (still waiting for it on Steam), Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 has been such a disappointment it has made me depressed, disgusted and hateful.  And I don't play video games to be depressed, disgusted and hateful.  You have been warned.

reviewText:
I can't even explain how pumped I was for this game. I watched all the trailers over 30 times at least and got kinda obsessed over it, but then release day came. I started playing and it was a great game! Smooth combat which improves a lot over LoS 1. There are many moves for all weapon types and with each mastery level, the weapon's effectiveness improves. The enviroments are stunning (plus with the free camera, you can enjoy them more), and with the HD texture pack only available on PC, the games was absolutely amazing and showed what PC's can do that consoles can not. I enjoyed the game quite a lot infact, but the story did seem dumbed down, especially the ending (won't spoil it for you and besides, it's my opinion on the ending). The modern day city was refereshing, but got a bit boring after going through the same area's multiple times during many missions. The stealth mission's are not exactly as good was Splinter Cell, but they are alright in their own way. Characters in this one seemed a bit bland as well, even Alucard and Gabriel. The only part I enjoyed in terms of characters was the Carmilla part, other than that, the story was pretty dull in most areas. After all, Dave Cox did say that we were going to get an epic, emotional ending as well.

I'll just list pro's and con's on my view:

Pro's:
Great combat system! Way better than that of LoS 1.

Beautiful enviroments (just a bit repetitive).

Great QTE's for boss fights.

Soundtrack is absolutely one of the best I have ever heard in a video game!

The free-camera.

Pretty cool boss fights.

Con's:
The story was pretty bland compared to the first one.

Characters seemed to not be that interesting either (Except Alucard, Gabriel, Zobek, Marie, Carmilla and maybe Victor) Mainly the acolytes and Satan (Dave also stated we'd see how Satan progressed as a character. Didn't really see that at all).

Some enviroments are boring when you keep having to go through them all the time.

Not too many enemy types actually. I came across about 10-15.

Stealth isn't the best either.

The difficulty has been lowered down in this game as well compared to LoS 1.

Final Verdict for me:
Personally, I'd give it a 7 maybe 8/10. The ending wasn't all the good in my opinion, others may disagree. I think the game was pretty over-hyped, but most games are these days to be honest. I would definitely recommend buying this game, but don't expect as much a story as LoS 1. Combat was lovely though as well as the climbing buildings, wires and lamposts etc. I only ever got to use the dragon form once though (found it rare to find fragments of the medallion). Overall, if you loved the first one and MoF, get it! If you found LoS 1 and MoF a bit boring and bland, this game may not be for you then. I personally enjoyed 80% of it, but I feel that it will be another year or 6 months until I replay it.

reviewText:
I would highly recommend that you play LoS1 before playing this - the premise of the game spoils the 'secret ending' of the first game, but the game does recap the story if you just want to jump in here.

Combat is much tighter than the first game - not only do you control three distinct weapons (a long-range whip, a mid-range healing sword, and close-range guard-breaking gauntlets), but the Mastery system encourages you to play around with and get comfortable with all of the moves in your repertoire instead of just mashing the simplest combo.

Visually the game is intense - this is about as good as it gets from the PS3/360 generation, and the PC version has special HD textures.

As far as the story, I was personally hoping for something a little less safe considering the gut-punch ending of the first game.  I have heard that Konami changed the original ending to the one we have here, so we'll see what the DLC offers.

All in all I think that I may have enjoyed the first game more than this one, but this had moments, especially in the first half of the game, where I felt as if it was exactly what I had wanted out of the sequel.  The latter half also has great segments, such as the Toy Maker, but the last quarter of the game the narrative begins to get a little loose and things just happen because end the game already.  Which is a shame, but it doesn't necessarily ruin it.

reviewText:
MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS:

To be honest, I really enjoyed this game during.  I think the combat was well put together.  The story we really well done, IMO.

This is a tricky review though.  As I said, during the game it was fun.  On beating the game though, I did feel disappointed.  But let me break down some of the elements.

Stealth:  I feel the hate for these sections is misplaced.  The fact is, they are such a tiny part of the game, they might as well not even be there.  They can all be completed in no more than 10 minutes.  I also feel the whole transforming into the rat swarm was not neccesary at all.

Enemies:  Most enemies are very good.  They vary up their attacks, they dodge your attacks, and large groups of them can prove problematic.  Out of all the times I died, it was mostly to these situation.  At points you are under seige from large groups of small enemies, and then sometimes you are facing two or three very large hard to kill enemies.

As it should follow - Combat:  The combat I feel was excellent in this game.  It was as good as the combat in the first game, hands down.  They added this power up element which basically incentivizes changing attacks and weapons.  The dodge was much more responsive feeling in this game than the last game.  Accordingly, the timing for the charge moves of enemies is very much varied.  So there is no absolute time to block.  They also made it harder to syncronize block in this game.  It felt like you have less frames to hit the button in.  I noticed that some enemies hardly ever normal attack and almost always charge.  Those enemies ended up being the easiest though as their attacks tended to not be varied.

The World:  This is where the game has some failings.  It placed you in many small corridors and very few vistas.  In the first game you had lots of open and interesting areas to fight and puzzle your way through.  In this one lots of times it felt lackluster because of this failing.  The castle, as other reviews have stated, is awesome.  But it just feels like the castle is mostly optional.  You find Wolf portals between the worlds, but I found little reason to back to the castle and explore.

Environmental puzzles:  Almost non-existent.  It's a shame, iit was fun to try and get past timing puzzles and spike traps in the first game.  This game had none of that.  No timing puzzles, no spike traps, it just felt like you were walking forward a lot in this game with little to hinder your way... well little except finding a switch which was usually located in the same room.  I just didn't see the point of pulling a lever to open a door that was five feet away.

Extracurriculars: There was plenty of things in this game to collect.  But the back tracking isn't fun to me.  In the first game, the stage based design was awesome for this.  Go back, find the scrolls, collect the gem or the weapon upgrade, maybe do a the stage challenge while you are at it.  I loved the challenges in the first game, they were fun to try and complete.  This game didn't really have that.  They had some sort of challenges that I unlocked throughout the game, and the game managed to tell me about them about 700 times throughout the course of the game.  The funny part was, going through the pages of the Journal and menus... where the hell are they located?  I never figured it out, but I wan't inclined to backtrack and figure it out.

Pros that don't need explanation:

Music was awesome
Voice acting was awesome
Story was, for the most part, very good

Cons (many of these are personal cons and as such I know aren't objective or shared by many people):

Free Camera - I loved how the first one was with the locked camera.  The devs always put it in a good spot to show off the awesome world.  I feel that stepping away from that was a mistake.  The camera was downright annoying in some battles, and in other battles it didn't do a good job.

Open World:  As explained, I didn't enjoy this aspect.  I am a firm believer that not every game is automatically made better by an open world.  This one was definitely not.  Believe it or not, the world actually felt much smaller than the stage based world from the first game.  I think a good open world is truly awesome, but this unfortunately was not.  Also, in making it an open world that helped to deny my want to go back and find collectibles.

Overall Opinion:  I think this is a worthy game on a sale.  If you played and liked the combat from the first game, you are probably gonna love the combat in this one.  I also felt that the dev failed to deliver on a conclusion to the trilogy.  The ending was not a conclusion, but an outright attempt to further the series into yet another game, which disappoints me.  I am anxious to see what they do with DLC however.  There are rumors of an Alucard DLC, which I would be interested in playing.   If they did some sort of DLC that let you play as the other Belmont you meet in the game, that would also be fun.  If I had to give it a score, I would probably give it a 6/10.  This is not an objective review, I have explained what I personally did not like about it.

Edit:  At the time of writing my Steam timer shows 25 hours in game.. but I alt/tabbed out of the game to do something, realized I had to leave for work, and then left it on while I was at work by accident.  I really only put 15 hours or so into the game, so that was a disppointment.  The first one I put 29 actual hours into.

Edit2:  I did a No" recommend.  But if you get it on sale and want to see how the story plays out

reviewText:
This is a very, VERY good game!  Take note that this is a review from a gamer that ACTUALLY read all the memorials, did not skip a scene, took the time to look at statutes, arts and building structural designs, and all the back stories in every description. I also take this game as it is, instead of relating it back to any other Castlevania, such as Symphony of The Night or the first LoS.

10/10 would recommend this game, and here's why:

Pros

1) The story is amazing.  As I dig deeper into the story, I feel I can relate to some of the characters, know why they did what they did, and that is important! Some may argue that the ending is dull, I personally think that it is fitting.  Reading the memorials help me understand how the modern era portrays the world and history.

2) Voice acting is phenomenal.  They not only fit the characters, they brought out the emotions of their characters and made the story more colorful.

3) The soundtrack is amazing as well.

4) The city and castle designs are amazing.  While it is set in a modern world close to ours, it also retain some original castle structures that makes sense to remain there.  The castle is, well, Dracula's castle, and it is beautiful.  The texture of the stone/wooden floors, ceilings, and walls are so detailed that they are worth admiring, one could feel that this is not a simple copy-and-paste world.  I actually took time to look at statutes from different angles, just to admire them.  The world is interconnected, different routes to a place is possible.

5) Game's free-camera-control is great, and the combat is fluid.

6) I love it when in Dracula's rat form.  While some will argue it's necessity (Dracula too powerful to be a rat), it gives me a different view of the city.  What amazes me is that despite everything being bigger, the texture of the world is still amazing (floor tiles, walls and cables)!  So what he turns into a rat? He's a ♥♥♥♥ing Dracula!

7) The most controversial part of the game: Argreus.  I like the stealth part in his maze.  Again, many people would argue that since Dracula is so powerful why the sneaking and the one-shot-kill? Ever heard of Pan's Labyrinth? Well, Argreus IS Pan's brother, so it makes sense that a maze like that would be his world, and the one-shot-kill is justified.  That is why we have to make it past the maze to a higher ground where it is not a maze to fight him.  Savvy?

Cons

1) The stealth system is flawed.  While bat swarm works on certain enemies (only on the red armored marine if I recall correctly), most of the time when you use it sneaking up on an enemy, it just draws attention to every enemy in the vicinity to focus on you (once you use it, they know where you are).

2) Despite having so many different skills, as the game progresses, skills will become less useful.  Some enemies are so aggressive that you just don't have time to use different attacks without being knocked down first.  I ended up using basic attacks in most of the situation.

Overall, this is a great game.  You will be missing out if you rely your decision to buy this game on unprofessional critic's opinions about this game.  Hell, reviewing a game ain't even close to my profession, but after seeing some negative reviews of this game, and after personally playing it, I feel compelled to write something to justify the unjust.  After all, it's really about whether you had fun or not about a game, right?

reviewText:
Unlike its predecessors, Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 in overall did not move me as much I was expecting it. Gameplay wise, it's gone back to the dungeon crawling genre which could be great for some of the gamers out there. The abilities are quite similar to what we experienced in Castlevania: Lords of Shadow however with different type of weapons and upgrades. There is a larger selection of secondary items that can help, but in my personal experience, they were rarely used. Some events were quite interesting but I must agree with most people that the stealth feature should have been scrapped and put focus on the platforming and puzzles.
As you might have guessed, the storyline begins with Dracula or formerly Gabriel Belmont fight the Brotherhood of Light then ends with Alucard appearing. You then jump through time into a modern technological world, and start with the ridiculous stealth feature à la Metal Gear Solid. So, your objectives are basically to fight various bosses and repossess old powers which Dracula has lost through time. Pretty much like any dungeon crawling game.
Unfortunately, there is little content about the storyline which was pretty disappointing. Characters, including Dracula and Alucard were uninteresting, emotionless. The exception is when Dracula returns to his castle throughout the playthrough. I finished this game without any emotion and with lots of questionning.

Do I recommend this game? I will for the people who like Castlevania, the old dungeon crawling genre. But, you must expect some disappointment if you want to know the rest of the story. Cheers.

reviewText:
Addictive!

If you liked the first game, expect improved mechanics and a better developed battle system which encourages you to learn your combos instead of constantly using the same button. Leveling your weapons up is a much better experience now and you will actually feel the difference as Dracula's power returns.

As for graphics, the game is beautiful - though not as inspired as the first episode. Light is improved, textures are improved, creativity not so much. Bear with the game for the first 2 hours and it won't let you down. Playing through modern cities with the almighty vampire might sound like a nice idea but the lack of better designs and the feeling of repetition as the scenery looks the same for a while will make you ask why the developers chose this path instead of focusing on the much nicer gothic    landscapes Castlevania really shines on.

Storywise, even though the actors are awesome and doing their best, they haven't got much to work with. Still, this is only true if you compare it with the first LoS. Yes, there's a story, yes, it's kind of mediocre... Well, the majority of games I've been playing haven't been above mediocre so I guess it's fine.

Other than that, lots of places to explore and collectibles all over the place will give you replayability over the already lenghty main course. So, yeah. Good. Really good and recommended at full price.

7/10

reviewText:
I have to admit I was a little late to the game when it came to the first game. For those that don't know, the first Lords of Shadow - and by extension this game as well - is a reboot of the franchise as opposed to a continuation of the original canon.

That being said, I have been greatly anticipating this sequel since finally playing and beating LoS and man was it ever worth all that waiting and anticipation! LoS 2 has you playing as the Prince of Darkness, Dracula (Gabriel Belmont in this universe) himself which really needs no explanation in regards to it's freaking cool factor.

Patrick Stuart reprises his role as Zobek (aka Death) and Robert Carlyle is back (and better than ever!) as Gabriel/Dracula, which alone are two good reasons why this game rocks! Also, Richard Madden as Alucard was a pretty splendid choice in my opinion. The sound and music - and the other voice work too - is all quite excellent as well.

I have been absolutely loving the gameplay so far, especially the combat which I feel has recieved a nice overhaul. There is still enough of the old system there that it should feel familiar and comfortable, but they also improved nicely upon some of the smaller snags I felt the first game suffered from. AI is a bit more agressive and (only slightly) less predictable this time, which is a bit refreshing. Also, for all intents and purposes - at least as far as gameplay is concerned - Gabriel and Dracula are two entirely different characters, despite actually being the same person.

Gone is the Combat Cross, Gabriel's signature weapon from LoS; instead Dracula most commonly wields the Shadow Whip which is a manifestation of his own blood that he can summon and control. Instead of Gabriel's Light and Shadow Magic, you now have the life-leeching Void Sword and the armor-piercing Chaos Claws which each offer their own form and style in combat. You can also feed on stunned opponents to recover your health in a pinch. Oh and instead of the consumables Gabriel used to carry around, Dracula wields powerful vampire abilities and other dark magics - Shadow Daggers, Void Projections, Bat Swarms and more; instead of being consumable they all have their own cool-down timers and thus behave more like spells would.

The game is much bigger and better all around for the most part, though there a few minor things that I personally find annoying. For instance exploration is way more 'hand holdy' than it was in LoS... to the point that ledges you can grapple and climb now glow faintly and are surrounded by a small swarm of bats, objects you can bash with your throwing daggers are outlined by a glowing red ring of what appears to be blood, and the addition of an actual function (hold LT) while platforming that outlines possible moves 2-3 steps ahead of where you're currently climbing/hanging. Not really a deal breaker, per say, but definitely takes a lot of the fun out of it. In LoS I actually missed quite a few collectibles due to not being able to find them or simply not being able to reach them once I did locate them - this in turn drove me to explore further and look all the harder for what I may have missed; the possibility for this level of challenge is all but impossible in LoS 2 it would seem.

I won't give away too much of the plot, for two reasons: one I have yet to beat the game and two it would just be a damn shame to spoil something so good. That being said the basic premise is this: a thousand years (and a 3DS game) have passed since the events of LoS, Dracula has been defeated and weakened - by his own blood no less - and thus left vulnerable to an attack from Satan, whom Gabriels seriously ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off the last time they met. Zobek makes a timely arrival to warn his 'old friend' of course and offers him both a way to regain his powers - to defeat Satan - and a way to free him from his curse - death at the hands of Zobek, who has supposedly located the Combat Cross. Thus the battle begins between the Prince of Darkness and the agents of Satan.

One of the best adventure games I have had the luxury of playing. The reviews on the internet seem to be very harsh and biased. In Truth this game features the most beutiful sound track, atmosphere and design that I have seen in a game. There are many innovative tools used so that you dont have to have any loading screens traveling in between area's. There is a lot of exploration within this game and as its best comparason would be an upgraded version to Darksiders or a 3D Metroidvania Zelda.

The combat mechanics have been improved heavily since the first game and feel really good. You could compare the combat to Devil May Cry or God of War.

Peoples main issue has been with some small sections of stealth and or turning into rats to get around which I should note is not often and if it happens it allows you to open up new paths to travel. Do not let it bother you as it only adds to the depth of the game. The developers set out with very ambitious goals and should be commended for pumping so much into a single game of this quality, somthing I dont feel I have really seen on this generation.

The game is at its best on a PC with incredible visuals, I would however suggest a controller as it is an action game and does not feel right with a mouse.

Enjoy!

reviewText:
Massively fun!

Lords of Shadow 2 is an improvement upon the original in every way. Regardless of how one feels about the architecture of the 'new world' versus the classic macabre, renaissance atmosphere that is a staple of the series, it can't be argued that the game doesn't look absolutely gorgeous.

The combat is improved greatly, as is that horribly static camera angle that gave so many of us unnecessary troubles (that has now been modified to be a completely movable, 360-degree camera). The PC version's upgraded graphics settings are highly appreciated to those of us that have the means to run it. Even then it's not the most demanding game for video cards and being an older engine, it still makes use of every technique in the book to give the game a next-gen look.

The story itself is expanded and the lore is explored heavily; it's recommended that you play at least the first LoS game to get a decent grip on the storyline, but the prologues and 'follow ups' are perfectly acceptable to rely on. If you know the storyline already, then not much needs to be said, it the sequel we've been waiting for an a truly gorgeous take on Dracula's story along with the Belmont clan in general.

The music took me by surprise with this one. The original did a lot of harkening back to older Caslevania staples and did a lot of newer approaches to that old Gothic vibe. LoS2 does a great job at feeling like a standalone title and that shines the most through the music; it still feels like a Castlevania, but touches and nuances to certain tracks (techno-vibes for the future, classic organs for the past) make it feel fresh. There's some really beautiful tracks in this soundtrack.

All in all this isn't the Castlevania I've been fawning for over the years since the series has gone 3D; I still pine for a classic HD/pseudo-3D/2D 'Metroidvania' title. But this has proven that the series can at least work in the 3D realm. Improvements are necessary, and they've done enough to prove to me that 3D Castlevania can not only work, but flourish. It's not a perfect game and there's a few hiccups in both the gameplay and story, but it'd be nitpicking to say that these tiny aspects took away from my mainly thoroughly (and still in-progress) journey through the dilapidated castles and the sprawling wasteland of the futuristic, yet still familiar gothic city.

reviewText:
One of my favorite action-adventure games; but be careful, this game has a different tone than the first Lords of Shadow and also, it has big plot holes and some gameplay flaws.
The combat is very similar to the first Lords of Shadow, but improved.
The puzzles are easier but most of them are more related to the game than the puzzles of the first Lords of Shadow ( now many puzzles involves using the abilities of Dracula instead of moving pieces in a board).
This game also have camera control with the right stick instead of the predefined camera of the first game.
Another noticeable change is that now there are exploration in the game, it's really a 3D Metroidvania game, where you unlock new areas while getting new powers.
About the tone, LoS 2 has an atmosphere much darker than the first one, basically you explore two worlds:  one is very similar to the first game(but darker), and the other one at the beginning may look like an arkham city less appealing, but most of the game it's more like the first Darksiders atmosphere.
The story also remind me Darksiders and a little bit of Hellboy.
The bad parts: there are some stealth sections that feels out of place and there are not very fun, the first hour of two of the game(after the prolog) are not very good, Dracula doesn't look like a vampire(but you can buy a skin :) ), and the game has some annoying on-screen suggestions (fortunately, they can be deactivated in the menu).
Even when these shortcomings most of the game is great.

reviewText:
A massive overhaul of the combat system without forgetting tricks learned, optional quicktime system, across the board admission that they made mistakes with the first game, and a demonstration that they can learn from them. The only problem this game has is the menu interface, which doesn't allow multiple saves or easy access to an actual title menu. But it doesn't hurt the actual content of the game.

Graphics: 9/10. Only deducted points is for some weird-looking hair and particle animation touching on the uncanny valley, but it's otherwise a gorgeous, nigh perfectly beautiful game.

Sound: 10/10. The score is wonderfully emotional and puts you in the middle of each moment. You'll find yourself humming along with the rat theme, and gratified during the main theme's return in key moments.

Gameplay: 9/10. It's not castlevania anymore, but I'm not complaining. The tricks they picked up from Devil May Cry combine well with other improvements, and mesh in the Symphony-esque metroidvania world. No more is the whip the only useful weapon, no more is spamming R1 the easiest way to end fights. No more are quicktime events required, but neither are they abandoned, for those who enjoy them. And they skip function works beautifully, at no point during even cutscenes do they feel forced, nor does the lack of them feel depriving. A good status quo. But it looses a point for not having a heart system, or a means to deal with stealth sections as a combat option. Sorry, series fidelity is one thing I'm big on, and Castlevania isn't a stealth game, neither is it Devil May Cry. That said, the stealth segments are still very well designed, just a littlle immersion breaking when you're playing as the Prince of Darkness, whom the devil and death both fear.

Replay: 9/10: Postgame, Newgame+, and some really enjoyable once-through sequences, with a train sequence early on being a standout, and a few of the boss build-ups having that effect as well, make for a game that you won't feel a need to give up for awhile, and will always be willling to dig out in a year for another run. No complaints, only point deducted is thanks to Dark Souls moving the goalposts (and Dark Souls II doing it again,) for replay value in recent years by evolving the new game+ formula, and there should have been an attempt to learn from their methods. Great games learn from each other. This applies to all games developed after a previous game. You don't need to change your self-entity, but cool tricks should not be ignored.

Story: 10/10 Yes. On par with the first, with a slightly more Castlevania-y feel, despite your role as the series villian. No more pacing problems. Just awesome. There is emotion, forshadowing, character depth all done wonderfully. If I can make a complaint, it is only that some character arcs require a knowledge of the much-less-enjoyable first game to fully appreciate, but watching a youtube cutscene compilation will fulfil your need.

Overall: 94/100. If you're into the genre, if you're into the series, heck, if you're into just good storytelling in general, give this game a shot. If you're scared, wait for a steam sale. It's optimized wonderfully, so hardware shouldn't be a big problem.

reviewText:
A few notes about this review: I'm yet to play the prequel to this game as of the time this review was written, and as such, will not be comparing this title to Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 1.

Gameplay:

The game is very reminiscent of open-world  hack and slash classics such as Devil May Cry and Bayonetta. The mechanics are well varied and properly executed, and at its' very beginning, launches the player into action.

The boss fights are bloody, epic, and memorable. Little was spared in terms of length and difficulty when encountering various bosses, who are well varied and endowed. Prepare to die a few times in your quest to make progress.

Note that duie to the nature of the story (see section below) , repetitive gameplay is necessitated for one to unlock Dracula's potential abilities as the story progresses. This is executed in a repetitive manner, and as such, incurs a considerable challenge at the early stages of the game. However, as an indirect consequence, later sections are very rewarding as your new abilities are fully utilized in making progress. Prepare for a challenge.

The stealth system and mechanics used are not ideal and are out of balance. A being such as dracula shouldn't be reduced to a powerless imp in the stealth sections, which can be confusing and often convoluted.

Graphics:

Excellent, judging bu its' requirements and visuals. They are well balanced and properly executed. Details are clear and vivid, and so are the vast, open world environments. Character forms are well refined and so are their spectral abilities.

Story line:

All in all, dependin gon your background, its' taste may differ to you. I've read previous reviews from people who played the games' prequel and most were not pleased.
in my opinion, I found the fusion of both the present and the past (through the use of the Wolf Medallion) a bit unique in that you can switch to either timeline and progress at your own rate. In a manner, this further enhances the open world experience. As a drawback, this can make the game very repetitive since the environments are consrained to one transitional area, a chemical company. This also incurs a drawback to the overall quality of Dracula's retelling as a legendary vampire who must be trapped to a moden themed factory for extended periods of gameplay time as a requirement to progressing in the game. This repetitive nature may not bode well for all players.

Overall rating:

The production quality is superb, and so is the gameplay. Comes highly recommended.
My personal rating is 7.5/10.

reviewText: This game is really good. If you liked the first one, like I did, I highly recommend it. The combat depth from the first is still there, and no amount of button mashing will save your life. And the combat is quite chalenging. The map exploration is a Metroid-Vania, but in a 3D enviroment, look like Darksiders. The game rewards exploration, since there are a lot of collectibles and upgrades, and you can easily miss then if you don't explore, and a quick travel trough castle map rooms are a enourmous help, altough the quick travel system could be better. Story is awesome, what could you ask? It is Dracula, The prince of Darkness kicking Satan in the nuts - that's a good one on my book. The presentation is spot on, you totaly look like a badass vampire and fight like one, and both city and castle parts are impressive. The developers reproduce the horror ambience from other Castlevania games perfectly, and even when you are in modern times, it really looks like a Castlevania. The only complaint I have is that they could use more of the open air parts of the modern day city, since it looks so awesome, but you'll be on the inside of buildings most of the time. I'm a big fan of the series, and this is a worthy sequence of a great game. I'm still working on beating it, and the boss fights are really good.

reviewText:
Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 is an entertaining, 12+ hour long action game with a few issues holding it back from greatness. It's a shlocky, hamfisted and (in my mind) enjoyable story focused on Dracula and his bloody escapades around his palace in two different timelines.

While not wholly divergent enough from the play-book of the first Lords of Shadow to call it a Metroidvania, Lords of Shadow 2 (LoS2) makes an admirable attempt at creating a fully explorable world which requires backtracking to old nooks with new moves in your arsenal to claim some doodad for your growing inventory of glowing crystal assistance-thingies. It's all very obvious and not particularly exciting, but it does reward you for your time and attentiveness.

You won't really need those 'hidden' rewards unless you're playing on the upper difficulty echelons. The combat is instantly recognizeable if you've played the first game. This year's model does come with improvements, weapon switching on the fly similar to DmC: Devil May Cry replaces the blue glow/red glow for essentially the same status effect, but with new combos to learn. There's also a fully adjustable camera, which is a pleasant new necessity (given the level design). Like the first Lords of Shadow, LoS2 has a deeper combat system than you might give it credit for at first appearance, it'll grow on you, but it doesn't go as far as some contemporaries and on all but the highest difficulties you won't struggle in battle.

LoS2 has a few obvious issues. While there's some goofy and entertaining narrative chunks to push you forward early on, there's also some sluggish tutorialization. The two timelines are enjoyable, but the past clearly has the art design edge- with the present not really distinguishing itself nearly as much. You'll probably greet flashlights with a weary sigh as the signal in another easy, brainless stealth section that, conceptually, is used to break up the monotany of entertaining flashy combat and brisk level design. Yeah, great idea.

At the end of the day, Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 is a likeable sequel. It's self-aware, in many aspects, with fantastic options like 'Turn off QTEs' which I highly recommend, as well as boasting satisfying boss encounters. It unfortunately struggles with branching out and exploring new gameplay elements. The pacing could be tighter... But, that said, I had a lot of fun with it. There are some great sequences, great moments that play off of the crazy Castlevania Dracula power trip which make it easy to recommend to fans of the first game. When it's firing on all cylinders, it captures the essence of what so many people liked about the first.

It hits a lot more than it misses and is worth your time and money if you happened to enjoy the first. It runs great, looks great and is fun to play. While it didn't surpass my expectations, it met them.
