reviewText:
Dracula is back and this time, it's worth it.

Castlevania Lords of Shadow 2 is one of the few decent 3D castlevania's, with Dracula's character being dark and even cruel at times.

I enjoyed the combat, though the decision to include the blood-whip as a primary weapon was headscratching, why not use a different weapon?

Regardless, it has a bestiary which is interesting and plenty of in-game lore to read th rough if you enjoy that.

The game has however some flaws: the biggest being the forced stealth segments. These can range from creative to asinine, and they get progressively less fun, forcing the question of: Why does Dracula have to sneak around? it's Dracula!

The storyline can be silly at times and I would've preffered the timeline to stay in the past, in Castlevania. However the decision to include the present was confusing as it neglects the most interesting part: Dracula in the present. The social implications of this would be amazing, yet it's completely ignored. I feel this was a wasted opportunity.

That being said, at the end of the day this is easily the strongest entry into the 'Lords of Shadow' stable, but I'd only recommend it for diehard fans.

reviewText:
Dracula is back and this time, it's worth it.

Castlevania Lords of Shadow 2 is one of the few decent 3D castlevania's, with Dracula's character being dark and even cruel at times.

I enjoyed the combat, though the decision to include the blood-whip as a primary weapon was headscratching, why not use a different weapon?

Regardless, it has a bestiary which is interesting and plenty of in-game lore to read th rough if you enjoy that.

The game has however some flaws: the biggest being the forced stealth segments. These can range from creative to asinine, and they get progressively less fun, forcing the question of: Why does Dracula have to sneak around? it's Dracula!

The storyline can be silly at times and I would've preffered the timeline to stay in the past, in Castlevania. However the decision to include the present was confusing as it neglects the most interesting part: Dracula in the present. The social implications of this would be amazing, yet it's completely ignored. I feel this was a wasted opportunity.

That being said, at the end of the day this is easily the strongest entry into the 'Lords of Shadow' stable, but I'd only recommend it for diehard fans.

Big fan of the first one but can't say I loved this.
Story builds up a lot of hype for nothing. The final battle is a joke and the ending is the laziest ♥♥♥♥ I've seen in a long time, opening up for DLC obviously.
Game tries to spice up as much as possible the original formula by bringing out zelda elements : hub, tons of subweapons, backtracking. It doesn't work : the hub is confusing at best, the subweapons feel like cheating and well backtracking isn't very fun. Music is so so with like 10 remixes of the same theme.

Good points are three very cool boss fights and the gorgeous art direction. The rest is pretty bland and the stealth sections, while not as bad as expected, don't really bring anything.

It had been one of my most anticipated games for two years. I'm really dissapointed.

reviewText:
Finally, a 3D Metroidvania that does the series justice. This game is packed so full of homage to classic CV its ridiculously cool. Gameplay is similar to the first game, but much tighter. 'Useless' moves were removed, now every move in your arsenal has a point and purpose. The new movesets for the Void Sword and the Chaos Claws are excellent and diverse, they have a distinct different 'feel' as opposed to simply being light and dark powers.

A true Castlevania fan will appreciate how far the series has come in this conclusion to the LoS story. Don't listen to the butthurt Igavania fanboys who are seriously the cancer killing the series. There are merits to both 2D and 3D CV's and this game fully delivers the 3D CV real fans have been waiting for.

Oh, and ignore the paid reviewers who are butthurt they didn't get a paycheck, or simply suck too hard at REAL games to actually get far enough to form a proper unbiased opinion. It shouldn't even need to be mentioned though, anyone with a fraction of a brain knows to ignore 'professional' reviewers nowadays.

reviewText:
Pay little attention to the Reviews out there giving this game 5's and 6's. I find it hard to understand the harsh reviews this game has gotten so far, i am about half-way thru the game and it just keeps getting better. here are my obdervations so far

Whats Great:
+ Game is Gorgeus! lives up to the amzing looks of the 2d castlevania's
+ The Combat system is satisfying and a vast improvement over the previous LoS
+ Boss fights are intresting everytime and i am loving the enemy designs
+ Enviroments in the castle are stunning and detailed (many a time did i stop to gawk at statues)
+ Fantastic soundtrack (I still miss the symphonic metal of the old games but this is still pretty good)
+ Being the final chapter in the LOS series the story from all those games is paying off and cant wait to see how it unfolds
+ Open world enviroment is back!, the first LoS was more of a level based game while this one tries to stick to its roots of open exploration via powers and items unlocked

Whats not so Great:
+ Stealth sequences (who put this in my castlevania game?)
+ Modern time setting feels out of place and unexciting (I get sad everytime i leave the castle)
+ Needs a more detailed overworld map

Overall i am excited to finish it and i hope this game does not go unnoticed due to mediocre reviews as many other steam users here seem to agree with me that this game is worth at least your time to try the demo. And if you enjoyed the first LoS there is no reason not to enjoy this one.

reviewText:
A definite improvement over the last game.  Better world, story, and gameplay.

The explorable world with collectable lore was a major plus. Exploration and secrets were a fairly good distraction that led me to look at the world a little more thoroughly. The lack of any side missions or story was a bit dissappointing.

The story is fairly engaging, more so I imagine considering I played the first game and have already developed an understanding and sympathetic realtionship with the main character.   Robert Carlyle offered a wonderful dracula and the supporting cast were almost invariably superb.  I'm glad they had the lore portion of the in game menu, because without it I would have felt that they introduced some characters out of the blue without any exposition. Which could be viewed as lazy but I didn't find it too offensive.

The combat is quite fluid and the controls are pretty intuitive.  It only took me about ten minutes to get a really good grasp on the mechanics of the game.The boss fights are pretty good as well.  One complaint about the boss fights is that they seem to be very interesting and tactically stressful to begin with but they gradually push into tedium when you learn what tactics are necessary to defeat them.  This is most prevenlant in the first boss and last two bosses.  Another negative thing about certain sections of the game would be the stealth" sections.  They were lacluster
date: slowing the game down unecessarily sometimes
recommended: mostly due to the whole system seeming under-developed.\n\nOverall this game has alot to offer in most of its areas with only a few minor misses but doesn't really do anything epicly well or ground breaking.  I definitely enjoyed it."

reviewText:
Let's just get one thing straight; Lords of Shadow was my personal GoTY. Whilst I will admit that it had its foibles, overall I enjoyed it more than any other game I played that year. After spending some time with LoS2 I can already say that this is more of the same, so if you liked the first game then you will like this and vice versa. The game looks simply amazing, there's no denying that.

The gameplay is almost identical to LoS but with a few tweaks. You now have a free roaming camera; This makes sense, as whilst the game world is stil split into distinct areas, you have the freedom (of a kind) to move between them as you see fit, and having a free camera lets you search around levels for all of those secret hideaways and stashes. As I just mentioned, the game world this time round is a much more open one. There are a ton of secrets and upgrades to find. Some of the things that made some people dislike LoS return, though they aren't deal breakers (platforming is still ropey and sometimes you think (can) jump to ledges only to bounce" off them and fall into some lava or a pit and have to restart your platforming. The game starts off slowly but then builds pace nicely. The combat is almost identical to LoS (no bad thing).

There are however some annoying things; "cheap" shots by enemies that are way off screen
date: unlbockable and sometimes un-dodgeable attacks and the way enemies will keep you in their fight area if you try to run/climb your way out of a fight. reviewText:
18 hours on record, but it felt like a lot longer and I did barely any of the exploring. Lords of Shadow 2 is a fantastically composed game, with an enjoyable mix of platforming sections and combat, though the balance towards the platforming and forced stealth after the game's introduction is a bit skewed.

Combat feels incredibly meaty, and switching weapons mid combat is far more satisfying than the magic system from the previous game, really making combos feel heavy and devastating. Though there is a limited meter for each of the weapons, I found that I barely reached the bottom unless I was obsessing heavily over one. The one complaint is enemies with shields that need to be broken with the chaos claws, and whilst you can backflip over them, the mercenary soldiers seem to be able to rotate instantly, requiring the use of the claws more often than not. There is a plethora of abilities for each weapon, and unless you constantly back and forth between zones grinding enemies for xp, it is highly unlikely you will have unlocked them all by the game's end.

Boss battles are big and epic, featuring multiple phases, transitions and enjoyable visuals and backgrounds, the second fight with Volkova being one of the highlights of the game. Lords of Shadow 2 also ignores some of those awkward climbing bosses from the first game, with only a short climbing section featuring in the pentultimate encounter. Whilst it isn't always immediately obvious where to go, swarms of bats linger on ledges Dracula can jump on from the ground, whilst holding a button highlights the path you need to take.

The voice acting is superbly well delivered, Patrick Stewart as Zobek owns any scene he's in, and although Gabriel/Dracula's dialogue in the game's introduction is quite hammy, Robert Carlyle really hits his stride as the game's pace picks up, especially in the more emotional engagements with his family.

All in all I would recommend Lords of Shadow 2 if you're after a game that's going to last you a good long while, however one thing I would object to is marathoning it as fast as possible (as I did) as you'll find yourself getting burnt out and frustrated quickly.

reviewText:
The game was alright overall, but it's a poor man's Arkham game. The story of the main game was interesting and the art style is fantastic, but the gameplay and combat system actually got quite annoying near the end, when trying to get all the collectables.

Part of the problem is the level design which is a non-obvious corridor, where areas are separated by a multitude of sluice-gates, elevators, decontamination rooms, etc. It's constant delaying and unnecessary gratuituous animations which get boring rather quick. It takes a very long time to navigate between areas and respawning mobs often prevent you from leaving before you dealt with them, even though you have nothing else to gain from killing them. Once I got the final secret collectible, it took me something like 20 minutes to get to the area where you trigger the final boss encoounter.

Unlike the Arkham games where collecting additional content is enjoyable and adds to the experience, the design of the levels actually takes enjoyment away. I would recommend doing a story driven run and avoiding backtracking for collectables and challenges.

The music is OK on it's own, but doesn't fill inspired as much as the art style and often doesn't really fit the environemt or add much to the game.

The PC port is pretty bad. You pretty much need a controller, as all the button prompts are laid out for a 360 pad. It's much worse than the first game which you could play with KB/Mouse perfectly fine. The game runs well and stable, but it's absolutely impossible to tab out. You need to trigger an automatic save, which often happens between areas, but isn't reliable, and quit the game.

Lastly, something that bugged me personally. You frequently either fight or partner up with humnoid characters. They have about 3 phrases each on average and will keep shouting them non-stop. Gets seriously annoying.

reviewText:
I loved the first Lords of Shadow and I'm a fan of Castlevania in general. But I can't recommend Lords of Shadow 2. Gone are the sweeping vistas and gorgous colorful scenery of the first LoS, now it's all drab grays of a gothic city and a gothic castle. Even Patrick Stewart can't say the rediculous lines he's given with any gravitas. Which was a problem in the first game but is even moreso in the sequel. Further, the stealth sequences are shoehorned in and are very clunky. Dracula can take down giant gorgon monsters, combat mechs, and blood golems, but he can't handle some jerk in a suit with a grenade launcher.

The plot meanders about, spending alot of time introducing characters who'll never be seen outside of their introduction until it finally mercifully ends on an anticlimatic note.

The combat is good, if somewhat shallow, but the platforming is floaty at best. On the whole, you should wait for the steam sale before getting this game.

I completed it only for the plot.

+ More like the first game
+ Beautifully crafted
+ Enjoyable enemies
- No story related content at all...

City: 4/10
+/- Story is here, but it's not that good...
- Cheap enemies
- Bland and boring setting
- Horrible stealth sections

Overall: 6/10
Half of the game is horrible and other half is ok. Recommended only to HC fans of Castlevania.

reviewText:
Lords of Shadow 2 fills in the story around the time of (mostly after) the first Lords of Shadow game. LoS2 takes place in a combination of the modern world built on Dracula's castle and the past. While playing LoS2, I never really felt a sense of progression, I just felt like I was playing. It's not a particularly difficult game but it does have some stealth scenarios that can be annoying. The boss fights aren't particularly intuitive, just hack and slash and avoid getting hit. The modern environments weren't really my cup of tea but I thought it was fun that they used Dracula's castle as the foundation of an entire city. The past environments were nice and the graphics were done fairly well.

I had no performance issues with the game (played with an i7-950 & GTX 780) and no technical issues; it worked very well for me. I played with a gamepad, as any sane person should do with such a game.

Took me just over 16 hours to complete. I didn't collect all of the items and upgrades, but probably most of them. Reading the lore is probably the best part of the game.

Can't really say I highly recommend this game unless you're a Castlevania fan. Don't hate it, but probably won't replay it.

reviewText:
So first of all I didn't play the Castlevania series before which means I don't know anything about the GBA/Nintendo etc games.
I bought Darksiders -which was in a bundle- and I realy fell in love with the game. Afterwards I got Darksiders 2 and after I finished it aswell I started to search for games which are alike. Someone told me about Castlevania: Lords of Shadows.

So I started with Castlevania:LoS (Ultimate Edition) and it was one of the best expiriences I've ever had. The atmosphere, the fights, the mechanics (light/darkness) and the insanelly good music made this game a 9/10 for me. When I finished the game and closed the client I got an announcement by Steam about Castlevania:LoS2 and I was soooooooooo happy.

I immediatelly bought it and when it was released, I immediatelly started it.
The 1st thing was the Tutorial" which was epic as ♥♥♥♥. One of the greatest things in my opinion is the new usage of Light and Darkness which is splitt in new weapons (Sword/Gauntlet). I really liked the character development and how much the characters in the game actually changed.

I'll be honest. After I played for about 1 hour I was really disappointed about the game. It didn't feel like the 1st LoS and something was missing. I felt that the story was really flat and -maybe- it was the new location which I felt were not fitting the game. And I stopped playing it.
After some time passed I started the game again and realized it was the worst mistake ever to stop playing it.

#######################SPOILER###########################

It's amazing! I love how the game changes all the time. The timetravel and the changes in the locations are amazing. The story of the 1st LoS and LoS2 combine themself very well and makes a lot of sense. The story of LoS2 feels very flat but after I reach a certain point in the game my opinion changed completely. It pretty much change the whole point of view.
One of my favourite parts is still the music in this game which fits perfectly.

About the gameplay it's really simple to explain. The people who played the 1st LoS won't find many differences. You can still  find containers to increase your life/light/darkness. The 1st difference lies within the skilltree. While you still purchase new combos with the points you gain
date:
your skills level aswell if you use them and you can compile them in your weapon which makes the weapon stronger. This change is really good in my opinion because it was one of the flaws in LoS. The skilltree didn't seem to be important and you didn't really need to unlock the combos becuase you could beat the game with the stadart attack. Now there is at least a reason to use different attacks.
A new feature I really appreciate are the challenges which are a small sidekick. You get different challenges where you need to kill enemies within a certain time of do other things.
One of the facts that every LoS1 players will love is the camera which you can move completely freely.

What else can I add. The bossfights are still really good and the finishing moves are still epic as ♥♥♥♥
recommended:
the enemys use undodgeable moves more often which makes the fights a bit harder while the overall gameplay didn't change that much from LoS1.

I will say it this way: If you liked the 1st LoS and enjoyed it you will like the 1nd one aswell. Give it some time and don't drop it after an hour like me. Play it and see how well it develops.

My rating: 8 /10"

If you're considering this, you already know it's hack and slash: and it delivers on that.

You hack. You slash. You're obviously very, very insane, but that's okay; being a rather old recently re-awakened vampire lord apparently does that. People complain that it doesn't live up to it's predecessor, but not having played the predecessor I can say this game is fine.

COMPLAINTS:

You cannot play this without a controller. None of the keys are coreographed properly for quicktime, skill use or anything else (X, Y, A, B on EVERYTHING) You can re-map the keys and go through it (mostly) fine... with one, notable and game-shattering problem: navigating the skills menu. Unless it gives you a pop-up, you just can't, and that's a deal-breaker for PC support.

reviewText:
An amazing sequel. Graphics are top notch (HD-Texture pack is free and a recommended install), gameplay is engaging and fun, controls are crisp and free from lag or any kind of delay. Combat is varied and there's a truckload of skills to unlock and use.

Exploration feels less of a hassle as it did in the first game and you usually pick the various bits and bobs up as you progress through the story. There's a huge number of unlockables and power ups to find, it'll keep you busy for quite a while.

The music is fantastic. Really immersive.

Overall a lot of quality of life improvements have been made.

The only thing that really annoyed me was that the further you progress in the game, the more the enemies seem to favour using unblockable Power Attacks and wear heavy armour requiring you to expend Chaos Magic to break their defenses.


Some enemies hit a lot harder and quicker than I think they should. It can quickly ruin your day if you're not careful.

All in all, this is a really solid game.

A well deserved 9/10.

reviewText:
I had a much better time with this than I expected. The early reviews for the game made it sound like it was terrible, but it really wasn't that bad. However, that's not to say it isn't without its flaws.

The highlight of the game is probably its combat. You get three different weapons this time around instead of just magical powerups for the whip like in the original LOS: A light magic sword, dark magic gauntlets, and the whip returns as the default weapon. Each has their own style and role in combat; the sword can heal you when you do damage, the gauntlets do more damage than the other two overall and can also break enemy blocking, and the whip has good crowd control skills and has more range overall. Each weapon also has a fleshed out skill/move set tree that you can unlock with experience points. Gabriel controls more or less the same as he did in LOS with a couple tweaks, like a free moving camera.

For the overall main plot the game is shorter than the original Lords of Shadow, but it has much more in the way of secret items and challenge modes. The game is also much less linear than the original, with a semi-open world map that you can freely roam when not in a specific mission. The voice work is high quality, with much of the cast of the original returning (Patrick Stewart FTW) along with some new cast members who give a great performance as well. The game itself also looks great with very detailed and unique locals, characters, and monsters.

The biggest let down of the game is probably the forced stealth sections. They slow down what is normally a relatively fast paced game to a crawl, and don't work out well with how the game controls. They also don't really make sense in the context of the game, you are supposed to be this powerful being and yet these power armored lackeys can utterly destroy you if they see you. Thankfully there aren't many of these sections, and the rest of the game definitely makes up for it.

Overall I'd say the game is pretty good and is definitely worthwhile if you've played the other Lords of Shadow games.

reviewText:
Awak­ened after cen­turies of sleep, Gabriel Bel­mont joins his for­mer men­tor in an attempt to reclaim his pow­ers and defeat Satan and his acolytes in this final chap­ter in the Lords of Shadow series.

The game tran­si­tions between present time and medieval times, just before Dracula’s cas­tle was ruined. Dur­ing these tran­si­tions, Gabriel must not only fight Satan’s Acolytes, but he must also bat­tle his inner self in order to be able to regain his strength.

Lords of Shadow 2, like its pre­de­ces­sor, is an action-adventure hack n’slash game, but unlike pre­vi­ous install­ments it has some inter­est­ing game­play inno­va­tions, such as var­i­ous puz­zle ele­ments and stealth-like sec­tions. The new addi­tions, espe­cially the stealth ele­ments, tend to hin­der the pro­gres­sion of the story though and being totally scripted does not seem to add any­thing spe­cial to the whole gam­ing expe­ri­ence. There are no alter­nate routes, there is only one way… Despite this fact how­ever, the pres­ence of var­i­ous col­lectibles and upgrades which can be found through­out the map of the game make explo­ration quite a reward­ing experience.

Read the rest of my review here:  http://www.blowsomesteam.com/castlevania-lords-of-shadow-2/

*Edit: When I first wrote the review, I was only almost done with the game, but now that I have seen it through to the end, I feel I have to amend a couple of my points, primarily with the story. The ending sucks. I won't spoil anything, but I must say it was quite a let down. Many unresolved questions and an unsatisfying end both in story and boss fight. It was easier than the first acolyte.
Looking at this game from a completed perspective, even before my edit, I can say that this game had a lot of potential and good ideas, but from what I've read had a botched development. It shows because a lot of the game feels incomplete or like the developers rushed to finish what was left after some development troubles. It's really a shame and very disappointing.*

I played the first Lords of Shadow and I enjoyed it. As for this one, I would say it's better in some areas and worse in others.

COMBAT: Compared to the first, it feels like they really smoothed out the combat in terms of how you move around and perform moves. some difficulties become clearer when it comes to one mechanic though: the way some enemies block in this game. When some enemies are blocking, they stop your combo and deflect your attack and zero damage is done. This can get really annoying when there are multiple enemies and you are attacking one that is open, but the one right next to the first is blocking. it will stop your combo. This makes engagements with multiple blocking enemies really annoying unless you are really good with your chaos energy (it's like the shadow energy from the first game and it breaks through shield and armor). Multiple skeletons are the most annoying thing in this game... That said, thankfully those kinds of enemies don't show up terribly often, and combat can still be very fun now that it's smoothed out.

STORY: Sadly, I would have to say the story in this game is inferior to the first overall. There is no longer an opening narration to each stage like their was in the first because of the way they made the map somewhat open world (I'll get into that further down). There are also seems to be less moments of significant plot progression throughout the game; a lot of times it feels as if you go a great distance just to get a small snippet of story. That said, one of the things that brought me back toward liking the game more were the story moments (they pick up more once you get a bit further) when you see the way Gabriel changes based on his interaction with the other characters. Some of them were very moving. Still, overall there just doesn't seem to be as much story as there was in the first game, and for Patrick Stewart in particular, it almost seems like a waste of his talent.

VISUALS: For the most part, I'm going to say that this game's visuals are gorgeous. Very pretty and detailed environments. Not a lot of more vibrant environments like the first game, but they are still very detailed and pretty, especially when the game's graphics are turned up. reviewText: Over all I found this to be a spectacular game and would absolutly reccomend it to any player who enjoys their games with good story and characters. As said the story is fairly interesting. You play as Dracula on a mission to destroy Satan in order to stop a demonic invasion and finally be able to rest in peace. The voice acting was absoluely fantastic and the characters were completly believable and not at all flat. There was nothing weak with the characters.The Graphics and animation are also superb and the player is presented with stunning visuals all around, especially with the scenery which presents a gorgeous display of gothic architecture and other surroundings which will leave the player feeling fully immersed. Combat was intersting in that you could not simply just plow through a horde, but actually have to take the time to defeat them. I was playing on easy and defeating casual enemies was even then not just a simple task. Every enemy took time to kill. Quite a few boss battles took place and every boss was also an interesting character, who took time to defeat. Though I didn't find too much of a strategy nessessary, they still took time to defeat and it was enjoyable. The game is quite long and I feel that there were some parts the developers should have left out and even some parts I found completly unnessessary. For instance, there is at least two occasions where you are practiacally playing hide and seek, which I didn't feel was really nessessary or even enjoyable. Aside from this I feel it is a very well developed game. While I do not feel is is a classic, it was undeniably an enjoyable expirence that I can highly reccomend to anyone looking for strong characters, good story, and outstanding visuals.

reviewText:
Honestly, i was going through a lot of these reviews, expecially from fans of the first game, and i was surprised by how much negatives came here. So this review will be focused in comparing the two games (I played the first on X360)

I will say that, only in my first 2 hours of gameplay, i felt comfortable to rely on the lore for my so expected ending of the story. And i need to point out that this is a great game, regardless of comparations with the first. Also, a lot of these reviews say negative stuff about the stealth moments, but i think it's good and important because you have to acompany the story, if Gabriel lost most of his power, how would he go against a creature of Satan? It's very important to the lore. And i cannot agree to you being a fan of the saga if you don't pay attention to the story. I feel like these moments show me that like in the first game, i had to become strong. Playing all the game with ultimate Dracula powers would be tiring, and most likely ruin the experience.

As to graphics, my system is not the best, but what i've seen in my game and videos, it doesn't leave a lot to be wished.

I really enjoyed the new mechanics of gameplay, especially Gabriel's (sorry, can't call him Dracula :////) new powers. this really feels like to play the first game, but much more complete than that. Something i dislike strongly is the new combat rythim, i can't get to use special attacks, because i'm 95% busy finding enough time to do so. Also, there are some times when you truly don't know what to do, and you have to perform some action too quickly. I found this very troublesome in some parts.

And the camera, oh, the camera. That's something MUCH better than in the first game, when the camera was placed in map-specific locations, and also had the problem of having to stop to ajust your controls, since they were kept on camera changes (40% of camera changes). Now, it's something much more subtle, the camera is controlled by the player, and stays in a 2nd/3rd person view which receives some influence in a few map areas (but nothing that forces the camera on a spot or a too strong change. It feels better because now it gives me the immersion of exploring the world. And of course, this is better because now i feel rewarded for looking for a nice view and finding an amazing view. It's very balanced.

I do recommend this game to everyone, best buy, worth all the money (altough i got it on a discount).

Please feel free to add me or comment on my profile with any disagreements or suggestions to this review.

I wished to give it 10/10, but the gameplay has a few artifacts in my point of view.

8.5/10

reviewText:
Fantastic game!   It absolutely lived up to all of my expectations, including the DLC.  It ended, for the most part, exactly how I would have wanted.  It is sad that Mercury Steam will most likely never work with the Lords of Shadow series again, but the story is at least complete and was well done from start to finish.  What more could a fan of great story-telling ask for?

It does have some problems here and there, but if you are interested in it due to being a Lords of Shadow fan then your money will be well spent, since you are most likely here for the series' most accomplished attribute, it's lovingly crafted tale.  Otherwise, I suggest doing some more research on it, or maybe even trying the first two games (Don't forget Mirror of Fate) to see if the story grabs you.

Either way, my final opinion on this game is that it is a finely polished piece of software that has phenomenal storytelling and an extremely well implemented combat system.  It suffers slightly from some odd gameplay design choices here and there that might be a bit off-putting to some, but this game did not get the attention, nor respect, that it truly deserved.  Hopefully, Mercury Steam will craft something in the future that is not so much the diamond in the rough" that this game
recommended: ended up being.  Maybe something with a bit more mainstream appeal
hoursPlayed: i suppose?  I hope only the best for their future after having finished the Lords of Shadow series and am tentatively awaiting news of their next project."

reviewText:
What can I say?  I loved the first game.  I felt they did a great job rebooting the series and breathing new life into it.  While I loved the old games story wise they sucked.  Even lament of innocence which was great and tried its best to explain the belmont & dracula feud still lacked a little bit.  Now Lord of Shadow did a great job of really giving that belmont dracula feud a purpose and reason.  This game picks up right from the first game and really starts to breath life into dracula and with great story telling elements and voice acting really connects the players to dracula and kinda makes us question is her really that bad.  Maybe he has a good reason for being ♥♥♥♥♥♥.

People will pick apart the game play and the stealth mode.  I didn't enjoy the stealth mode but I did enjoy the combat system and loved using his new powers.  I loved the leveling up of the weapons and skills.  The items you pick up on the way I felt were just wasted I never used anyone of them expect of the health potion.

The environment was good.  I enjoyed my time in the Castle but didn't care for the modern world.

The important question is should I buy this game?  I think so but not at the full price.  The reason why is because of the ending.  The game really built things up with scenes of Dracula kinda coming back into the light and forgiving himself and redeeming himself in his own eyes.  This was great and really connected me to him even more.  The ending just kinda flopped there like a fish out of water.  It didn't wrap anything up or raise any question of whats next like the last game.  It was disappointing.  The fight with satan wasn't as tough as it was in the first one.  I kept thinking to myself he got beat the last time hit the gym and came back buff, but his old cross fitter body was better.  They need to give this game a proper ending if this really is the final game.  If they don't then all of that great work to just end on a bad note.


So final thought great story, but buy at half price due to the lack of a ending.

reviewText:
This game had a lot of promise but ultimately felt like a parody of itself. This game was loaded with recycled content including characters that shouldn't have been there - and game mechanics that were random and only served to draw the game out.

The load screens were my favorite where Gabriel/Dracula stared thoughtfully into some candlelight while his inner dialogue summed up the most immediate objective. Soft, introspective piano music would play in the background. Then you the accept button and a slashing sound was followed by Gabriel glaring suddenly into the camera... It was over-the-top.

The return of his wife Marie was a surprise and a happy one but they failed to tie her presence in to the over-arching arch. The ending was like watch an okay movie where they awkwardly avoid bring closure for the sake of making sequels that you already know are going to be bad.

Its a little sad given how well this reboot started.

reviewText:
Castlevania Lords of Shadow 2 is hard to judge in my opinon. I really looked forward to the progression of the story from Lords of Shawdow 1.  I felt a little disappointed with the story since the previous game and its DLC made it seem that much action was going happen.
That being said I still enjoyed most of the game, specifically its fighting mechanics, bosses and challenges.

Cons: (not trying to spoil so it will seem vague)
1. The developers made some odd decisions with the overall features/design of the game, some levels had these sections that required special abilities to get through them which to broke the pace of the game. There were also too many climbing sections.
2. You're Dracula, and while he is weak the developers could have taken a more creative route with the abilities.
3. The direction of the Story could have been better, The plot development left for so much to be desired.

Pros:
1. FIghting Mechanics were awesome. The leveling of weapons and powers were balenced.
2. Challenges were a great addition, they were fun and just right in difficulty.
3. The new items and some of the abilities were interesting.

I recommend the game if you completed Lords of Shadow 1, if you get it at a reasonable discount.

reviewText:
Take the first Lords of Shadow, and now make it like Devil May Cry.  If that sounds awesome, you are in good shape. If not, then probably not for you.

It's more open world and less linear than the first one, which is usually pretty fun.  The story is the biggest draw here, however that got kinda convulated as well.  I have to say, the first game was very very good, while this sequel took some chances and only a few paid off.

Lastly, they introduced stealth sections which just serve to be annoying.

With all that negativity out of the way, it's still a super fun game.  Incredible voice acting, great graphics, and tight game play.  I wish they had stayed more true to the original, but I can appreciate them trying some things out.  If you loved the first, you will enjoy this one, you will just have a few complaints.

It does however end on a satisfying note, and Gabriel remains a very interesting character.

reviewText: I loved the first Castlevania LoS. I was really excited the moment they shown the first trailer for the sequal over two years ago that I was highly anticipating this next installment.  When the reviews started coming out for the sequal I was upset what they were saying when I had high hopes for this game.  The negative comments seem to over embelish the quality of the game that it would get a D minus rating over issues such as the stealth portion, a shallow ending, and boring environments.  After playing this game I thought whoever was playing this game seem to be as bad as the critics, reviewing movies in that they are blind to what is an actual great movie when the majority movie going public seems to love the movie.  This game my fellow gamers is a great quality game.  Gone the fixed camera angels, you now have a free camera you can manipulate around the character to get a better view of Dracula and his environment.  The environment is breathtaking, The amount of work and detail that went into Dracula's castle and Castlevania City makes you take a moment to study the detail and architecture. The environment also reminds me they were trying a Castlevania SOTN where the city and castle are connected to each other. The gameplay is very smooth especially the combat portion. Gone are the Combat Cross, light and shadow magic systems in place are the Shadow Whip, Void Sword, and Chaos Claws.  My favorite weapon is Chaos Claws simply because it reminds me of using Hercules Gauntlets in God of War.  But interchanging between weapons is a fluid motion you can make awesome combos.  If I had to make any complaints about this game is the story.  It didn't feel fulfilling (ie character development)  especially the end.    I was disappointed with the last boss Satan. It would have been nice to fight him head on vice using (SPOILER ALERT) someone close to Dracula. Also I wish the ending had an epilogue like the first one. It sort of left a question mark on Dracula's fate.  Like I said the grips that people had of this game is minor.  The stealth system was interesting idea but in some place poorly executed. Like when Dracula is already powerful why does he need to avoid Satan's Elite Armored brutes? Some of the stealth puzzles can prove irritating for some people have to start over and over again namely sneaking past Pan's brother.  But after observing other players in how they pass him it became quite easy and a little scarey lol.  This is great game which I highly recommend if your fan of this genre or God Of War type games.  Additionally I am re-playing this game again. This is one of those games I hope they make a movie out of this game use this plot for the story.

reviewText:
This game is kind of a mixed bag with me, so I'll just list the pros and cons.

Pros
+Gameplay
The gameplay is quite a bit improved from the first game; camera is no longer locked, climbing is easier, items are actually useful this time, and there's items dedicated to helping you uncover secrets. I'm also quite fond of the openness, allowing you to go back at virtually any time to explore, collect items, etc.

+Graphics
Visually, the game is beautiful, and there's plenty of areas in the game that are simply stunning. Found myself taking in the view more than once.

+Combat
The mastery system rewards using different skills to enhance your weapons' power. Each of Dracula's weapons have their own specific use, similar to the first game, but are more than just enchanting your whip with magic this time around, giving you entirely different movesets for each weapon. Also you get to drink your enemies' blood.

+Music
The music of the first game was good, but it lacked any sort of memorability. The music in Lords of Shadow 2 is much better, although you'll hear a lot of the same tracks over and over. Somewhat of a hit and miss here, but a majority of the music is good enough that this is more of a pro than a con.

+Pacing
There was a lot of nothing in between the major events of the first game; the pacing was just kinda crap, in all honesty. There always seems to be something going on in LoS 2, it's easier to feel like you're actually doing something rather than roaming through some ruins without much of a goal, which was a major problem throughout the first third of the first game.

+Gabriel is More Interesting
I was completely incapable of feeling any sort of sympathy for Gabriel in the first game. He was a cardboard cutout of a character devoid of most emotion. In this one, however, he's a little more interesting simply because he is fairly PO'ed. Also he's the dark lord, he has a reputation to live up to. Thankfully, he does.

+Environment
As previously mentioned in the Graphics, the game is beautiful. The environment is also essential for this as well; for the areas that they created, the world is detailed and interesting. Areas are distinguishable from other places, and the concept of building a city on the ruined foundations of Dracula's castle is, honestly, quite interesting. It creates a distinctive gothic-type city that still seems reminiscent of Dracula's castle pre-ruin when you have opportunities to overlook the city.

+Lore
While the story blows (more on that later), it does have some intriguing lore to find, some of which indicating that the people of Castlevania City are fully aware that monsters and magic are a thing. It's definitely a turn from the original Castlevania games and other games such as Vampire: The Masquerade- Bloodlines where hiding the supernatural from the world was of the utmost importance. In Lords of Shadow 2, I find it intriguing that they accept, and are even fascinated by, the fact that there used to be werewolves, vampires, and even the siege against Dracula are merely documented as history and treated as such. Their history is as natural to them as our own is to us. This is certainly something I'd love to see expanded on in future games- maybe not Lords of Shadow, but other franchises where the supernatural is merely embraced as a part of history rather than hidden from the world for safety.


Cons
-It's Not Castlevania
You can add the title, give the characters the names, and everything else, but it still doesn't make it a Castlevania game. Let alone it's horridly out of place with half of the game taking place in a modern day city. To be perfectly honest, it feels more like Darksiders than Castlevania due to the themes throughout the game. The heart and spirit of the series is completely absent from Lords of Shadow, hence I only ever refer to it as Lords of Shadow.

-Story
I find it ironic that they rebooted Castlevania with an intended focus on story, and then ended up dropping the ball. The first game had an okay, albeit not-very-original story with Satan having Necron Syndrome and popping up literally out of nowhere at the end. Mirror of Fate was an atrocity of a game and explained jack squat. Similar problems are in LoS 2- Gabriel often finds himself back in what appears to be either the past of his memories of his castle. Honestly have no idea because it's never explained at all. His memories/past/whatever-the-fudge-is-going-on also has zero relevance to what's going on, aside from getting back his powers because reasons. There's also some Resident Evil bullcrap going on where the citizens are mutated by some demonic virus; this is so out of place it hurts. Everything else is fairly easy to follow, and there's some interesting things that do happen throughout the game, but it's nothing to write home about. Story is honestly not a good reason to play this game, and if it's what you're looking for, turn the other way.

Gabriel forgot how to Open Doors
Found a door? Guess what? You're going to have to pull a switch to open it. He's only a superhuman Prince of Darkness, godforbid he opens a metal door on his own. There's a lot of this crap that just slows the game down needlessly, especially since it takes forever for said doors to open. This game was made in 2014, this is rather inexcusable.

-Enemies can be Annoying
There's a guard/perfect guard mechanic in the game, which is quite useful. Unfortunately, roughly 50% of the time, the enemies perform an unblockable attack, which renders guarding a lot less useful than you'd like it to be. Also there's plenty of times where I simply wanted to get somewhere and didn't want to fight. Going places often involve climbing. Guess what? Every freaking enemy in the game can use some kind of projectile to knock you down, often forcing you to fight enemies when you don't want to. This is often infuriating when you merely want to explore for upgrades and other hidden items.

-Stealth Segments
Okay, I get that he's weak and whatnot at the beginning, but this just seems so unnecessary. Especially since the stealth segment with Agreus is absolutely infuriating.

-Bugs
Every now and then, characters may say something" without sound- basically the sound file for the line they're supposed to say doesn't play (no subtitles either

reviewText:
'Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2' isn't a good game... there I said it, it isn't good, but it is however, brilliant. The game seems to have this uncanny ability with me to make me keep wanting to come back for more (And I'm sure it's the same with many others) The Graphics are stunning and a pleasure to look at and each level seems to have been thought out in fantastic depth to provide the most fun for the person playing it.

The gameplay is as smooth as the previous game in the 'Lords of Shadow' series. The fighting is smooth an as fun as ever, and the array of new moves (And old ones with a new twist) just add more enjoyability to the game and truely make you feel like the all-powerful vampire that Gabriel Belmont is.

The story, as every is a pleasure to work through, with each character being able to snap your interest to them and not make you feel bored or fed up with the cutscenes. Lastly, something that deserves a mention, the boss battles in this game are just amazing, as fun as they look from the opening cutscene all the way to the end of it.

In conclusion, I would certainly recommend that people buy this game and if you do, I hope you have as much fun with it as I do.

This game is quite entertaining, despite not being like what I expected.

The game itself plays pretty much like the first Lords of Shadow. Game mechanics, movement and art style is very much the same. Very well executed, and especially the scenery of the game is nothing short of stunning!

The storyline, however, is a bit confusing to those who have not read up on what they are going into. The game is open-world, with some backtracking and exploration. Collectibles are hidden where you won't necessarily be able to get them first time around, which can be frustrating if you are not aware of what skills are necessery to get to them. Also, I had a hard time getting used to the fact that Dracula was running around in a modern world for a part of the game, and with the game happening one part in the modern day, and the other part in Draculas castle, the skips can be confusing.

The game however is quite fun, the dialogue is quite great, really moving moments that often surprised me in how much they made me care about the characters. Would recommend if you are a Castlevania fan, with an open mind.

reviewText:
If you're considering this, you already know it's hack and slash: and it delivers on that.

You hack. You slash. You're obviously very, very insane, but that's okay; being a rather old recently re-awakened vampire lord apparently does that. People complain that it doesn't live up to it's predecessor, but not having played the predecessor I can say this game is fine.
The stealth sections are very annoying, as most would say. Quite disposable, and shouldn't have been part of the game. More focus on puzzles would have been appreciated, instead.
Another big complaint is the city over the castle... the apocalyptic castle/moderncity is rather unique, and imho, still beautiful. At some parts it feels a little like the modern parts of the city desecrate the castle, but I think that's intentional, too.

COMPLAINTS:

You cannot play this without a controller. None of the keys are coreographed properly for quicktime, skill use or anything else (X, Y, A, B on EVERYTHING) You can re-map the keys and go through it (mostly) fine... with one, notable and game-shattering problem: navigating the skills menu. Unless it gives you a pop-up, you just can't, and that's a deal-breaker for PC support.

reviewText:
Honestly, i was going through a lot of these reviews, expecially from fans of the first game, and i was surprised by how much negatives came here. So this review will be focused in comparing the two games (I played the first on X360)

I will say that, only in my first 2 hours of gameplay, i felt comfortable to rely on the lore for my so expected ending of the story. And i need to point out that this is a great game, regardless of comparations with the first. Also, a lot of these reviews say negative stuff about the stealth moments, but i think it's good and important because you have to acompany the story, if Gabriel lost most of his power, how would he go against a creature of Satan? It's very important to the lore. And i cannot agree to you being a fan of the saga if you don't pay attention to the story. I feel like these moments show me that like in the first game, i had to become strong. Playing all the game with ultimate Dracula powers would be tiring, and most likely ruin the experience.

As to graphics, my system is not the best, but what i've seen in my game and videos, it doesn't leave a lot to be wished.

I really enjoyed the new mechanics of gameplay, especially Gabriel's (sorry, can't call him Dracula :////) new powers. this really feels like to play the first game, but much more complete than that. Something i dislike strongly is the new combat rythim, i can't get to use special attacks, because i'm 95% busy finding enough time to do so. Also, there are some times when you truly don't know what to do, and you have to perform some action too quickly. I found this very troublesome in some parts.

And the camera, oh, the camera. That's something MUCH better than in the first game, when the camera was placed in map-specific locations, and also had the problem of having to stop to ajust your controls, since they were kept on camera changes (40% of camera changes). Now, it's something much more subtle, the camera is controlled by the player, and stays in a 2nd/3rd person view which receives some influence in a few map areas (but nothing that forces the camera on a spot or a too strong change. It feels better because now it gives me the immersion of exploring the world. And of course, this is better because now i feel rewarded for looking for a nice view and finding an amazing view. It's very balanced.

I do recommend this game to everyone, best buy, worth all the money (altough i got it on a discount).

Please feel free to add me or comment on my profile with any disagreements or suggestions to this review.

I wished to give it 10/10, but the gameplay has a few artifacts in my point of view.

8.5/10

*Edit: When I first wrote the review, I was only almost done with the game, but now that I have seen it through to the end, I feel I have to amend a couple of my points, primarily with the story. The ending sucks. I won't spoil anything, but I must say it was quite a let down. Many unresolved questions and an unsatisfying end both in story and boss fight. It was easier than the first acolyte.
Looking at this game from a completed perspective, even before my edit, I can say that this game had a lot of potential and good ideas, but from what I've read had a botched development. It shows because a lot of the game feels incomplete or like the developers rushed to finish what was left after some development troubles. It's really a shame and very disappointing.*

I played the first Lords of Shadow and I enjoyed it. As for this one, I would say it's better in some areas and worse in others.

COMBAT: Compared to the first, it feels like they really smoothed out the combat in terms of how you move around and perform moves. some difficulties become clearer when it comes to one mechanic though: the way some enemies block in this game. When some enemies are blocking, they stop your combo and deflect your attack and zero damage is done. This can get really annoying when there are multiple enemies and you are attacking one that is open, but the one right next to the first is blocking. it will stop your combo. This makes engagements with multiple blocking enemies really annoying unless you are really good with your chaos energy (it's like the shadow energy from the first game and it breaks through shield and armor). Multiple skeletons are the most annoying thing in this game... That said, thankfully those kinds of enemies don't show up terribly often, and combat can still be very fun now that it's smoothed out.

STORY: Sadly, I would have to say the story in this game is inferior to the first overall. There is no longer an opening narration to each stage like their was in the first because of the way they made the map somewhat open world (I'll get into that further down). There are also seems to be less moments of significant plot progression throughout the game; a lot of times it feels as if you go a great distance just to get a small snippet of story. That said, one of the things that brought me back toward liking the game more were the story moments (they pick up more once you get a bit further) when you see the way Gabriel changes based on his interaction with the other characters. Some of them were very moving. Still, overall there just doesn't seem to be as much story as there was in the first game, and for Patrick Stewart in particular, it almost seems like a waste of his talent.

VISUALS: For the most part, I'm going to say that this game's visuals are gorgeous. Very pretty and detailed environments. Not a lot of more vibrant environments like the first game, but they are still very detailed and pretty, especially when the game's graphics are turned up. reviewText: This was my first Castlevania game so I went in not really knowing what to expect. First of all, the combat's fun, not played many hack'n'slash games and this made me wonder why, it's incredibly satisfying pulling off that perfect combo right after a successful synchronized block. Only real criticism I have of the combat is that there's not much of an incentive to try the special moves. When a game's this simple to beat and the enemies aren't overly difficult, nothing really forces you to have to pull off the special attacks, and you find yourself halfway through wondering if you're really getting the full experience because of your lack of variation in how you play combat-wise. Can't really comment on the exploration, as I've really no idea what makes someone want to explore a game world, some open worlds make you want to explore - some don't. I have no idea if it's to do with art style or hidden secrets, but I definitely wanted to explore the castle and find every secret there was to find, found myself spending hours just exploring different areas. Graphics-wise, this game looks amazing - found myself pressing F12 way more than I probably should have been, and I've changed my desktop to different screenshots about 5 times since I bought this game. The gothic architecture of the castle really gives the developers a chance to pull off some of the most stunning scenes, last-gen ports have never looked so good. Although I've never played the first LoS, I kinda felt myself wondering how great this game would be if it had the same setting, medieval Europe. I really dreaded the modern day parts of the game, the city was boring - everything looked the same, spent most of it hoping I'd see another castle sequence soon. Voice acting was great, can't really go wrong with a cast like Richard Madden, Robert Carlyle and Patrick Stewart, although when voice actors so famous play roles you can't help but see them as the actor as opposed to the character, because you've heard their voice so many times before. Characterisation wasn't the best, I wanted to see a Dracula that didn't start tearing up everytime he was reminded of his past, and he didn't really develop much throughout the story. Not going to go too into depth about stealth, all I'm going to say is that it was terrible and I'm glad it wasn't more prominent in the game. Story-wise, this game's brilliant, sometimes when the combat became a bit too repetitive and I was stuck in the city knowing I wouldn't see another medieval-esque area for a while, I was just hoping another cutscene would occur. The whole father-son dynamic between Trevor and Gabriel was really well-written and enjoyable to listen to, and although I complained about him being too emotional, I really liked the parts that Gabriel's human side showed in the scenes with his family. Boss fights were one of my favourite parts of the game, it was different every time and it forced you to adapt to the situation as opposed to just hitting and dodging, only criticism is that the dialogue during the fights could be improved as I heard the same line over 50 times when fighting some bosses. Can't really think of any other elements of the game to comment on. Overall I'd say this game is definitely worth getting - not got much replayability but the first playthrough is worth the money. Despite its many drawbacks like stealth and poor setting - the art style, voice acting, combat and story do more than enough to make up for it.

reviewText:
Not without its faults, but still quite enjoyable.

After playing the full game. I certainly do not feel it deseved such low critic scores. Are there some issues, of course. But on the whole, I still had fun with it, and that's what it all boils down to. If you want some handy bullet points on the matter:

Pros:
* Combat is very fluid, and there are a number of attacks and options at your disposal
* The Boss battles are the real showstoppers in terms of granduer and excitement, and are the high points of the game, and each one of them is unique.
* Platforming is also very fast and has definitely been streamlined from the original
* The Castle setting is simply beautiful and really makes the player want to explore it
* Game is super optimized and runs amazingly well on most machines. Played at 1080p with all settings maxed at a constant 60fps
* The musical score is just so well put together and a treat to listen to, fitting the action on screen perfectly

Cons:
* The game starts off slow after the prologue, focusing a lot on the modern day section
* The modern day section is sadly lacking in terms of creativity and imagination. Was expecting something more unique from a modern day Satanic laboratory (especially compared to Frankenstein's Lab or the Toymakers Workshop from the previous games) for instance.
* Most time in the modern day is spent underground or in corridors, opposed to the more visually pleasing areas such as the Arts District.
* The Stealth sections needed more variety to be interesting, or should have been limited to just a few segments. Though they still only take a few minutes to do. Too much of a big deal was made about one stealth segment in particular, only because people forgot about the handy Mist ability.
* The ending is somewhat inconclusive and the final segment leading up to it lacks any real sense of build up.

reviewText:
8/10

My only actual complaint was that the game was too short. I beat my first run on the second hardest difficulty (considered hardest until you beat it... semi-smart idea for a rerun) in about six hours, and that's with finding most of the collectables along the way. The reason why I have so many hours put into this is because I actually like walking around and beating stuff up; it's that fun to do it.

My other complaint (but rather a nitpick) was the difficulty. Even on the hardest I found the game is way too easy, but that's maybe because of my experience with these types of games. Others will say it's hard and I won't disagree with them. Some people can work with it while others can't.

I enjoyed the story (Though how well it connected with the first game was pretty stale) but really wished that they put a lot more time into it for a full price game (that 6$ off because of pre-order did help slightly). The combat is fun to play around with and the idea of upgrading your weapon is interesting but the makers kept it simple, which is alright.

I'd recommend it to anyone once the price goes down or if it goes on sale. 6 hours runtime for 60$ is kind of disappointing, especially with a decently good story behind it.

Until then!

reviewText:
Lords of Shadow 2 is a great game when it wants to be but unfortunately it's marred by misguided forced stealth sequences and a story that goes nowhere until the tail end of the adventure. The modern setting looks more like a faux Resident Evil than it does Castlevania and the game only really shines when it will occasionally go back to its familiar Gothic locale.

It's not all bad though, the combat is really great and even by the end you'll still be pumping points into it to unlock new combos. It's also a very gorgeous game and is a fantastic PC port.

Lords of Shadow 2 is a disappointment more than anything. The series had amazing potential after the underrated Lords of Shadow in 2010 but it's all been squandered here with head scratching design choices and plot that just plods along until it feels like pushing forward. This is a game only for those who have put their time in with the two games before it and really want to experience the ending of the trilogy.

reviewText:
First, let me get this out of the way:

I am a big Castlevania fan. I got into the series during the GBA days (for the record I was about thirteen when Circle of the Moon came out). I played it, I played Harmony of Dissonance, Aria of Sorrow, both the DS Castlevania games, and yes... I wish they'd go back to those... but that doesn't mean this is a bad game.

The voice acting is good, the combat is fun and engaging, the level design is interesting (especially the bits in Dracula's castle), and it has some of the most imaginative bosses I've seen (the Toymaker is a special favorite).

... it just doesn't play like a Castlevania game.

Its neat to play as Dracula, its neat to have to fight as a vampire and use vampiric powers, and damn if I didn't let out a laugh when I saw what happened to that Chupacabra ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ from the first game.

... but it feels more like God of War.

Its by no means a bad game! I had fun with it! The giant robot fight at the beginning was lovably nuts and the fight against Death was really intense and actually almost killed me more than a few times.

... but it just doesn't feel like a Castlevania game.

So, go into it not thinking of it as a Castlevania game. Think of it as a game where you play an ancient vampire who was awoken to fight off invaders to his realm and who has to learn to act and fight in a modern day world and regain his powers after his long slumber.

Its great, its a hell of a lot of fun. Its just... not really a 'Castlevania' game.

'Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2' isn't a good game... there I said it, it isn't good, but it is however, brilliant. The game seems to have this uncanny ability with me to make me keep wanting to come back for more (And I'm sure it's the same with many others) The Graphics are stunning and a pleasure to look at and each level seems to have been thought out in fantastic depth to provide the most fun for the person playing it.

The story, as every is a pleasure to work through, with each character being able to snap your interest to them and not make you feel bored or fed up with the cutscenes. Lastly, something that deserves a mention, the boss battles in this game are just amazing, as fun as they look from the opening cutscene all the way to the end of it.

In conclusion, I would certainly recommend that people buy this game and if you do, I hope you have as much fun with it as I do.

reviewText:
This game is almost the perfect balance of right and wrong game design.

The Good: The hack and slash gameplay is incredibly fun. The leveling system for your weapons actually requires you to try out different combos in order to max out and get points to make the weapon stronger, which encourages trying new attack patterns and not using the same, one effective combo over and over again (*cough* God of War *cough*). The character models are very detailed and the voice acting is pretty spot on. Not to mention the level design is absolutely gorgeous when you're in the castle. The bosses have memorable designs and battles. And I loved the open world to explore that wasn't of the MetroidVania design.

The Bad: Despite the game throwing hordes of different looking enemies at you, they oddly enough don't feel too varied. The game constantly shifts back and forth betwen the modern city evironment and Dracula's castle, but it feels kinda hectic and you almost never do anything in the city; Kinda like they just didn't have much planned out for it. The story is actually pretty awful and does an almost complete nose dive in the last hour or so and ends with one of the weakest plot resolutions I think I've seen in a long time, even though everything up to that point in the writing feels pretty sturdy; Almost as if the writer just stopped caring when the game was almost finished. And the stealth sections are absolutely terrible. They're the kind where you only have ONE way to go about getting through each section and it never changes EVER. The game designed one specific enemy for you to encounter during this sections which kill you easily. This is explained by Zobek saying you're too weak to fight them. If you're familiar with old vampire lore, you know they can take different animal shapes, typically being of the night time variety (wolves, bats, etc.) but the game only lets you change into one animal, being rats. But both these points really fall through at the end when you're pretty much a full strength Dracula and you're still having to sneak past these things disguised as rats.

I don't really know if I'd recomend this or not. I mean, I did enjoy the game for the most part. But if you're wanting to play this because you enjoyed the last one as I did and really wanted to see how things would end for Gabriel, all I can say is, without giving any spoilers, I couldn't have felt like I got a bigger slap in the face. But if you don't care about the story and want to play a beautiful game with some of the best hack and slash I've seen in a while, I say try.

EDIT: I decided to give this game a recommendation because despite its flaws it was one of the better games of 2014. I suppose that's some merit

reviewText:
Did you like the first game in this series? Well, you might find this one annoying then.

The first major problem is that unlike the first game, this one is much shorter. You can beat it in about 6-8 hours. That's a decent run time, but then you realize there is nothing else. The game even feels like less is going on, even when a lot of stuff is happening. And not in a good way.

The story is this:
Gabriel Belmont is Dracula. He wants to die. Because being Dracula is really rough. Now it's the future, and he wakes up. Death shows up and tells Dracula that if they defeat Satan together, than Dracula can have a weapon that will give him eternal rest. Dracula agrees, and it's off to hunt down three of Satan's kids to save the world.

Seems like a simple story, right? Well, it kinda isn't. Dracula ends up world hopping from time to time. This means he travels between two totally different world maps. A city, and a castle. The castle is a highly detailed and very pretty wonderland. It's well designed, tons of interesting enemies, and great atmosphere. The castle areas are the best enviornments in the game. Unfortunetly, the castle areas are also home to the worst bits of story. You mostly spend time running around, talking to characters from related to the lore. This also includes Dracula's dead wife and son, who ask you to preform fetch quests for them. At the end, you fight Dracula's inner evil, and the castle section is dead forever. No more use out that.

The city on the other hand is the worst. Everything is grey and looks alike. All the good will of the castle and it's varied enviornments is sucked away by the fact that Dracula can't jump over a fence. Running around the city area is difficult too, as the layout is poor and often trying to cram too much into too little space. I got lost a great number of times just trying to go back the way I came because they force you to take different routes all the time. The enemies are mutated humans who somehow manage to be able to block your strongest attacks by using a shotgun as a shield. The other enemies are humans in mech suits, which are easily amongst the most annoying since they fly outside your range and have high damage dealing guns. They even come equiped with shields to block the attacks that do land.

But the City part is where all the story happens. All the important, interesting, story details go on in the city. But the boss battles suffer even then. Boss fights in the city are single stage moments with more cutscene than combat, in comparison to the more interesting and BETTER boss fights found at the castle. Clearly there was a conflict during development.

The game seems split most of the time actually. It feels like there was a great deal of splits amongst the developers, as some stuff feels a lot less fleshed out. Especially since the ending is flat and awful. Nothing feels resolved, and I guess this was done so that you would still be able to free roam through the city and pick up the collectables you missed.

And now, for something that some may be a bit confused by. But the game needed more Quick Time Events. OR at least a better allocation of those QTEs. Let me explain. The bosses are completely void of quick time events. But, there is still a quick time event to open a door. The QTEs for the bosses was deemed LESS important than the QTEs to open the door. It just seems odd to me. And in a way makes the ability to turn off QTEs utterly pointless since there aren't enough to justify the option.

The combat is better though. The gameplay has been improved. But oddly enough, the difficulty has raised quite a lot. But not in the good way. Instead of making the enemies more interesting to fight, they no longer stagger, have more health, and tend to swarm. Most have shields that require a three hit combo from your chaos guantlets. The chaos guantlets are really slow, have poor range, drain magic, and the enemies tend to dodge after the second hit, so the third hit rarely hits. And that's if you even manage to get a full combo off since the enemies attack so often you spend most of your time dodging instead of attacking. The game even brings in enemies later in the game who summon more enemies, and have unblockable attacks.

The game isn't bad. But is a sad sequel to the first Lords of Shadow.

reviewText: I loved the first Castlevania LoS. I was really excited the moment they shown the first trailer for the sequal over two years ago that I was highly anticipating this next installment.  When the reviews started coming out for the sequal I was upset what they were saying when I had high hopes for this game.  The negative comments seem to over embelish the quality of the game that it would get a D minus rating over issues such as the stealth portion, a shallow ending, and boring environments.  After playing this game I thought whoever was playing this game seem to be as bad as the critics, reviewing movies in that they are blind to what is an actual great movie when the majority movie going public seems to love the movie.  This game my fellow gamers is a great quality game.  Gone the fixed camera angels, you now have a free camera you can manipulate around the character to get a better view of Dracula and his environment.  The environment is breathtaking, The amount of work and detail that went into Dracula's castle and Castlevania City makes you take a moment to study the detail and architecture. The environment also reminds me they were trying a Castlevania SOTN where the city and castle are connected to each other. The gameplay is very smooth especially the combat portion. Gone are the Combat Cross, light and shadow magic systems in place are the Shadow Whip, Void Sword, and Chaos Claws.  My favorite weapon is Chaos Claws simply because it reminds me of using Hercules Gauntlets in God of War.  But interchanging between weapons is a fluid motion you can make awesome combos.  If I had to make any complaints about this game is the story.  It didn't feel fulfilling (ie character development)  especially the end.    I was disappointed with the last boss Satan. It would have been nice to fight him head on vice using (SPOILER ALERT) someone close to Dracula. Also I wish the ending had an epilogue like the first one. It sort of left a question mark on Dracula's fate.  Like I said the grips that people had of this game is minor.  The stealth system was interesting idea but in some place poorly executed. Like when Dracula is already powerful why does he need to avoid Satan's Elite Armored brutes? Some of the stealth puzzles can prove irritating for some people have to start over and over again namely sneaking past Pan's brother.  But after observing other players in how they pass him it became quite easy and a little scarey lol.  This is great game which I highly recommend if your fan of this genre or God Of War type games.  Additionally I am re-playing this game again. This is one of those games I hope they make a movie out of this game use this plot for the story.
