reviewText:
As an avid fan of the Castlevania series, I will say most of the 3D entries have been mostly mediocre.  Some had good ideas marred by poor controls (N64 games) while others had tedious gameplay with excellent music and atmosphere (Lament of Innocence and Curse of Darkness).

Then 2010 rolled around and Lords of Shadow came out.  Another 3D Castlevania that I had zero expectations for but still an almost forced obligation to try...and it blew me away.  Amazing graphics, gripping story, phenomenal soundtrack, varied enemy encounters, huge boss fights, and a simple on the surface but surprisingly deep combat system in the vein of God of War (this doesn't have to be an insult, people) gave a shockingly well rounded package that earned the game some high sales and critical praise the series hadn't seen in a long time.  It had its faults, namely a camera that couldn't be controlled and a somewhat slow beginning, but the series seemed to be headed in a positive direction.

A few years later we got Mirror of Fate, a sort of in-betweener entry to bind the stories of LOS1 and LOS2.  It also marked a return to the side-scrolling roots with flashes of SOTN style gameplay.  The story was interesting but markedly less central compared to LOS.  Still, the gameplay was mostly interesting, a little different, and again had a wonderful score.

With the announcement of certain features like a seamless world and a controlled camera, LOS2 had a lot to live up to.  For the most part it delivers, though it definitely has its flaws.  Rather than continue on with the paragraphs at length, I'll make some easy to peruse pros and cons lists.

PROS:
-The story is still well told and interesting, voice actors all nail their roles (specifically Robert Carlyle and Jason Isaacs).
-The soundtrack is still amazing.
-Gameplay remains mostly unchanged, though there is less emphasis on puzzle solving.
-Good length, around 15-20 hours depending on how much secret hunting you engage in.
-Lots of neat references to classic entries.
-Dracula's castle offers some cool, varied areas.
-Weapon mastery/skill tree system rewards experimentation and discourages 'spamming.'

CONS:
-Seamless world exploration is hurt by an incredibly weak map system.  Opening the map in the menu only lets you see a very small portion of the area you are in, and you can't cycle between them.  There are also a scant number of teleportation rooms, making backtracking quite painful.
-Difficulty seemed all over the place.  I found most bosses very easy and generally struggled more with the regular enemy encounters.
-The modern city you explore has that Gothic Castlevania feel to it, but unfortunately most of the areas are hard to differentiate.
-Ending is rather abrupt and anti-climactic.

As for the now infamous 'stealth' sections, I can safely say they have been completely overblown in just about every review.  Yes, they are by no means a good part of the game.  However they are very simple and account for less than 45 minutes or so of game time.  Don't let that be what sways your heart on the game.

Although it has a few questionable design choices, for the most part I can give a positive recommendation for LOS2.  Arguably one of the best facets of the series is that each game brings something different to the table.  LOS was about the closest we've gotten to a (fun) 3D classic Castlevania, Mirror of Fate was more along the lines of a 2D SOTN/Circle of the Moon type game, and LOS2 was an attempt to merge the two.  None of them are perfect, but the series hasn't been this interesting in over a decade.  I look forward to whatever Mercury Steam does next, and we will see what future Castlevanias have in store for us.

reviewText: This was my first Castlevania game so I went in not really knowing what to expect. First of all, the combat's fun, not played many hack'n'slash games and this made me wonder why, it's incredibly satisfying pulling off that perfect combo right after a successful synchronized block. Only real criticism I have of the combat is that there's not much of an incentive to try the special moves. When a game's this simple to beat and the enemies aren't overly difficult, nothing really forces you to have to pull off the special attacks, and you find yourself halfway through wondering if you're really getting the full experience because of your lack of variation in how you play combat-wise. Can't really comment on the exploration, as I've really no idea what makes someone want to explore a game world, some open worlds make you want to explore - some don't. I have no idea if it's to do with art style or hidden secrets, but I definitely wanted to explore the castle and find every secret there was to find, found myself spending hours just exploring different areas. Graphics-wise, this game looks amazing - found myself pressing F12 way more than I probably should have been, and I've changed my desktop to different screenshots about 5 times since I bought this game. The gothic architecture of the castle really gives the developers a chance to pull off some of the most stunning scenes, last-gen ports have never looked so good. Although I've never played the first LoS, I kinda felt myself wondering how great this game would be if it had the same setting, medieval Europe. I really dreaded the modern day parts of the game, the city was boring - everything looked the same, spent most of it hoping I'd see another castle sequence soon. Voice acting was great, can't really go wrong with a cast like Richard Madden, Robert Carlyle and Patrick Stewart, although when voice actors so famous play roles you can't help but see them as the actor as opposed to the character, because you've heard their voice so many times before. Characterisation wasn't the best, I wanted to see a Dracula that didn't start tearing up everytime he was reminded of his past, and he didn't really develop much throughout the story. Not going to go too into depth about stealth, all I'm going to say is that it was terrible and I'm glad it wasn't more prominent in the game. Story-wise, this game's brilliant, sometimes when the combat became a bit too repetitive and I was stuck in the city knowing I wouldn't see another medieval-esque area for a while, I was just hoping another cutscene would occur. The whole father-son dynamic between Trevor and Gabriel was really well-written and enjoyable to listen to, and although I complained about him being too emotional, I really liked the parts that Gabriel's human side showed in the scenes with his family. Boss fights were one of my favourite parts of the game, it was different every time and it forced you to adapt to the situation as opposed to just hitting and dodging, only criticism is that the dialogue during the fights could be improved as I heard the same line over 50 times when fighting some bosses. Can't really think of any other elements of the game to comment on. Overall I'd say this game is definitely worth getting - not got much replayability but the first playthrough is worth the money. reviewText:
Not without its faults, but still quite enjoyable.

After playing the full game. I certainly do not feel it deseved such low critic scores. Are there some issues, of course. But on the whole, I still had fun with it, and that's what it all boils down to. If you want some handy bullet points on the matter:

Pros:
* Combat is very fluid, and there are a number of attacks and options at your disposal
* The Boss battles are the real showstoppers in terms of granduer and excitement, and are the high points of the game, and each one of them is unique.
* Platforming is also very fast and has definitely been streamlined from the original
* The Castle setting is simply beautiful and really makes the player want to explore it
* Game is super optimized and runs amazingly well on most machines. Played at 1080p with all settings maxed at a constant 60fps
* The musical score is just so well put together and a treat to listen to, fitting the action on screen perfectly

Cons:
* The game starts off slow after the prologue, focusing a lot on the modern day section
* The modern day section is sadly lacking in terms of creativity and imagination. Was expecting something more unique from a modern day Satanic laboratory (especially compared to Frankenstein's Lab or the Toymakers Workshop from the previous games) for instance.
* Most time in the modern day is spent underground or in corridors, opposed to the more visually pleasing areas such as the Arts District.
* The Stealth sections needed more variety to be interesting, or should have been limited to just a few segments. Though they still only take a few minutes to do. Too much of a big deal was made about one stealth segment in particular, only because people forgot about the handy Mist ability.
* The ending is somewhat inconclusive and the final segment leading up to it lacks any real sense of build up.

reviewText:
Shortly: (trying no to tell any spoilers and and I didn't play the DLC: Revelations)
Basically, the game is a sequel for the original Castlevania: Lords of Shadow and the Castlevania: Mirror of Fate games, and it continues the story of Dracula (Gabriel Belmont) thousand years after the events of those 2 games.

The game is staged on a modern era, where Satan is once again trying to destroy the world of men with the help of his Acolytes.

Unlike in the original LoS game, this time the game is a openworld game, however you can only travel to new areas AFTER you've aquired a certain powerup to access them. And like in all openworld games, this one also has fast-travel system, but its pretty primitive.

There are 2 different worlds that you can travel, the modern era where the Satan's forcers brings havoc and the Dracula's Castle where the Dracula's own blood is trying to trap you.

Graphics are decent, sounds and voice actings are doreable. The battle system is slightly better than it was in the original LoS, but at the same time it feels a little bit watered down from what it was.

The overall story is a cliche, because you can easily predict that what's about to happen. However, it is interesting enough to see it through. The ending itself however was a disappointment for me, because there's no conclusion, but that's just my opinion.


Pros:
+ Battle and upgrade systems
+ Boss encounters (though the last boss was disappointment)
+ Lots of different enemies
+ Lots of collectables for those interested
+ Over 20 hours of gameplay if you collect every collectable like I did

Cons:
- Disappointing last boss
- Awful Fast-travel system (though you only need it when you're searching for collectables)
- Lots of annoying enemies at the end
- Bad ending (there's no conclusion in my opinion but then again I didn't play the revelations DLC)
- The Shop's location is bad, because getting some of the collectables requires a certain item that can only be bought from the shop, so you need to visit it a lot
- Kleido's Challenges offer no reward except a few Steam achievements
- Few un-skippable cutscenes and events such as the slow paced transition between the modern era - Dracula's Castle


Do I recommend ?:
If you're interested to see what happens to the Dracula after the events of Lords of Shadow and Mirror of Fate, then this might interest you. But if you haven't played those 2 games before, don't care about the story and are only interested for the action, then don't bother.

Verdict: 6 / 10 - Slightly good game
( 1 = Do-not-bother game
5 = Average game
10 = Must own game )

reviewText:
I played both Lords of Shadow back to back. I definitely liked this game, and do wish there was a third ready to queue up.

Overall it was a great game, with amazing visuals, great story, and an amazing soundtrack. However, it was an interesting mix of strengths and weaknesses, some being very different than the 1st game. I would say that its 1st strength is how powerfully it started, I was drawn into the story immediately and even felt goosebumps as the 1st cut scene gracefully sets the stage of what Gabriel has become, complete in its gothic splendor of visuals, music, and of being loathed by the locals and probably even by himself. It’s the type of vampire that I wish could replace the entire Twilight series. If you’ve read the Anne Rice novels, I noticed many details that were alike.

The 1st hour was a blast, then come an hour of wondering if this game was going to turn horrible, followed with an awkward climb back to awesome, and luckily it stayed there til’ the end of the game.

The bad: There were many things that weren’t explained in the 2nd hour which made the story seem artificial, luckily everything started making sense as you put the pieces together yourself, that’s if you didn’t bail in the meantime and read every piece of lore you found. Often there wasn’t enough of a visual clue to know what to do next, I found myself running through the same halls over and over again, trying to find that one thing I missed and now I can’t move on. Finally, the final boss is Satan, and you never really fought him, and then he was “dead”. Game over, time for DLC-expansion. Just so awkward.

The end result is we have lots of 10/10 experiences mixed with subpar experiences, leaving you wanting more if you made it far enough to understand its style, but also hoping they’re learning from their mistakes and that they figure they’re ♥♥♥♥ out. I would probably relate my enjoyment to watching the beginning seasons of Dr. Who, of which they luckily got their ♥♥♥♥ figured out which is apparent in later seasons.

reviewText:
A masterpiece.

This game furthers the fantastic story-telling from Lords of Shadow and ramps up the gameplay variety. The game now offers more of an open world to explore and its elements remind me of the gameplay of Batman: Arkham Asylum. The music is brilliant, the visuals (not to mention the concept art) are stunning, the gameplay is fun, varied and challenging, and the story is probably my favourite of all the Castlevania games. There are also a lot of callbacks to previous Castlevania games, and the story of Lords of Shadow 2 cements a kind of retconning of the series into a fresh and remarkably rich canon. Some old favourites of the series make a triumphant return...!

Read on for a few spoilers...
.
.
.
.
.
.

The only drawbacks to this game are 1) finding every secret is extremely time consuming and at times frustrating - the little caches of 500 EXP are next to worthless and expend a Dodo and a lot of time if you haven't got the Dungeon Key to open it; and 2) there was something about the ending that was a bit off (not unlike Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 1). The finale leaves the story open for a sequel but I doubt that will happen. After all the moving scenes with Gabriel and his memories of Marie and his son Trevor, you'd think that the ending would match that level of drama, but it didn't. The game is exciting and its story matches the blaring crescendos of its musical score all the way through, until it kind of falls flat at the very end. I'm reminded of my disappointment that Gabriel only becomes Dracula in the DLC of Lords of Shadow 1. Nevertheless, the story is compelling (again, probably the best of any Castlevania I've played) and the game's world is built masterfully.

reviewText:
- Graphics :

Very very good. Few glitches here & there. Still wondering why Dracul would have a shadow but no reflection (because they're kind of the same thing...). But a very nice and polished game graphically speaking. Artistic direction is... you know, quite nice. The environment are less numerous than in the previous game considering we really have two sets : the castle & the modern town, but both are cool to explore (yes, even the modern world).

- Sound & Musics :

Voice acting is yet again very good, musics are kind of below the quality of the first game's ones.

- Gameplay :

A bit better than the first game : it's still the same thinking but with more variety (you got a whip, your fists & a sword this time), the moves are really fun to launch and there's more strategy this time. The boss fights have also improved.... 'xcept the last one...

- Storytelling :

So, it's the conclusion, and all in all it's not that bad but there's one thing that totally ruined it for me : the ending. The last battle & the ending following that is one of the worst I've seen. Last battle : too easy and not at all making you feel involved in it. And the ending was totally rushed, it just sucks. This whole ending was completely rushed.

- Length :

Half the time you'll need to complete the first LoS, this game is much shorter (partly due to the fact that it's much easier)


CONCLUSION :

IT'S NOT A BAD GAME. You need to remember that. BUT:  it's lacking a lot in the storytelling (especially nearing the end) & in environment. I still recommend it because the whole experience isn't a bad one... not just the epic game everyone was expecting.....

reviewText:
To be perfectly honest, if you want more Lords of Shadow, you're better off replaying the first game.

I feel this one really missed the mark, and after reading about the internal struggles of the development team and their near-constant battle with their director, I can say I'm not really surprised.

Lords of Shadow 2 is, in every way, inferior to its predecessor. Graphically, it fails to impress. Mechanically, it feels sloppy. The combat is frustrating and choppy and, while LoS1 had its fair share of controller-throwing platforming segments, LoS2 doesn't even justify its own such moments with an equal helping of fun, satisfying ones. I have only put a couple hours into the game so far, and already I'm mad at it. I cannot comment on the overall story yet, but the beginning feels rushed and strange, and I have to feel bad for Patrick Stewart being forced to deliver such a petty script as Zobek. The writing is childish and uninspired, and the semi-animated lore sequence explaining the Belmont lineage is utterly boring.

But you know, I could forgive all of that if the game didn't so completely miss its own point. At no time during play did I ever FEEL like Dracula, who is supposed to be an absolute powerhouse, combining strength, speed, and magical abilities to devastate ranks upon ranks of foes. The most basic of enemies can take a monumental beating from any of your weapons, and can even attack straight through your combos to strike you. One minor strike from an enemy, however, will interrupt your combo and send you flying, which makes your stature feel pitiful, even if you aren't taking significant damage from those attacks. These problems are only magnified and exacerbated when, after the tutorial sequence, the story fast-forwards some centuries and resets all of Gabriel's powers, requiring you to slowly unlock them, one by one.

Other games have successfully portrayed their protagonists as extremely powerful beings without robbing the game of its core challenge. A great case in point is Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine. Lords of Shadow 2, however, takes the legendary Dracula and nerfs him into the ground, and then poops all over him with bad gameplay mechanics.

I'll say it again: if you want more LoS, play the first game again, because you'll enjoy it a whole lot more.

.
.
.
.

The only drawbacks to this game are 1) finding every secret is extremely time consuming and at times frustrating - the little caches of 500 EXP are next to worthless and expend a Dodo and a lot of time if you haven't got the Dungeon Key to open it; and 2) there was something about the ending that was a bit off (not unlike Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 1). The finale leaves the story open for a sequel but I doubt that will happen. After all the moving scenes with Gabriel and his memories of Marie and his son Trevor, you'd think that the ending would match that level of drama, but it didn't. The game is exciting and its story matches the blaring crescendos of its musical score all the way through, until it kind of falls flat at the very end. I'm reminded of my disappointment that Gabriel only becomes Dracula in the DLC of Lords of Shadow 1. Nevertheless, the story is compelling (again, probably the best of any Castlevania I've played) and the game's world is built masterfully.

reviewText:
Shortly: (trying no to tell any spoilers and and I didn't play the DLC: Revelations)
Basically, the game is a sequel for the original Castlevania: Lords of Shadow and the Castlevania: Mirror of Fate games, and it continues the story of Dracula (Gabriel Belmont) thousand years after the events of those 2 games.

The game is staged on a modern era, where Satan is once again trying to destroy the world of men with the help of his Acolytes.

Unlike in the original LoS game, this time the game is a openworld game, however you can only travel to new areas AFTER you've aquired a certain powerup to access them. And like in all openworld games, this one also has fast-travel system, but its pretty primitive.

There are 2 different worlds that you can travel, the modern era where the Satan's forcers brings havoc and the Dracula's Castle where the Dracula's own blood is trying to trap you.

Graphics are decent, sounds and voice actings are doreable. The battle system is slightly better than it was in the original LoS, but at the same time it feels a little bit watered down from what it was.

The overall story is a cliche, because you can easily predict that what's about to happen. However, it is interesting enough to see it through. The ending itself however was a disappointment for me, because there's no conclusion, but that's just my opinion.


Pros:
+ Battle and upgrade systems
+ Boss encounters (though the last boss was disappointment)
+ Lots of different enemies
+ Lots of collectables for those interested
+ Over 20 hours of gameplay if you collect every collectable like I did

Cons:
- Disappointing last boss
- Awful Fast-travel system (though you only need it when you're searching for collectables)
- Lots of annoying enemies at the end
- Bad ending (there's no conclusion in my opinion but then again I didn't play the revelations DLC)
- The Shop's location is bad, because getting some of the collectables requires a certain item that can only be bought from the shop, so you need to visit it a lot
- Kleido's Challenges offer no reward except a few Steam achievements
- Few un-skippable cutscenes and events such as the slow paced transition between the modern era - Dracula's Castle


Do I recommend ?:
If you're interested to see what happens to the Dracula after the events of Lords of Shadow and Mirror of Fate, then this might interest you. But if you haven't played those 2 games before, don't care about the story and are only interested for the action, then don't bother.

Verdict: 6 / 10 - Slightly good game
( 1 = Do-not-bother game
5 = Average game
10 = Must own game )

reviewText:
- Graphics :

Very very good. Few glitches here & there. Still wondering why Dracul would have a shadow but no reflection (because they're kind of the same thing...). But a very nice and polished game graphically speaking. Artistic direction is... you know, quite nice. The environment are less numerous than in the previous game considering we really have two sets : the castle & the modern town, but both are cool to explore (yes, even the modern world).

- Sound & Musics :

Voice acting is yet again very good, musics are kind of below the quality of the first game's ones.

- Gameplay :

A bit better than the first game : it's still the same thinking but with more variety (you got a whip, your fists & a sword this time), the moves are really fun to launch and there's more strategy this time. The boss fights have also improved.... 'xcept the last one...

- Storytelling :

So, it's the conclusion, and all in all it's not that bad but there's one thing that totally ruined it for me : the ending. The last battle & the ending following that is one of the worst I've seen. Last battle : too easy and not at all making you feel involved in it. And the ending was totally rushed, it just sucks. This whole ending was completely rushed.

- Length :

Half the time you'll need to complete the first LoS, this game is much shorter (partly due to the fact that it's much easier)


CONCLUSION :

IT'S NOT A BAD GAME. You need to remember that. BUT:  it's lacking a lot in the storytelling (especially nearing the end) & in environment. I still recommend it because the whole experience isn't a bad one... not just the epic game everyone was expecting.....

reviewText:
Lords of Shadow 2 is a great game when it wants to be but unfortunately it's marred by misguided forced stealth sequences and a story that goes nowhere until the tail end of the adventure. The modern setting looks more like a faux Resident Evil than it does Castlevania and the game only really shines when it will occasionally go back to its familiar Gothic locale.

It's not all bad though, the combat is really great and even by the end you'll still be pumping points into it to unlock new combos. It's also a very gorgeous game and is a fantastic PC port.

Lords of Shadow 2 is a disappointment more than anything. The series had amazing potential after the underrated Lords of Shadow in 2010 but it's all been squandered here with head scratching design choices and plot that just plods along until it feels like pushing forward. This is a game only for those who have put their time in with the two games before it and really want to experience the ending of the trilogy.

reviewText:
This game is kind of a mixed bag with me, so I'll just list the pros and cons.

Pros
+Gameplay
The gameplay is quite a bit improved from the first game; camera is no longer locked, climbing is easier, items are actually useful this time, and there's items dedicated to helping you uncover secrets. I'm also quite fond of the openness, allowing you to go back at virtually any time to explore, collect items, etc.

+Graphics
Visually, the game is beautiful, and there's plenty of areas in the game that are simply stunning. Found myself taking in the view more than once.

+Combat
The mastery system rewards using different skills to enhance your weapons' power. Each of Dracula's weapons have their own specific use, similar to the first game, but are more than just enchanting your whip with magic this time around, giving you entirely different movesets for each weapon. Also you get to drink your enemies' blood.

+Music
The music of the first game was good, but it lacked any sort of memorability. The music in Lords of Shadow 2 is much better, although you'll hear a lot of the same tracks over and over. Somewhat of a hit and miss here, but a majority of the music is good enough that this is more of a pro than a con.

+Pacing
There was a lot of nothing in between the major events of the first game; the pacing was just kinda crap, in all honesty. There always seems to be something going on in LoS 2, it's easier to feel like you're actually doing something rather than roaming through some ruins without much of a goal, which was a major problem throughout the first third of the first game.

+Gabriel is More Interesting
I was completely incapable of feeling any sort of sympathy for Gabriel in the first game. He was a cardboard cutout of a character devoid of most emotion. In this one, however, he's a little more interesting simply because he is fairly PO'ed. Also he's the dark lord, he has a reputation to live up to. Thankfully, he does.

+Environment
As previously mentioned in the Graphics, the game is beautiful. The environment is also essential for this as well; for the areas that they created, the world is detailed and interesting. Areas are distinguishable from other places, and the concept of building a city on the ruined foundations of Dracula's castle is, honestly, quite interesting. It creates a distinctive gothic-type city that still seems reminiscent of Dracula's castle pre-ruin when you have opportunities to overlook the city.

+Lore
While the story blows (more on that later), it does have some intriguing lore to find, some of which indicating that the people of Castlevania City are fully aware that monsters and magic are a thing. It's definitely a turn from the original Castlevania games and other games such as Vampire: The Masquerade- Bloodlines where hiding the supernatural from the world was of the utmost importance. In Lords of Shadow 2, I find it intriguing that they accept, and are even fascinated by, the fact that there used to be werewolves, vampires, and even the siege against Dracula are merely documented as history and treated as such. Their history is as natural to them as our own is to us. This is certainly something I'd love to see expanded on in future games- maybe not Lords of Shadow, but other franchises where the supernatural is merely embraced as a part of history rather than hidden from the world for safety.


Cons
-It's Not Castlevania
You can add the title, give the characters the names, and everything else, but it still doesn't make it a Castlevania game. Let alone it's horridly out of place with half of the game taking place in a modern day city. To be perfectly honest, it feels more like Darksiders than Castlevania due to the themes throughout the game. The heart and spirit of the series is completely absent from Lords of Shadow, hence I only ever refer to it as Lords of Shadow.

-Story
I find it ironic that they rebooted Castlevania with an intended focus on story, and then ended up dropping the ball. The first game had an okay, albeit not-very-original story with Satan having Necron Syndrome and popping up literally out of nowhere at the end. Mirror of Fate was an atrocity of a game and explained jack squat. Similar problems are in LoS 2- Gabriel often finds himself back in what appears to be either the past of his memories of his castle. Honestly have no idea because it's never explained at all. His memories/past/whatever-the-fudge-is-going-on also has zero relevance to what's going on, aside from getting back his powers because reasons. There's also some Resident Evil bullcrap going on where the citizens are mutated by some demonic virus; this is so out of place it hurts. Everything else is fairly easy to follow, and there's some interesting things that do happen throughout the game, but it's nothing to write home about. Story is honestly not a good reason to play this game, and if it's what you're looking for, turn the other way.

Gabriel forgot how to Open Doors
Found a door? Guess what? You're going to have to pull a switch to open it. He's only a superhuman Prince of Darkness, godforbid he opens a metal door on his own. There's a lot of this crap that just slows the game down needlessly, especially since it takes forever for said doors to open. This game was made in 2014, this is rather inexcusable.

-Enemies can be Annoying
There's a guard/perfect guard mechanic in the game, which is quite useful. Unfortunately, roughly 50% of the time, the enemies perform an unblockable attack, which renders guarding a lot less useful than you'd like it to be. Also there's plenty of times where I simply wanted to get somewhere and didn't want to fight. Going places often involve climbing. Guess what? Every freaking enemy in the game can use some kind of projectile to knock you down, often forcing you to fight enemies when you don't want to. This is often infuriating when you merely want to explore for upgrades and other hidden items.

-Stealth Segments
Okay, I get that he's weak and whatnot at the beginning, but this just seems so unnecessary. Especially since the stealth segment with Agreus is absolutely infuriating.

-Bugs
Every now and then, characters may say something" without sound- basically the sound file for the line they're supposed to say doesn't play (no subtitles either
date: which is even more aggravating). I've had other instances where the objective was the last objective I just did

reviewText:
To preface: I came into this game off the expectations of the first Lords of Shadow, which I found to be one of the most worthwhile plays of the generation, marred only by the disconnect between cut-scene plot and loading screen plot (the former I chose to ignore for the much greater depth and intrigue of the latter). The way the last game ended, the trailer involving the castle siege, the unique universe and artistic style the game takes place in; how could they go wrong?

And at first, it seemed like they'd made another great game (just like the first, which also came out to muted-to-mediocre reception but would prove to be a stellar experience). Even beyond the introduction sequence, with the lackluster stealth, linearity and meagerness of the city, it stilled promised to be much more, at least to me.

For as long as I could, I held onto the concept that, at worst, it could be a poorly executed great concept; it kept sliding further and further away from that great concept ideal, to be expected of something coming from such a high plateu with too much expectation; a fault of my own if anything.

What was dreadful about this game, however, was not its inability to match the former game's great expectations: it was unbelievably poor direction the plot lurches towards the mid-to-end of the game. In almost complete contrast to Lords of Shadow, which started off slow, picked up speed and took off into orbit: this game started off in orbit, slowed down and instead of just falling to the ground, somehow fell into a wormhole that took it straight into the jaws of a black hole where it went full-on Event Horizon.

Give this game a massive miss; play the first and imagine what could have been, don't make the mistake that I did and assume the reviews were just a repeat of the first on release, of fans of Castlevania of old and this game just didn't live up to their rose-tinted rememberance of easiers times, and those who refused to do anything but accuse it of being a God of War clone, when it was so much more.

In short, this game represents a tragedy in what could have been, of which I am saddened to have been a part of.

reviewText:
To be perfectly honest, if you want more Lords of Shadow, you're better off replaying the first game.

I feel this one really missed the mark, and after reading about the internal struggles of the development team and their near-constant battle with their director, I can say I'm not really surprised.

Lords of Shadow 2 is, in every way, inferior to its predecessor. Graphically, it fails to impress. Mechanically, it feels sloppy. The combat is frustrating and choppy and, while LoS1 had its fair share of controller-throwing platforming segments, LoS2 doesn't even justify its own such moments with an equal helping of fun, satisfying ones. I have only put a couple hours into the game so far, and already I'm mad at it. I cannot comment on the overall story yet, but the beginning feels rushed and strange, and I have to feel bad for Patrick Stewart being forced to deliver such a petty script as Zobek. The writing is childish and uninspired, and the semi-animated lore sequence explaining the Belmont lineage is utterly boring.

But you know, I could forgive all of that if the game didn't so completely miss its own point. At no time during play did I ever FEEL like Dracula, who is supposed to be an absolute powerhouse, combining strength, speed, and magical abilities to devastate ranks upon ranks of foes. The most basic of enemies can take a monumental beating from any of your weapons, and can even attack straight through your combos to strike you. One minor strike from an enemy, however, will interrupt your combo and send you flying, which makes your stature feel pitiful, even if you aren't taking significant damage from those attacks. These problems are only magnified and exacerbated when, after the tutorial sequence, the story fast-forwards some centuries and resets all of Gabriel's powers, requiring you to slowly unlock them, one by one.

Other games have successfully portrayed their protagonists as extremely powerful beings without robbing the game of its core challenge. A great case in point is Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine. Lords of Shadow 2, however, takes the legendary Dracula and nerfs him into the ground, and then poops all over him with bad gameplay mechanics.

I'll say it again: if you want more LoS, play the first game again, because you'll enjoy it a whole lot more.

reviewText:
- Graphics :

Very very good. Few glitches here & there. Still wondering why Dracul would have a shadow but no reflection (because they're kind of the same thing...). But a very nice and polished game graphically speaking. Artistic direction is... you know, quite nice. The environment are less numerous than in the previous game considering we really have two sets : the castle & the modern town, but both are cool to explore (yes, even the modern world).

- Sound & Musics :

Voice acting is yet again very good, musics are kind of below the quality of the first game's ones.

- Gameplay :

A bit better than the first game : it's still the same thinking but with more variety (you got a whip, your fists & a sword this time), the moves are really fun to launch and there's more strategy this time. The boss fights have also improved.... 'xcept the last one...

- Storytelling :

So, it's the conclusion, and all in all it's not that bad but there's one thing that totally ruined it for me : the ending. The last battle & the ending following that is one of the worst I've seen. Last battle : too easy and not at all making you feel involved in it. And the ending was totally rushed, it just sucks. This whole ending was completely rushed.

- Length :

Half the time you'll need to complete the first LoS, this game is much shorter (partly due to the fact that it's much easier)


CONCLUSION :

IT'S NOT A BAD GAME. You need to remember that. BUT:  it's lacking a lot in the storytelling (especially nearing the end) & in environment. I still recommend it because the whole experience isn't a bad one... not just the epic game everyone was expecting.....

reviewText:
Lords of Shadow 2? ♥♥♥♥ yes.

Definately can't have enough Castlevania after Lords of Shadow 1, and LoS2 gives you the 'more' you needed. Although LoS2 has less atmosphere and eyecandy than Lords of Shadow 1,it's still a worthy and great sequel.

The gameplay as a whole is satisfactory (even the stealth parts have their own charm), and the combat is just as fun as the first game (although very identical, with a few different moves and weapons).

The story and progression are amazing, nothing to ever complain about.

I've played at the hardest diffculty available (before I've unlocked a harder difficulty), and found the game to be a bit too easy, only struggling at some bosses.

The game is slightly shorter than most single players (I've beat it in 13.5 hours), but enough to satisfy you, and there's the resurruction DLC that you can get if you haven't had enough.

Overall, the game is great and definately what you want and need after you're done with Lords of Shadow 1.

7.5/10

Bottom line: Solid game that is worth the money (on sale). I think I picked it & all DLC up on a seasonal sale for $20.
